text: no filling defect is identified within the pulmonary arteries.the thoracic aorta maintains a normal contour.the heart and pericardium are within normal limits.lungs show moderate bilateral pleural effusions, slightly increased since prior exam.multifocal airspace opacities are seen throughout both lungs consistent with pneumonia, slightly better aerated in the upper lobes compared to ___.since the last exam there is interval development of bronchietasis within the lingula, left upper lobe and right middle lobe.small mediastinal lymph nodes are present, the largest of which measures 1.2 cm in the left paratracheal station.limited views of the upper abdomen show ascites.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolus.multifocal patchy opacity within both lungs consistent with pneumonia, minimally improved in the upper lobes compared to ___.interval development of bronchiectasis within the lingula, left upper lobe and right middle lobe.bilateral pleural effusions, slightly increased in size.no intraluminal filling defect within the bilateral lower extremity veins from the popliteal to the common iliac ___.left suprapatellar knee joint effusion and ___ cyst.diffuse bodywall and extremity anasarca.large amount of free fluid within the included abdomen and pelvis.

text: the technical quality of the examination is good and allows to exclude pulmonary emboli at the level of the central, segmental and part of the subsegmental pulmonary arteries.also, there are no indirect signs for pe, no wedge-shaped peripheral opacities, no pleural effusions, no focal oligemia, and no signs of pulmonary infarction.the aorta is unremarkable, there are no signs of aortic dissection.massive cardiomegaly with enlargement of both the right and the left aspect of the heart, but without inversion of the septum.bilateral areas of atelectasis, combined to bilateral nonspecific ground-glass opacities.mild esophageal distention without wall thickening, moderate lymph node enlargement in the mediastinum, most likely associated to cardiac failure.small nodule in the left lobe of the thyroid.mild ascites, marked dilatation of the inferior vena cava.otherwise, no abnormalities seen in the imaged parts of the abdomen.
summary: no evidence of acute or chronic pe.no aortic pathology.massive cardiomegaly with bilateral areas of atelectasis and uncharacteristic ground- glass opacities.ascites and inferior vena cava dilatation.small left thyroid nodule.moderate mediastinal lymph node enlargement.

text: there is no evidence for pulmonary embolus.the visualized aorta and great vessels contain atherosclerotic calcifications.the visualized aorta is normal in caliber.the airways are patent to the segmental level bilaterally.there are moderate sized bilateral pleural effusions, right greater than left with associated bibasilar subsegmental atelectasis.no pathologically enlarged axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.calcifications are seen along the pleural surface of the lung suggesting prior asbestos exposure.multiple small collateral vessels are identified.within the visualized portions of the abdomen, the visualized liver, spleen, and kidneys are unremarkable in appearance.note is made of contrast refluxing down the inferior vena cava into the hepatic veins suggesting right heart failure.
summary: no evidence for pulmonary embolus.moderate sized bilateral pleural effusions with bibasilar subsegmental atelectasis.contrast refluxing down the hepatic veins suggesting right heart failure.pleural calcifications suggest prior asbestos exposure.

text: ct of the chest with contrast: a nodule measuring approximately 6 mm in diameter is noted in the right lung apex (2; 8) which appears stable from previous study.changes consistent with radiation therapy are also noted in the right lung (2; 17).a left pleural effusion is noted.there is mild bibasilar atelectasis.in the left pleura, there is a nodule measuring 7 mm in diameter that was not seen on previous study (2; 34).coronary artery calcifications are noted.no axillary lymphadenopathy is seen.there is no evidence for pneumothorax.a rounded opacity in the right lower lobe likely represents ateclectasis.
summary: left pleural effusion stable.new left pleural nodule of uncertain etiology.cholelithiasis without evidence of cholecystitis.ascites.fluid-filled right inguinal hernia.

text: there is no filling defect in pulmonary artery branches that could suggest presence of pulmonary embolism.pulmonary artery is persistently enlarged measuring 38 mm and suggests pulmonary hypertension.there is an interval new development of bilateral moderate pleural effusion associated with adjacent atelectasis in lung bases.there is interval worsening of interlobular septal thickening.asymmetric ground-glass opacities and foci of consolidation in right apex, dependent portions of upper lobes and left lower lobe.right middle lobe pleural thickening and atelectasis or scarring are unchanged.interval increase in size of mediastinal and bilateral hilar lymph nodes (known sarcoidosis) that are probably reactive to the lung process.calcifications are noted in the coronary arteries, aortic valve and along the aorta and great vessels.aorta is normal in size, without evidence of dissection.the asymmetric breast soft tissue should be correlated with regular mammogram as already recommended.imaged portions of the upper abdomen reveal presence of thickened left adrenal gland which is unchanged compared to prior study; otherwise unremarkable.
summary: negative examination for pulmonary embolism.persistent enlarged main pulmonary artery suggestive pulmonary hypertension.new development of moderate bilateral pleural effusions.interval development of septal thickening attributed to hydrostatic edema.asymmetric ground- glass opacities and consolidation that may represent asymmetric pulmonary edema, but superimposed infectious process or aspiration pneumonia should be considered in the appropriate clinical setting.interval increase in size of previously described lymph nodes in mediastinal and hilar regions..asymmetric breast soft tissue on the left.this should be correlated with regular mammogram as previously recommended.

text: an endotracheal tube is seen terminating at the thoracic inlet.a nasogastric tube is placed within the stomach.the heart and great vessels are unremarkable.there are diffuse mildly prominent mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes, some of which have central hilar calcification.there is mild dependent bibasilar atelectasis.
summary: diffuse fatty infiltration of the liver.no acute abnormalities.mediastinal and hilar adenopathy which may reflect underlying sarcoidosis.in an immunocompromised patient, tb would be in the differential, although this would be less likely.findings discussed with dr.___ on ___.

text: there is significant improvement in previously demonstrated post-surgical changes including loculated right pleural effusion and hydropneumothorax.the current study demonstrates stable appearance of post-surgical site at the right upper lung with no pneumo or hydrothorax.the right lung parenchyma demonstrates extensive areas of paraseptal and centrilobular emphysema, grossly unchanged since the prior study.previously demonstrated right upper lobe nodule is currently cavitated, 4:67, approximately 6 mm in diameter and should be closely followed.within the left lung, there are extensive areas of emphysema as well.there are no new areas of consolidations or new nodules of concern with right upper lobe subpleural thickening, 4:31, atelectasis at the right lung base, 4:113, left basal rounded atelectasis, 4:167 and lingular lobe subpleural nodule, 4:167, being unchanged.there is decrease in the right lower lobe nodule, 4:120, suggesting a small loculation of fluid rather than pulmonary nodule.the current study demonstrates extensive subpleural opacities most likely representing dependent atelectasis, giving the suboptimal inspiration of the study accompanied by areas of air trapping.questionable nodule adjacent to the left cardiac border is suspected, 4:200, which might represent artifact, but also a small aneurysm cannot be excluded and this area should be closely followed on the subsequent studies.the imaged portion of the upper abdomen demonstrates hypodense liver lesion, 2:55, most likely representing benign cysts by the dedicated imaging is recommended for precise characterization of this stable abnormality.additional liver lesions, 2:59, is 5 mm in diameter.partially imaged calcified right kidney cysts are redemonstrated and also might be evaluated by dedicated study.within the mediastinum, there is resolution of previously seen right lower paratracheal collection with currently stable lymph nodes seen at that area.there are no pathologically enlarged lymph nodes.extensive coronary calcifications involving all major coronary arteries.aorta is ___ calcified.small hiatal hernia is redemonstrated.
summary: significant improvement up to almost complete resolution of post- surgical complications.multiple pulmonary nodules as described, none of them enlarged but one being cavitated in attention to this area and a three-month follow up is highly recommended to exclude slow growing cavitating malignancy.bibasilar areas of atelectasis.questionable aneurysm versus nodule adjacent to the left heart border versus artifact.followup in three months is recommended as well as evaluation with echocardiography.extensive atherosclerosis as described.liver cysts, kidney lesions evaluation with dedicated abdominal ultrasound or ct abdomen might be suggested.extensive centrilobular and paraseptal emphysema, unchanged since the prior studies.

text: ct chest with iv and oral contrast: the thyroid is unremarkable.the heart and great vessels are unremarkable.there is no supraclavicular or axillary lymphadenopathy by ct criteria.the right lung is clear with no focal consolidation, pulmonary nodule or pleural effusion.the liver enhances homogeneously with no focal lesion.there is no portal vein thrombosis.there is no intra- or extra-hepatic biliary dilatation.there is no mediastinal lymphadenopathy by ct criteria.
summary: stable retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy with enlarged portacaval, as well as two right periaortic lymph nodes that are recorded in the oncology table for further follow up.soft tissue density between right kidney and liver.as well as soft tissue seen in the region of the splenectomy clips.

text: assessment of the pulmonary arteries is slightly suboptimal due to timing of the contrast bolus, with slight decreased opacification of the pulmonary arteries peripherally particularly at the lung bases.allowing for this limitation, no evidence of pulmonary embolism is seen.the visualized aorta maintains normal caliber throughout, without evidence of aneurysmal dilatation or dissection.note is made of coronary artery calcifications.otherwise the heart size is normal and there is no evidence of pericardial effusion.no evidence of mediastinal, hilar or axillary adenopathy is noted.compared to the ct torso of ___, there is new moderate-sized left pleural effusion which measures simple fluid in density, and is without evidence of fluid-fluid level.this is associated with atelectasis, particularly along the left lung base.no evidence of pneumothorax or right pleural effusion is noted.there is mild atelectasis noted in the right lung base.the airways remain patent to the subsegmental levels.a single calcified nodule is noted in the right lower lobe (3:37) consistent with prior granulomatous disease.while the current study is not designed for subdiaphragmatic evaluation, no gross abnormality is noted in the very limited views of the upper abdomen.multiple anterior left rib fractures are incompletely visualized on the current study, however the visualized fractures appear to be in similar alignment compared to the initial trauma ct.
summary: allowing for suboptimal opacification of the pulmonary arteries, no evidence of large or central pulmonary embolism is seen.new left pleural effusion.multiple anterior left-sided rib fractures appear unchanged in alignment, although they are incompletely visualized on the current study.

text: the great vessels of the thorax including the thoracic aorta and pulmonary artery show no acute pathology including no evidence of aortic dissection, or aneurysm.there is no large pulmonary embolism.moderate calcification of the aortic arch and at the origins of the supra-aortic vessels.there is no mediastinal hematoma and no pericardial effusion.there is a small to moderate sized right pneumothorax with small foci of air in the mediastinum consistent with trace pneumomediastinum.there are fractures of the eighth, ninth and tenth right lateral ribs with an associated small right lower lobe lung contusion at the right tenth rib fracture.the left lung appears is clear without pneumothorax.there is small right basilar atelectasis.there is no pleural effusion, and no mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy.extensive subcutaneous emphysema is seen in the right right chest wall extending to the supraclavicular soft tissues.
summary: small to moderate sized right pneumothorax and trace pneumomediastinum.eighth, ninth, tenth right lateral rib fractures and large amount of subcutaneous emphysema in the right chest wall.fatty liver.no acute abdominal injury.

text: the examination is compared to ___.there is status post left lower lobectomy.the previously hypo-ventilated remaining left lung is now almost completely expanded.only at the level around the stump and minimally cranial to this stump, a plate-like area of parenchymal compression is seen.the pre-described ground-glass nodules scattered throughout both lungs are no longer visible.unchanged millimetric right upper lobe subpleural granuloma (5, 116).unchanged 2-3 mm dorsal subpleural right upper lobe granuloma (5, 130).unchanged 3-mm triangular fissural thickening in the right lung (5, 168).4-5 mm left basal lung nodule with one pleural tag and small spiculations, potentially seen on the previous examination, but displaced by the pleural effusion that has resolved in the interval.because of its morphology, however, the nodule should undergo a ct followup in six months.no other lung nodules.no pericardial or pleural effusion.small hiatal hernia.the extrathoracic left-sided fluid collection seen on the previous ct scan is almost completely resolved (3, 14).the known right adrenal lesion has an unchanged size of 21 x 26 mm.no other abnormalities in the abdomen.no evidence of destructive bone lesions.
summary: substantially improved ventilation of the post-surgical left lung.potentially newly appeared 4 mm nodule in the left dorsal lung base, the nodule should undergo ct followup in approximately six months.complete resolution of the pre-existing scattered bilateral ground-glass opacities.several small mostly subpleural nodules in the right lung are not suspicious.unchanged size of a right adrenal lesion, likely to represent an adenoma.no evidence of local recurrence.

text: bilateral lower lobe airspace consolidations are present, left greater than right.there is volume loss, with portions of enhancing parenchya, and therefore a component of atelectasis.areas of heterogeneity with air are concerning for pneumonia.air within the consolidated air is likely aerated lung.the thoracic aorta opacifies normally.there is no pleural effusion or pericardial effusion.prominent lymph nodes within the mediastinum do not meeting size criteria for pathologic enlargement, the largest, a precarinal node while measuring 15 mm in short axis has a normal fatty hilum.note is made of dense vascular atherosclerotic calcifications.there are no enlarged hilar or axillary lymph nodes.tracheostomy tract is partially imaged.
summary: bilateral lower lobe airspace consolidation, left greater than right.while there is a component of atelectasis, areas of heterogeneous enhancement are worrisome for pneumonia.air attenuation foci within the right lower lobe likely represent areated lung, however, attention on follow-up studies is recommended to exclude cavitation/abscess formation.emphysema.4-cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm.massive ventral abdominal hernia.the liver, gallbladder, small bowel, and colon lie directly under the skin surface.this likely accounts for the physical exam finding of "crepitus".findings were discussed with dr.___ ___ on ___ at 6:20 p.m.

text: the thoracic aorta has moderate-to-severe atherosclerotic calcification and is tortuous, without evidence of aneurysmal dilation or dissection.the pulmonary arteries are well opacified to subsegmental levels without evidence of acute pulmonary embolism.moderate coronary arterial calcification is present.there is no pericardial effusion.bilateral moderate-to-large simple pleural effusions are seen, with compressive atelectasis of major portion of the lower lobes, new since the prior study.there is reflux of contrast into the hepatic veins and ivc, indicating right heart decompensation.small lymph nodes in both axilla do not meet ct criteria for significant adenopathy.no significant mediastinal or hilar adenopathy is seen.
summary: moderate-to-severe atherosclerotic calcification of the thoracoabdominal aorta without evidence of acute aortic dissection.no evidence of pulmonary embolism.infrarenal aortic aneurysm measuring 3.8 cm, stable since the prior study.bilateral moderate-to-large simple pleural effusions with compressive atelectasis of both lower lobes.possible right heart strain.

text: ct of the chest with iv contrast: again seen are two perifissural nodules in the right middle lobe which have increased in size since the previous study and now abut each other to form a lobulated mass.the largest pulmonary nodule measures 2.1 x 1.7 cm, previously 2.1 x 1.4 cm.the previously smaller nodule now measures 2.8 cm x 1.3 cm, previously 1.7 x 0.7 cm.a large bulla in the lateral aspect of the right upper lobe is stable in appearance and size.a new pulmonary nodule is present in the right lower lobe (2:44) and measures 7 mm x 5 mm.a subcarinal lymph node adjacent to the left main stem bronchus (2:32) measures 1.3 x 0.9 cm which was not definitively seen on the previous study.no other pathologically enlarged axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymph nodes are noted.a small hypodensity is noted within the right lobe of the thyroid measuring 6 x 5 mm, slightly better seen on today's study.
summary: increase in size of the right middle lobe pulmonary nodules.new right lower lobe pulmonary nodule measuring up to 7 mm.new left subcarinal lymph node measuring 1.3 x 0.9 cm.stable appearance of mild bilateral adrenal enlargement.

text: the study is compared with the series of the cects of the chest, dated ___, ___ and ___.there is prompt symmetric opacification of the pulmonary vascular tree, with no "filling defect" or vascular cut-off to suggest acute pulmonary embolism.the central pulmonary arteries are normal in caliber, with no ct finding to suggest pulmonary hypertension or right heart strain.the thoracic aorta is normal in caliber, contour, and opacification, with no finding to suggest dissection or other acute aortic process.there is relatively slight calcification of the lad, and the proximal coronary arteries are well-opacified, grossly patent and follow a normal course.there is no mediastinal or hilar adenopathy.there has been interval reaccumulation of a moderate-sized left pleural effusion, which appears loculated, particularly at the medial aspect of the left lung base, abutting and slightly effacing the left lateral aspect of the left atrium, as on earlier studies.this is associated with a small amount of loculated oblique fissural fluid, as well as persistent enhancement with some thickening, but no frank nodularity, of both visceral and parietal pleura.a small right pleural effusion is also seen.the left pleural fluid measures some 15-22 ___, pre-contrast, significantly lower in attenuation than on the ___ study, when it measured some 45 ___ (post-contrast).this process is associated with further left basilar subsegmental atelectasis, as well as scattered patchy ground-glass opacity and relatively smooth basilar interlobular septal thickening, non-specific, but also worse.no discrete consolidation is seen and the airways are patent to the subsegmental level.though the examination was not tailored to evaluate the infradiaphragmatic structures, again demonstrated are extensive surgical suture material at the gastroesophageal junction, apparently related to previous bypass procedure, with hiatal hernia.the patient is status post splenectomy with known splenosis in the left upper abdomen; the known intra- and extrahepatic biliary ductal dilatation is barely appreciated on the current examination.
summary: no evidence of acute pulmonary embolism or aortic process.recurrent left pleural effusion with evidence of loculation and associated atelectasis, but no definite consolidation.this finding is significantly worse since the ___ ct (status post removal of the pigtail drainage catheter) and should be correlated with detailed clinical information.although there is a small right pleural effusion, there is no ct evidence of chf.intra-abdominal findings, with very limited evaluation.findings posted to the ed dashboard.

text: thyroid gland is normal in appearance with symmetric enhancement.the patient is intubated with endotracheal tube in appropriate position 3.2 cm above the carina.numerous mediastinal nodes are seen, most notably is a 1.1 cm pretracheal node (2a:43).an additional 1-cm pretracheal node (2:32).there is no hilar, axillary, or supraclavicular nodes seen.there are pathologic nodes seen, though multiple non-enlarged nodes are noted.the heart is unremarkable without pericardial effusion.the aorta and major vessels are patent with incidental note made of a bovine arch.no pulmonary embolism is seen.the trachea and central airways appear patent, though evaluation of the distal airways is limited by motion.right upper lobe is better aerated than on the prior study with patchy poorly marginated nodular consolidation concerning for infective or inflammatory process.right lower lobar partial collapse is again noted.there is worsening since the prior study of the left lower lobar atelectasis.there may be a 7-mm left lower lobe nodule (2a:68); however differentiation of focal consolidation or atelectasis in the setting of all of the adjacent consolidative atelectatic changes is limited.small right and trace left pleural effusions are noted.soft tissues of the chest are unremarkable.the right medial pneumothorax or pneumomediastinum has worsened in the interim.extensive right pneumomediastinum with possible pneumopericardium is noted along with tracking of the air along the posterior border of the left atrium.air tracks along the anterior border of the trachea inferiorly to the esophagus.foci of pneumothorax are also identified along the inferomedial border of the right middle lobe.air also appears to track along interlobular septae again, as mentioned, there is trace left and small right pleural effusions.no clear source for the pneumomediastinum is identified
summary: interval increase in the degree of pneumomediastinum and possibly pneumopericaridum predominantly along the right mediastinal border tracking posteriorly and along the trachea and esophagus.etiology uncertain, but etiologies certainly include airway or esophageal injury.decrease in degree of collapse of the right upper lobe with poorly marginated nodular opacities remain concerning for infectious or inflammatory process.could also reflect ongoing reexpansion.persistent right and left lower lobe consolidation, greater on the right likely due to atelectasis.new small right and trace left pleural effusions.no pulmonary embolism.mediastinal lymphadenopathy of uncertain etiology.no free intraperitoneal air with new small volume ascites.celiac narrowing due to median arcuate ligament syndrome.changes to the preliminary interpretation were discussed with dr.___ by dr.___ at 9:40 on ___.

text: centrilobular emphysema is moderately severe in the upper lungs, milder elsewhere.bronchial wall thickening and mucus plugging is predominantly basal accompanied by moderate air trapping due to small airways obstruction.in the right lung multiple ground glass nodules and small regions of consolidation are seen in the upper lobe, the most conspicuous are a 2.1 x 1.3 cm juxtapleural consolidation (5:87), and 1.3 cm (5:111) and smaller ground glass nodules (5:113 and 5:123).in the left lower lobe a solitary juxtapleural consolidation (5:264) is surrounded by ground glass opacity.there is no pleural abnormality.the airways are patent to the segmental level.with the exception of a 1.2 cm right hilar node (3:32), no central or axillary lymph nodes are enlarged by ct size criteria.the heart is mildly enlarged althugh this study is not tailored for such assessment.coronary artery calcification is extensive.there is no pericardial effusion.the esophagus is dilated and somewhat patuloous, but no mass, likely stricture, or hiatal hernia is observed.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism or acute aortic syndrome.multifocal consolidations with associated bronchial wall thickening and mucus plugging suggest both small airways inflammation and active infection.ground glass nodules can be inflammatory also, but require 6-month followup because of the possibility of carcinoma in situ.dilated, patulous esophagus without wall thickening.aspiration due to esophageal dysfunction could be contributing to bronchial inflammation and infection.swallowing study recommended.severe coronary and aortic atherosclerosis, including ulcerated, but non-penetrating, aortic ulceration.

text: no axillary lymph nodes are identified.scattered mediastinal lymphadenopathy is identified with a representative node measuring 12 mm (2:16).the tracheobronchial tree is patent to subsegmental levels.the heart is mildly enlarged, though there is no pericardial effusion.the visualized great vessels are within normal limits.no central pulmonary embolism is identified on this portal venous phase study.dependent bibasilar atelectasis is identified.a 9 x 8 mm nodule is identified in the posterior aspect of the left upper lobe.there is no pleural effusion.
summary: no acute traumatic pathology within the chest, abdomen or pelvis.9 x 8 mm nodule in the posterior inferior segment of the left upper lobe.recommend followup ct at three months for further evaluation.pet/ct could also be considered if there is clinical concern for malignancy.scattered mediastinal lymphadenopathy, non-specific.evaluate for resolution/change at follow-up ct.6 mm soft tissue density nodule in the left paracolic gutter of uncertain significance.recommend close attention to the this region on follow-up imaging.

text: there is complete collapse of bilateral lower lobes with secretions in the supplying airways.patchy right upper lobe/linguar opacities and right middle lobe consolidation is compatible with multifocal pneumonia.the pulmonary arteries are normally opacified.the thoracic aorta is normal in caliber and contour.the heart size is normal.there is no pericardial effusion.small left pleural effusion is nonhemorrhagic.there is no central lymphadenopathy.the bones show no lesion worrisome for osseous metastasis.this exam is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation except to note normal size of the adrenal glands.
summary: complete collapse of bilateral lower lobes with secretions in the supplying airways.right middle lobe consolidation and patchy opacities in the lingula/ right upper lobe compatible with multifocal pneumonia.small nonhemorrhagic left pleural effusion.no pulmonary embolus.

text: there is no supraclavicular, axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymphadenopathy.a prominent right paratracheal lymph node measures 10 mm, but with normal morphology (2:21).the heart size is normal, and there is no pericardial effusion.the great vessels are unremarkable.this study is not optimized for subdiaphragmatic evaluation.within these limitations, the adrenal glands are normal, and there is no gross upper abdominal abnormality.there is a small right pleural effusion.there are no concerning pulmonary nodules.a calcified granuloma is seen in the right hilum (4:119).diffuse ground-glass opacity in the left lung base is consistent with atelectasis.there is mild centrilobular emphysema.there is severe scoliosis of the spine and marked degenerative change, but no focal osseous lesion concerning for malignancy.
summary: no evidence of active or latent tuberculosis.trace right pleural effusion and left basilar atelectasis.mild emphysema.no evidence of pneumonia or other active infectious process.

text: opacification of the pulmonary vasculature demonstrates no filling defect to suggest pulmonary embolism.the aorta is normal in caliber and contour.confluent opacities are visualized at the right lower lobe with a small nonhemorrhagic effusion adjacent.these findings are most likely representative of right lower lobe pneumonia with a small parapneumonic effusion.furthermore, there is a moderate left pleural effusion with near complete collapse of the left lower lobe.multiple prominent mediastinal lymph nodes are visualized, with the largest being an 18 x 14 aortopulmonary window lymph node (3:25).additionally, there is a focal soft tissue density at the left hilus measuring 14 x 13 mm (3:32) suggesting either a lymph node or possibly a mass.there is no axillary lymphadenopathy by ct size criteria.the heart is moderately enlarged but without a pericardial effusion.dual lead pacemaker appears in place with the leads terminating in the right atrium and ventricle.mitral valve prosthesis appears in place.enteric tube with the tip in the stomach, et tube with the tip in the mid trachea.osseous structures: there are no lytic or sclerotic osseous lesions suspicious for malignancy.
summary: right lower lobe pneumonia with a small parapneumonic effusion.complete collapse of the left lower lobe and moderate left pleural effusion.while the left lower lobe collapse may be due to mucoid impaction, the presence of mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy raises suspicion for an endobronchial or hilar lesion.however, this is difficult to assess at this point since the patient's lymphadenopathy may be reactive and due to pneumonia.as a result, a dedicated chest ct with contrast is recommended after resolution of pneumonia for further characterization.furthermore, consultation with pulmonology is recommended as the presence of an endobronchial lesion needs to be excluded.no evidence of pulmonary embolism or acute aortic injury.these findings were discussed by dr.___ with dr.___ via telephone at 8:40 am on ___.

text: the aorta is normal in caliber throughout without acute pathology.the pulmonary arterial tree is well opacified to the subsegmental level, without new filling defects to suggest acute pulmonary embolism.there remains to be resolving subsegmental thrombus within the right lower lobe posterior basal segment (3, 63), with associated probable pulmonary infarct (3, 64), with significant interval improvement of a clot burden since ___, ___.the heart is mildly enlarged particularly the left atrium and left ventricle.there is no evidence of right heart strain.there is a single-lead pacer/aicd lead terminating in the right atrium.subcentimeter prevascular, precarinal, subcarinal, and hilar lymph nodes are present.there is no axillary adenopathy by size criteria.there are bilateral small pleural effusions, right greater than left.there are new nodular peribronchovascular opacities throughout bilateral lungs, but predominating the right upper and middle lobes, highly suggestive of infection.central airways are patent.limited subdiaphragmatic evaluation demonstrates borderline fatty liver.within the lungs there are nodular peribronchovascular consolidations.within the right base there is wedge shaped opacity consistent with pulmonary infarct.
summary: resolving subsegmental pe in the basal posterior segment of the right lower lobe with diminishing area of now wedge shaped pulmonary infarct.no new pulmonary embolism.new multifocal bronchopneumonia, right greater than left lung.small bilateral pleural effusions, right greater than left.borderline fatty liver.no rib fractures.

text: again identified are multiple rounded low- attenuation cystic lesions within the anterior mediastinum, right hilum, and left infrahilar region of the mediastinum.the largest of these lesions in the left infrahilar region measures 11 x 6.7 cm and contains enhancing septa.this lesion causes severe extrinsic compression on the left lower lobe bronchus narrowing it to diameter of 1 mm.there is associated collapse of the left lower lobe.within the collapsed parenchyma, again seen is a 3-cm cavitary lesion with a thick enhancing rim (3:79).the largest hilar lesion (2:43) measures 5.8 x 3.7 cm and severely narrows the right lower lobe bronchus to a diameter of 1.5 mm.similarly, there is attenuation of the bronchus to the right middle lobe to a diameter of 3 mm (2:39).there is mild atelectasis, but no definite airspace consolidation within the right lung.again noted are several pleural-based masses, the largest along the lateral chest measuring 3 cm.numerous discrete subcentimeter nodular masses are seen along the right fissure extending towards the right hilum (2:42).a left pleural effusion has decreased in size.the heart size is normal.there are coronary artery and mitral valve calcifications.the degree of previously reported tracheal stenosis is less apparent on today's study secondary to improved inspiratory effort.however, on expiratory views, there is evidence of tracheomalacia as the cross- sectional area of the trachea narrows to less than 50% of the inspiratory volume.patient is noted to be post-median sternotomy and cabg.in the imaged upper abdomen, innumerable low-attenuation lesions are noted within the spleen (2:68).there are enlarged lymph nodes within the porta hepatis.bone windows demonstrate mild irregularity of the posterior right fourth and fifth ribs suggestive of prior thoracotomy.degenerative changes are seen within the visualized thoracic spine.
summary: multiple mediastinal and bilateral hilar cystic masses, the largest measuring 11 cm.hilar lesions cause high grade narrowing of the bronchi.several small right pleural lesions and perilymphatic nodules in right mid lung.multifocal distribution is not typical for provided diagnosis of lymphangioma and raises concern for a lymphoproliferative process such as lymphoma, especially given presence of numerous low- density splenic lesions, perilymphatic and pleural nodules, and periportal lymphadenopathy.numerous low-density splenic nodules concerning for lymphoproliferative disease such as lymphoma.infectious process and metastatic disease are less likely considerations.interval decrease in left pleural effusion.cavitation within the left lower lobe parenchyma suggestive of necrotizing pneumonia with abscess formation and less likely cavitary neoplasm.tracheomalacia.

text: an endotracheal tube is in satisfactory position approximately 5 cm above the carina.a nasogastric tube is in the stomach.there are two right chest tubes entering laterally.the posterior chest tube tip extends to just above the right apex.there is a moderate right pleural effusion which is partially loculated.there is the split pleura sign which can be seen with exudative effusion.there is a small left simple pleural effusion.a small retrosternal fluid collection is present above the xiphoid.there is extensive subcutaneous edema in the anterior chest wall tissues in this region as well.there is evidence of sternotomy.there is no significant axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.the heart, pericardium, and great vessels are unremarkable.evaluation of the lungs reveal consolidation with air bronchograms in the right lower lobe.there is compressive atelectasis involving the left base.in the imaged portion of the upper abdomen, the visualized liver, gallbladder, spleen, and pancreas are unremarkable.note is made of a right renal cyst.incidental note is made of gynecomastia.there is no signficant osseous abnormality.
summary: partially loculated moderate right pleural effusion with enhancing pleura suggesting complex exudative effusion such as empyema.adjacent right basilar consolidation with air bronchograms consistent with pneumonia.small left effusion with associated atelectasis.two right chest tubes, one with tip just above right apex.no pneumothorax.please note that pulmonary embolism cannot be accurately assessed with this examination and if this is a concern, dedicated pulmonary embolis cta could be considered.

text: chest: there is an approximately 3-4 mm pulmonary nodule within the right lower lobe (series 3, image 39).the presence or absence of this small nodule on the pet-ct of ___ is difficult to ascertain due to substantial differences in technique.there are no other nodules.the lungs are clear of consolidation.the central airways are clear.there is no axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymphadenopathy by size criteria.incidental note is made of a bovine arch.the aorta is normal in caliber.scattered atheromatous calcifications are noted within the thoracic aorta as well as the coronary arteries.postoperative changes from cabg are noted.there is concentric wall thickening of the distal esophagus to approximately the level of the ge junction.this is compatible with the patient's known esophageal cancer.
summary: distal esophageal thickening, consistent with the patient's known esophageal cancer.incidental: nonspecific 3-4 mm pulmonary nodule within the right lower lobe as described above; this should be followed up on subsequent examinations.nonspecific lucent foci within s1 and l5; attention should be paid to this location on subsequent followups.

text: in the anterior mediastinum, there is a 2.1 x 1.2 triangular bilobed-appearing soft tissue density in the location for the thymus, increased in comparison to the previous exam.at the left apex, there is a tiny 2 mm noncalcified soft tissue density, which may represent a scar, and was not included on the previous study for comparison.a similar appearing 2 mm nodule in the periphery of the right upper lobe is seen, unchanged from the previous exam of ___.finally, there is a focal ___ mm ill-defined opacity in the periphery of the superior segment of the left lower lobe, which may relate to prior inflammatory change seen in this area on previous exam.there are no pleural effusions or focal areas of consolidation.there is a linear scar seen along the right lung base, noted on previous exam and unchanged.there is no hilar or axillary lymph node enlargement.the heart and pericardium are normal.
summary: interval appearance of soft tissue density in the location of the thymus, with triangular bilobed configuration most suggestive of rebound thymic hyperplasia.however, clinical correlation and follow up is recommended.a few tiny lung nodules as described, 2 of which were noted on previous exam.the remainder may not have been depicted due to the small size of the lesions.attention to these findings is recommended on continued follow up.nonspecific well defined, rounded soft tissue density measuring 8 mm in the subcutaneous fat of the lower abdominal wall, just to the left of midline.the finding is nonspecific, but not definitively seen on the prior ct pelvis of ___.this is likely a benign finding and could releate to subcutaneous injections or trauma if the patient has suach a history.clinical correlation is recommended.attention will be paid to this are on follow-up.

text: there is no mediastinal hemorrhage, pneumomediastinum, or pericardial effusion.there is a small left pleural effusion with overlying atelectasis.right base atelectasis is seen.the thoracic aorta appears intact.there is no mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy.there are small lung contusions in the peripheral left upper lung zone due to multiple rib fractures.there are slightly displaced segmental rib fractures (fracture sites at two points, both at the posterior and the lateral ribs) of the third through sixth left ribs.there is no pneumothorax.there is no evidence of right-sided rib fractures.there is a comminuted fracture of the left scapula (series 2, image 13 and series 601b, image 42).there is a superior endplate compression fracture of t8 and a superior and inferior endplate compression fracture of t11 without evidence of retropulsed fragments.
summary: segmental slightly displaced left rib #3-#6 fractures.mild left pulmonary contusion.small left pleural effusion with overlying atelectasis.no pneumothorax.comminuted left scapular fracture.t8 and t11 vertebral compression fractures without evidence of retropulsion.

text: filling defects consistent with acute pulmonary embolism are noted in the distal left and right main pulmonary arteries (not saddle morphology) with extension into segmental branches of all pulmonary lobes.the main pulmonary artery is slightly enlarged at 2.8 cm diameter.the right ventricle is prominent in size suggesting elevated right heart pressure and possible strain.there is no acute aortic abnormality.the lung parenchyma is obscured by respiratory motion.dependent opacity of the right lower lobe is probably due to atelectasis.there is no hypoenhancing portion of this to suggest infarction.there is mild dependent change of the base of the left lower lobe.there is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax.there is no pericardial effusion.limited evaluation of the upper abdomen ___ fatty infiltration of the liver.
summary: acute pulmonary embolism involving both distal main pulmonary arteries with extension into segmental branches of all pulmonary lobes.prominence of the right ventricle suggests right heart strain for which further evaluation with echocardiography is suggested.fatty liver.these findings were immediately discussed with dr.___ ___ of the emergency room at 10:20 p.m.___ at which time an er dashboard wet read was also placed.

text: the examination is compared to ___.the pre-existing lung nodules have increased in size.for example, the pre-existing nodule in the right upper lobe, 7.4 mm on the previous examination, is now 9.3 x 10.1 mm.a second large nodule in the left lower lobe, previously 12 mm, is now 17 x10 mm.there is no evidence of newly appeared lung nodules.the airways are patent.there is minimal left apical scarring.no focal parenchymal opacities suggesting pneumonia.moderate subpleural bilateral basal areas of atelectasis, the pleural surfaces are even, no evidence of pleural lesions.no pleural effusions.no evidence of enlarged hilar or mediastinal lymph nodes.no osteo-destructive abnormality.no evidence of larger masses the abdomen.
summary: size progression of the pre-existing pulmonary nodules.no newly occurred pulmonary nodules.otherwise, unchanged examination.

text: the heart and great vessels are unremarkable.there is no pericardial effusion.there is bilateral atelectasis, left greater than right.there is a linear focus of atelectasis just distal to the right mainstem bronchus that tracks posteriorly.no pulmonary nodules or opacities are present.there are no pathologic mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymph nodes.
summary: linear atelectasis distal to the right mainstem bronchus could be secondary to intubation.small left pleural effusion with associated atelectasis.lungs are otherwise clear.no acute intra- abdominal or pelvic injuries.incidentally noted gallstones.

text: a predominately saccular pseudoaneurysm of the inferior aortic arch seen best on coronal imaging measures 4.2 x 2.7 cm (105b:30) compared with 4.1 x 2.7 cm on ___.the ap diameter of 3.5 cm is also unchanged.the proportion of the pseudoaneurysm with contrast filling measures 1.4 x 0.9 cm on coronal imaging and is unchanged.the patient is status post coronary artery bypass grafting with opacification of the patient's vein grafts.extensive atherosclerotic disease is present in the remainder of the thoracic and abdominal aorta.atherosclerotic narrowing is present of the left renal artery.no abdominal aortic aneurysm is seen.no pathologically enlarged axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymph nodes are seen.no pericardial or pleural effusion is identified.moderate/severe emphysema is seen in both lungs.no pulmonary nodules or masses are identified.
summary: a predominantly thrombosed saccular pseudoaneurysm arising from the inferior aortic arch measuring 3.8(si) x 3.1(tv) x 3.5(ap) cm is unchanged in overall size compared to ___.the nonthrombosed portion of this pseudoaneurysm that fills with contrast is also unchanged.severe emphysema.cholelithiasis.unchanged appearance of an atrophic ___ left kidney.bilateral simple renal cysts.

text: there are no filling defects in the central or segmental pulmonary arteries to suggest pulmonary embolism.there are bilateral moderate-sized pleural effusions with adjacent compression atelectasis.lungs are otherwise clear.patient is status post aortic valve replacement and ascending aortic graft as well as cabg with patent graft vessels.lad is diffusely calcified.there is no pericardial effusion.central airways are patent to the segmental levels bilaterally.osseous structures demonstrate no suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions.
summary: no evidence of central or segmental pulmonary embolism.bilateral moderate-sized pleural effusions with adjacent atelectasis.findings were communicated to the eu via dashboard.

text: there is significant respiratory motion limiting the evaluation of the segmental branches in the lower lungs.there is an apparent filling defect in the segmental branch to the anterobasal left lower ___ (3:51) which may be clot or artifact.the remaining pulmonary arterial circuit is free of filling defect.the main pulmonary artery is slightly enlarged in size measuring 3.4 cm in diameter.mild atherosclerotic disease of the left anterior descending and left circumflex arteries is noted.the heart is moderately enlarged.the aorta is of normal caliber and contour.there is no aortic dissection.extensive mediastinal lymphadenopathy is not significantly changed compared to ___.there is a rounded focus in the left lateral mid-thoracic esophagus at the level of the aortic arch, which is new relative to the prior exam (3:22).lung windows demonstrate chronic volume loss in the right hemithorax consistent with prior lobectomy.on today's examination, there are multiple focal areas of opacity present within the left upper ___.there is a small focus in the lateral basal segment of the left lower ___.ground glass opacity present in the remnant right upper ___ which may represent pneumonia versus atelectasis.there mild associated basilar atelectasis.there is minimal dependent right basilar atelectasis.limited views of the upper abdomen demonstrate stable pneumobilia, unchanged compared to previous examination.bone windows demonstrate a stable lucency present within a left thoracic posterior mid rib.aside from multilevel degenerative disease, no suspicious lytic or blastic lesions are detected.
summary: questionable embolus in the anterobasal left lower ___, ___ be artifactual given respiratory motion.no other filling defects present.multifocal airspace disease most consistent in appearance with multifocal pneumonia.clinical correlation is recommended.stable mediastinal, hilar lymphadenopathy.stable pneumobilia.possible soft tissue mass versus retained food in the mid esophagus.further evaluation by esophagram is recommended when clinically feasible.

text: since ___, widespread peribronchial abnormality in both lungs, less severe in upper lobes and more dense in lower lobes significantly improved and are now only ground- glass opacity.thickened interlobular septae with mild retraction of very small bronchi almost completely cleared.bronchiolar nodules in upper lobes also almost completely cleared.lung volumes remain low.airways are patent to the subsegmental level.prevascular lymph nodes are still enlarged and unchanged up to 10 x 16 mm.other mediastinal lymph nodes are not enlarged.axillary lymph nodes are numerous, but not meeting ct criteria for enlargement.there is no hilar lymph node.pericardial effusion cleared.there is no pleural effusion.this study was not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation, but the upper abdomen is unremarkable.bones remain normal.
summary: significant improvement in bilateral peribronchial opacity, more prominent in lower lobes, now only of ground-glass opacity without foci of denser consolidation.thickening of interlobular septae, very mild retraction and few bronchiolar nodules, almost completely cleared.pericardial effusion cleared.persistent prevascular lymph node enlargement with normal appearance of other mediastinal lymph nodes is slightly unusual for reactive lymph nodes.close followup is recommended in ___ months.

text: the mediastinal vessels appear unremarkable, except for some small atherosclerotic plaques in the descending aorta and some calcifications in the aortic arch.there are some small mediastinal lymph nodes.no mediastinal lymphadenopathy is noted.the pulmonary arteries are well opacified and are unremarkable, without evidence for filling defects.on lung windows, there is a new 9-mm nodular density in the right upper lobe.this is fairly ill defined and appears to have a lucency within it.some linear opacities are noted in the lower lobes bilaterally.a nodule in the right lower lobe is stable in size.small areas of consolidation are again noted in the right lower lobe and the right middle lobe.
summary: no evidence for pe.new ill-defined nodule within the right upper lobe as described above.the nodule measures 9 mm and the etiology is unclear, it might be infectious in origin, but neoplasm cannot be excluded.this should be followed to complete resolution on ct after treatment (at the latest with a 3-month followup scan).alternatively, if there is a high suspicion for carcinoma, a pet scan could be obtained.other lung changes stable as described above.

text: non-contrast examination demonstrates vascular calcifications of the coronary arteries which is unchanged since prior examinations.vascular calcifications are also noted.the thyroid is enlarged and somewhat low in location, with components almost substernal in locale.comparison of metastatic disease is difficult, given different distribution of disease.the metastases appear to be confined to the right hemithorax, with intralobular septal thickening which is new or progressed since the prior examination, indicating progression from the standpoint.consolidation of the right lower and middle lobes is slightly worse based on comparison of sagittal reformations, despite allowance for the decreased fluid in the pleural effusion on the current examination secondary to the paracentesis.exact comparison of the innumerable nodules involving the right lobe is again difficult due to the collapse of portions of the lungs on the prior examination which are better aerated today.some nodules appear somewhat smaller than on the prior examination.for instance, a dominant superior nodule (3:29) which measures approximately 13 x 16 mm on the current examination measured approximately 15 x 17 mm previously.other nodules such as one just posterior to this (series 3, image 25) appear larger, measuring 13 x 10 mm on the current examination and compared with 9 x 8 mm on the prior examination.however, there are some new patchy areas of soft tissue density and nodularity lobe (series 5, image 57), suggesting regions of progressed disease as well.examination of soft tissue structures demonstrates no axillary lymphadenopathy.ap window lymph nodes measuring up to 11 mm are present, and essentially unchanged.other small mediastinal lymph nodes also appear grossly unchanged.right hilar lymphadenopathy appears slightly worse than the prior examination, measuring up to approximately 14 mm, whereas on the prior examination measured only up to 9 mm in short axis.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism.size of pleural effusions is significantly less than on the prior comparison examination of ___, presumably due to the recent thoracentesis.right lower and middle lobe consolidation appears slightly worse since ___, and new intralobular septal thickening is present.it is possible that this is secondary to venous congestion from the previously described mass, although lymphangitic spread of disease remains a consideration.mediastinal lymphadenopathy is unchanged.right hilar lymphadenopathy may be slightly enlarged.

text: comparison is made to study dated ___.bilateral subclavian stents are again noted.no pathologically enlarged mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymph nodes are identified.radiation change predominantly involving the right superior mediastinal contour has a similar appearance.heart, great vessels, and pericardium appear grossly normal.assessment of lung fields demonstrates no suspicious nodular densities.there is a small right pleural effusion.airways are patent to the level of subsegmental bronchi bilaterally.imaged portions of the upper abdomen demonstrate no significant abnormalities.small amount of right renal remnant tissue is again seen following nephrectomy.no suspicious lytic or blastic osseous lesions are identified.
summary: stable post-radiation changes.no evidence of disease recurrence.

text: the lungs are clear except for a 2.9 cm bulla at the right lung base.heart size is normal and there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.no pathologically enlarged mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymph nodes.
summary: two new subcentimeter arterially enhancing foci (without washout) within segment v of the liver in the area of prior heterogeneous abnormality and overlying hematoma.these foci may represent perfusion anomalies related to trauma from the subcapsular hematoma; however, hcc is not excluded.given the indeterminate nature of these lesions, a short-term followup by multiphasic ct in three months is recommended.findings will be conveyed to dr.___ via the radiology communications dashboard.continued decrease in size of the subcapsular hepatic hematoma.portal venous anastomotic stenosis as seen previously.signs of portal hypertension including splenic venous enlargement and splenomegaly.

text: the pulmonary arteries are well opacified showing no evidence of filling defect suspicious for emboli.the aorta is unremarkable in size showing no evidence of dissection.since ___, there is progressive worsening of a now moderate right pleural effusion and a stable moderate left pleural effusion.the ground- glass opacity previously seen has gradually decreased on today's examination, although there is significant amount of motion artifact in the upper lobes.there are multiple non-pathologically enlarged subcentimeter lymph nodes seen in the mediastinal compartments unchanged since the prior study.in addition, there are multiple bilateral, left more than right axillary lymph nodes, also stable since the prior study.the heart is mildly enlarged, stable.a trace amount of pericardial effusion is noted mainly anteriorly; stable.adjacent to the effusions are compressed atelectatic lung tissue with a component of aspiration.the bony structures demonstrate a well-defined sclerotic focus seen in the right scapular ___, measuring approximately 13.8 x 13.2 mm.no other similar sclerotic foci are seen.some degenerative changes are noted in the spine.a tracheostomy tube terminates in the mid tracheal level in a satisfactory location.the limited evaluation of the abdomen shows no abnormality.
summary: negative examination for pe or aortic dissection.worsening moderate right pleural effusion and stable moderate left pleural effusion with adjacent atelectasis and a component of aspiration.no definite evidence of pneumonia is seen.trace amount of stable pericardial effusion.a sclerotic right scapular bony lesion for which a bone scan examination is recommended.stable non-pathologically enlarged lymph nodes in the mediastinum and axillary areas.clinical correlation is recommended.this report has been placed on the radiology dashboard for it to be conveyed to the referring physician.

text: the imaged portions of the thyroid gland appear within normal limits.there is a tracheostomy tube with its tip terminating approximately 2.1 cm above the carina.there is a left upper extremity access picc line with its tip terminating in the svc.there is no axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymphadenopathy.the cardiac ___ appear within normal limits.the thoracic aorta is normal in caliber.the pulmonary artery is normal in caliber.there are no filling defects within the central pulmonary arterial tree.there are no pulmonary nodules or masses.the lung volumes are low.there are mild linear opacities in the lung bases related to atelectasis.tracheobronchial tree is patent.
summary: no evidence of malignancy in the chest, abdomen, or pelvis.notably distended urinary bladder containing gas.correlate with history of recent instrumentation.

text: there is no axillary lymphadenopathy.a small prevasular and lower paratracheal lymph nodes are present, consistent with known hiv disease.the heart is enlarged.there is patchy bibasilar consolidation which probably represents pulmonary edema.in the left lung posteriorly within this consolidation, there is a rounded opacity abutting the pleura which may represent a lymph node.attention to this region is recommended on follow up.there are no pleural effusions.
summary: bilateral lower lobe patchy lung opacities probably representing pulmonary edema.infection cannot be fully excluded.focal area of nodularity within left-sided infiltrate to which attention should be paid on follow-up exams.splenomegaly.3.benign, congenital hemangioma in the liver.

text: there is a hemodialysis catheter with its tip in the cavoatrial junction.there is an enlarged pretracheal and right paratracheal lymphadenopathy, the largest node measuring 1.1 cm (image 9, series 4).there are bulky pericardial and left hilar nodes.the main pulmonary artery is not enlarged (2.2cm).the pulmonary arteries are patent and demonstrate no filling defects.the visualized aorta is unremarkable, without evidence of dissection.there is cardiomegaly with evidence of contrast reflux into the hepatic vein.there is a moderate-sized right pleural effusion and a small left pleural effusion.the tracheobronchial tree is patent.scattered throughout the lungs is diffuse ground-glass opacity with associated centrilobular nodules.there is an upper lobe predominance to these airspace opacities.dependent passive atelectasis is seen at the right lower lobe related to the effusion.less marked left lower lobe atelectasis is also appreciated.interlobular septal thickening is also appreciated.there are no suspicious skeletal abnormalities.
summary: there is no evidence of pulmonary embolism.cardiomegaly with evidence of venous reflux into the hepatic veins, suggesting right heart failure.bilateral pleural effusions.diffuse ground-glass opacities, intralobular septal thickening.the findings are most consistent with pulmonary edema.differential consideration in an acute setting would include pulmonary hemorrhage or infectious causes.clinical correlation is required.

text: the thoracic aorta is of normal caliber, and there is no evidence of acute aortic pathology.the central and segmental pulmonary arteries demonstrate no filling defects.the heart is unremarkable, and there is no evidence of pericardial effusion.bilateral right greater than left small-to-moderate pleural effusions are present with associated atelectasis.there are no pathologically enlarged axillary lymph nodes.a precarinal node measures 9 mm in short axis diameter, which does not meet the ct criteria for pathologic enlargement.lung windows reveal perihilar and upper lobe foci of consolidation bilatterally on a background of ground glass change.the airways are patent to the level of the segmental bronchi, bilaterally.an endotracheal tube terminates approximately 3.7cm above the carina.
summary: no acute aortic pathology.however, there is near-complete occlusion of the right common iliac artery extending into that external iliac artery with poor opacification of internal iliac artery branches.small-to-moderate bilateral pleural effusions with perihilar and upper lobar patchy consolidation and ground-glass change, concerning for infectious consolidation or aspiration on a background of volume overload.partial occlusion of superior mesenteric artery with opacification of the more distal sma.non-contrast evaluation of bowel is very limited but grossly unremarkable with no finding to suggest ischemia.

text: bibasilar centrilobular ground-glass nodules and peripheral tree-in-___ opacities are most apparent in the right lower lobe, though also seen in the left lower lobe and right middle lobe.these findings appear similar to those seen in ___, though note is made that in the interim in ___ these inflammatory changes had resolved.there is associated bronchial wall thickening, as well as extensive secretions seen within the tracheobronchial tree, causing complete opacification of the right lower lobe bronchi (4:78).the waxing/___ nature of these inflammatory changes, history of laryngeal radiation, and presence of airway secretions are highly suggestive of recurrent aspiration.there is mild emphysema.there are no pulmonary nodules identified concerning for malignancy.the patient is status post right upper lobe lobectomy with resection of the second and third ribs.the right upper lobe bronchial stump is unchanged in appearance, without increased soft tissue to suggest local recurrence.there is stable postradiation change identified at the right apex.the heart remains normal in size.there is coronary calcification, most prominent in the left main and left anterior descending arteries.the aorta and great vessels are normal in caliber and contour, as are the pulmonary arteries.there is no mediastinal or hilar adenopathy by ct size criteria.there is no supraclavicular or axillary adenopathy identified.there are no mass-like endobronchial lesions.the esophagus is unremarkable.there has been resection of the right second and third ribs.sclerosis of the right fourth rib is noted, unchanged dating to at least ___, likely post-radiation in etiology.there are no lytic or sclerotic lesions concerning for osseous metastasis.additionally, there is no soft tissue abnormality identified involving the chest wall, including in the right sixth-seventh interspace where abnormal fdg avidity was seen on recent pet scan.this examination is not tailored for evaluation of subdiaphragmatic structures, except to note a nodular thickening of the left adrenal gland, unchanged since ___, normal appearance of the right adrenal gland, and eccentric luminal thrombus in the upper abdominal aorta.
summary: stable appearance status-post right upper lobectomy, with unremarkable appearance of the bronchial stump and postradiation changes at the right apex.there is chronic sclerosis of the right fourth rib likely representing posttreatment change.there is no convincing evidence of locally recurrent or metastatic intrathoracic malignancy.recurrent bibasilar bronchial wall thickening, tree-in-___ opacities, and innumerable centrilobular nodules are, in conjunction with the history of laryngeal radiation and extensive secretions within the tracheobronchial tree, highly suggestive of recurrent aspiration.mild emphysema.stable thickening of the left adrenal.coronary and aortic atherosclerosis, with eccentric mural thrombus seen in the upper abdominal aorta.

text: there are bilateral pulmonary emboli involving the distal right main pulmonary artery and all of its corresponding branches along with the proximal left lower lobe arterial branch.the left upper lobe branch cannot be fully evaluated due to surrounding mass.mild distension of the distal right pulmonary artery is consistent with an acute thrombus.a previously noted enhancing right thyroid mass is grossly unchanged in appearance.a large prevascular mass which invades the left mainstem bronchus appears slightly larger on today's exam, measuring approximately 9.2 x 5.6 cm (prior measurement of 9.0 x 5.4 cm).there is corresponding left upper lobe collapse and contralateral shift across the midline as well as superior translocation of the left major fissure.an endobronchial stent is again identified extending from the left mainstem bronchus into the left lower lobe bronchus.the mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy appears grossly unchanged.previously noted pulmonary nodules in the right lower lobe and right middle lobe are unchanged in size and appearance.multiple 1-2 mm calcified peripheral pulmonary nodules are identified within the right lower lobe and right upper lobe, which were not as well visualized on prior exam.a better-defined posterior right lower lobe nodule (series 3, image 56) also appears slightly enlarged in size when compared to prior exam, measuring approximately 6 mm.no new pulmonary opacities or pleural effusions are identified.
summary: acute bilateral pulmonary emboli involving the right distal main pulmonary artery and all its branches and the left lower lobe branch.grossly unchanged size and appearance of previously noted left suprahilar mass and post obstructive volume loss in the left upper lobe.right thyroid mass unchanged.multiple new pulmonary nodules.limited examination of abdominal and pelvic organs due to suboptimal phase of contrast, but overall stable appearance to previously noted hepatic, omental, and renal lesions.unchanged bulky retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy.slight increase in pelvic free fluid.the above findings were discussed with the ordering physician, ___.___ on the date of exam shortly after image acquisition.

text: the pulmonary arteries opacify normally.there is no evidence for pulmonary embolus.the aorta is normal in caliber and opacifies normally, without evidence for dissection.the lungs are clear.a small amount of secretions noted in the bronchus intermedius (s4: 40).otherwise the airway is clear.mediastinal lymph nodes do not meet size criteria for enlargement.there are scattered atherosclerotic calcifications of the thoracic aorta at the arch.there is no hilar or axillary lymphadenopathy.there is no pleural effusion or pericardial effusion.there are minimal bibasilar dependent atelectatic changes.bone windows demonstrate no lesions suspicious for metastases.
summary: no pulmonary embolus.no aortic dissection.minimal secretions in the bronchus intermedius.

text: an endotracheal tube is seen ending 2.5 cm above the ___, ___ ng tube ends in the stomach, a left-sided central line ends in the lower svc and a right sided chest tube is seen entering the body through the right flank and ending at the level of the right apex (2:22).however, the major fissure is not clearly visualized and, although equivocal, the chest tube might be following an intraparenchymal course.mild amount of subcutaneous emphysema is noted adjacent to the chest tube track (2:51).the airways are patent to the subsegmental level.there is no mediastinal, hilar or axillary lymphadenopathy.the heart and pericardium are unremarkable.there is no esophageal wall thickening or hiatal hernia and an ng tube is seen tracking along the esophagus as previously mentioned.lung windows demonstrate total collapse of the left lower lobe, and nearly total collapse of the right lower lobe.scattered bronchial opacities, mostly nodular are noted throughout the inflated portions of the lungs, more conspicuous in the right upper lobe (2:27) in area of of prior contusion, which has resolved in the interval.a tiny right sided pneumothorax is still seen, but significantly improved.a small left pleural effusion is also present.
summary: numerous scattered ground-glass opacities in a nodular pattern are new from prior exam and might represent inferction versus hemorrhage.a potential intraparenchymal course of the chest tube is apparent although difficult visualization of the major fissure in the right limits accurate assessment.no evidence of acute aortic syndrome or pulmonary embolism, although the study is technically inadequate for assessment of peripheral segmental and subsegmental pulmonary arteries.complete collapse of the left lower lobe and nearly complete collapse of the right lower lobe.tiny right pneumothorax and trace left-sided pleural effusion.d/w dr ___ on ___ at 11 am via telephoone by dr ___.

text: there is a pulmonary embolus within the right upper lobe pulmonary artery extending into those segmental arteries.no other acute embolism is identified.the aorta demonstrates scattered mural calcification without evidence of acute aortic pathology.there is no pericardial effusion and the heart appears demonstrates scattered coronary calcifications.there are no pathologically enlarged axillary lymph nodes.scattered mediastinal nodes are noted, none of which meet the ct criteria for pathologic enlargement.lung windows reveal large bilateral pleural effusions and passive atelectasis.small focus of ground-glass change in the left upper lobe (3:39) is noted.scout image demonstrates that the right sided central line terminates in the lower svc.an endotracheal tube is in position.this examination is not tailored to evaluate abdominal organs; however, limited evaluation of the upper abdomen reveals that an ng tube courses into the stomach.a mild amount of free fluid is noted around the spleen.bone windows reveal no worrisome lytic or sclerotic lesions.multilevel bridging anterior thoracic spinal osteophytes likely represent dish.
summary: right upper lobar pulmonary artery embolus extending into those segmental vessels.no specific evidence of pulmonary infarction or right heart strain.large bilateral pleural effusions and compressive atelectasis.

text: bilateral pleural effusions are again demonstrated, moderate in size.the right pleural effusion is dependent in location and measures simple fluid attenuation.it has slightly increased in size since the previous ct.the left effusion has a lateral loculated component and also measures simple fluid attenuation.there is mild enhancement of the adjacent visceral and parietal pleural surfaces, but no nodularity of the pleural surface is evident.the left effusion is similar in size to the prior ct.numerous calcified pleural plaques are present bilaterally.increased number of mediastinal lymph nodes present in multiple stations.the vast majority of these nodes are borderline in size, measuring just below 1 cm in short axis dimension, but lymph nodes in the azygoesophageal recess meet size criteria by measuring over 1 cm (12 mm.).a few of the nodes are calcified, are partially calcified, but the vast majority are noncalcified.heart size is normal.no pericardial effusion is present.several small pericardial lymph nodes are evident.within the upper abdomen, there has been evolution and increased size of a subcapsular hepatic hematoma.the transverse width the hematoma is now 4 cm and was previously 2.5 cm.the attenuation has decreased in the interval, now measuring about 30 hounsfield units, previously measuring about 40 hounsfield units.within the periphery of the right lobe of the liver anteriorly (image 56, series 2), a 2.2 cm diameter hypervascular lesion is identified with hounsfield units of 150, similar in attenuation to the enhanced hepatic arteries.this is not clearly visible on the prior unenhanced ct.two punctate calcifications are present within the left lobe of the liver.adrenal glands are within normal limits.within the lungs, a broad-based 7 cm diameter anterior posterior dimension area of parenchymal opacification is seen in the periphery of the lingula with contiguous band-like areas of opacification.this is heterogeneous in attenuation, with small areas of high density similar to calcium and internal areas of both low and high attenuation.it directly abuts an area of pleural thickening and is associated with converging linear opacities and tethering of bronchovascular bundles.areas of atelectasis are present in both lower lobes adjacent to the pleural effusions, left greater than right.bilateral reticular subpleural interstitial opacities are present throughout the lungs, right greater than left.linear and nodular endobronchial opacities are present, most marked in the left main bronchus, probably due to areas of retained secretions.scattered calcified granulomas are incidentally noted within the lung parenchyma.degenerative changes are present within the spine.there are no suspicious lytic or blastic skeletal lesions.
summary: moderate-sized dependent right and partially loculated left pleural effusions.the left effusion is associated with a subtle split pleura sign, often seen in association with complex exudative effusion such as empyema.malignant mesothelioma may present as a pleural effusion, and sampling of the pleural fluid may be helpful in this regard.2.2 cm hyperdense lesion in peripheral anterior segment right lobe, concerning for a site of active bleeding in the setting of an enlarging subcapsular hematoma.this could potentially be the site of the reported recent liver biopsy and correlation with procedural history would be helpful in this regard.this finding was communicated to dr.___ ___, the ordering physician, ___ the date of the study by telephone.it was also discussed with the patient's primary physician, ___.___ on the afternoon of ___.numerous mediastinal lymph nodes, increased in number and size.although potentially hyperplastic, neoplastic etiology cannot be excluded.pet ct could be considered for further characterization if warranted clinically.

text: the patient is status post cabg.clips are noted in the pericardial space.there are coronary artery calcifications.sternal wires are intact.mild post-surgical changes are noted adjacent to the sternum.no pericardial effusion is noted.the aorta is normal in caliber throughout.there is no concerning filling defect in the pulmonary arteries or branches down to the subsegmental level, although evaluation of the subsegmental branches in the posterior lung bases is suboptimal due to the pleural effusions.there are moderate right greater than left pleural effusions with associated atelectasis, especially in the left lower lobe where superimposed consolidation can not be excluded.no mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy is seen.although this examination was not intended for subdiaphragmatic evaluation, imaged very upper abdomen is unremarkable.
summary: moderate right greater than left bilateral pleural effusions with associated atelectasis.no evidence of pulmonary embolism.

text: patient is intubated with the tip of the endotracheal tube residing at the thoracic inlet.the ng tube courses into the stomach.the great vessels of the mediastinum appear intact without evidence of dissection or mediastinal hematoma.the heart is normal in size and shape.no pericardial effusion is present.no lymphadenopathy is seen.lung windows are notable for collapse of the posterior segment of the right upper lobe, as portions of the anterior segment.there is also collapse of the posterior segment of the left lower lobe.collapse is likely secondary to aspiration/atelectasis.there is no evidence of pulmonary contusion or laceration.no worrisome masses are seen.
summary: l1 superior endplate compression fracture with only minimal loss of vertebral body height.segmental collapse in the posterior segments of the right upper lobe and left lower lobe likely secondary to aspiration/atelectasis.et tube tip positioned at the thoracic inlet.advancement is recommended.ng tube in appropriate position.findings were discussed with trauma surgery at the time of initial review.sesha

text: since the prior examination, there has been worsening of bilateral moderate pleural effusions.there is associated lower lobe compressive atelectasis.the aerated portions of lungs are clear with no focal consolidations or pulmonary nodules.there is no pneumothorax.there is no axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.scattered lymph nodes within the mediastinum do not meet size criteria for pathologic enlargement.there is extensive fat within the mediastinum.the thoracic aorta and coronary arteries demonstrate extensive atherosclerotic calcification.the heart is otherwise unremarkable with no evidence of pericardial effusion.there is enlargement of the main pulmonary trunk measuring up to 3.9 cm.a central venous catheter terminates with tip at the brachiocephalic junction.a nasogastric tube courses below the diaphragm.an endotracheal tube is in standard position within the mid trachea.the tracheobronchial tree is patent to the subsegmental level.
summary: no evidence of active extravasation to suggest acute bleeding.interval increase in size with now moderate bilateral pleural effusions and associated atelectasis.interval moderate increase in size of hemoperitoneum circumferentially involving the spleen greater than the liver.stable appearance of mesenteric fluid and hemorrhage within the central mesentery with no interval increase in size in this region.1.3 cm right adrenal adenoma.enlargement of the main pulmonary trunk can be seen in pulmonary hypertension.

text: the heart, pericardium, and great vessels are unremarkable.the thoracic aorta is normal in caliber without evidence of dissection.there is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax.the central bronchi are patent to the subsegmental level.there is a minimal amount of dependent bibasilar atelectasis, but the lungs are otherwise clear.there is no pulmonary contusion or laceration.no significant mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy is seen.
summary: unremarkable ct of the torso.no acute abnormalities.

text: recently described airspace opacity and anterior segment of right upper lobe has decreased in size from 4 cm to approximately 2.1 cm, and has decreased in density within some parts, with some areas of previous solid density now appearing ground-glass in appearance.large adjacent thick-walled cystic lucencies probably reflect involvement of spaces surrounding preexisting bulla.a second area of abnormality on the prior scan in the left suprahilar region has also decreased in size from 2.6 x 1.4 cm to 1.8 x 1.0 cm.residual left suprahilar opacity is best visualized on image 112 and the residual right upper lobe abnormality is best seen on image 106 (both on series 6).nonspecific reticular and linear opacities at the bases with associated traction bronchiolectasis appear similar to the previous study as well as a small loculated left pleural fluid collection with adjacent mild pleural thickening.there has been previous esophagectomy and pull-up procedure.numerous subcentimeter mediastinal lymph nodes appear unchanged, including a 9-mm lower left paratracheal lymph node.heart is normal in size.small amount of pericardial fluid is unchanged.exam was not specifically tailored to evaluate the subdiaphragmatic region, but adrenal glands are well visualized and normal in appearance.remaining imaged upper abdomen is without change from the prior study on this limited assessment.bilateral small renal hypodensities are too small to characterize by ct but appear unchanged.no concerning new skeletal abnormalities.
