text: the thoracic aorta shows no evidence of aneurysm or dissection or any other acute aortic pathology.there are moderate atherosclerotic calcifications of the aortic arch.pulmonary artery is normal without evidence of pulmonary embolism.there is no pneumomediastinum, mediastinal hemorrhage, or pneumothorax.the partially visualized supra-aortic vessels are normal.the endotracheal tube ends about 7.2 cm above the carina.in the interval between the chest radiograph and the ct, there is new collapse of the right upper lobe likely secondary to mucous plug.again noted is complete collapse of the right lower lobe.there is no evidence of pleural or pericardial effusion.there is no mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy.coronary artery disease is pressnt.
summary: in the interval between the chest radiograph and the ct, new collapse of the right upper lobe is seen likely secondary to mucous plug.as demonstrated on the chest radiograph, there is persistent complete right lower lobe collapse.endotracheal tube is 7.2 cm above the carina, tube should be advanced by about 2 cm.subacute nondisplaced right and left rib fractures.

summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism, as questioned clinically.findings compatible with disease progression compared to pet-ct ___.extensive mediastinal adenopathy and confluent hilar soft tissue have enlarged, as has a large soft tissue mass invading the esophagus in its mid portion, obliterating the lumen.it is unclear if this represents metastatic disease or primary esophageal neoplasm and correlation with pathology is recommended.also progressed are numerous pulmonary nodules, as detailed above.extensive perihilar and paramediastinal consolidation, which has progressed substantially from ___ but is essentially unchanged from ___.given the short term stability, infectious etiologies are less likely, though still possible.more likely differential considerations include developing radiation pneumonitis, as suggested by the paramediastinal distribution, or alternatively direct extension of hilar metastases.correlation with radiation history is recommended.new occlusion of the left lower lobe bronchus, with persistent significant left lower lobe collapse.narrowing multiple pulmonary veins, with a focal filling defect compatible with thrombus, bland or tumor, in a branch of the left superior pulmonary vein.little change of bilateral pleural and pericardial effusions.stable pathologic compression fracture of the t9 vertebral body.redemonstration of apical-predominant emphysema with bullous change.

text: there is a large filling defect within the left inferior lobe pulmonary artery.contrast can be seen between the nearly completely occluded vessel wall and the thrombus.further, non obstructive intraluminal filling defect can be seen in the right main pulmonary artery extending into the middle lobe artery.there is a new 1.5 x 0.9 cm prevascular lymph node.there is likely subcarinal lymphadenopathy as well.bilateral axillary adenopathy is again seen.in the interval since the prior study there has been an increase in size in the right pleural effusion, which is now moderate in extent and which is adjacent to atelectatic v.consolidated right lower lobe.the left pleural effusion seen on the prior study has nearly completely resolved.there is collapse/consolidation of the left lower lobe.there are focal areas of air within the left lower lobe, suggesting necrosis.the osseous structures are unremarkable.multiplanar reformatted images confirm the above findings.

text: the patient is status post cabg.the sternal wires are in expected position without obvious evidence of sternal dehiscence.small foci of air in close proximity and anterior to the wires are again noted, likely postoperative.there is no evidence of osteomyelitis in the sternotomy borders, however subtle osteomyelitis would not be detected.no fluid collection.there is slight interval worsening in the atelectasis in the lingula and lung bases.there is no evidence of pneumonia, pleural effusion, or volume overload.there is no focal fluid collection or abscess.

text: the known thoracic aortic dissection extending into the left subclavian artery has undergone ascending aortic repair.the coronary arteries originate below the level of the ascending aortic graft.there has been interval partial thrombosis of the false lumen at the level of the aortic arch.the false lumen is increasing in diameter in the proximal descending aorta, measuring 27 mm, previously 17 mm.the true lumen diameter at the level of the descending aorta is unchanged.the true lumen is slightly smaller measuring 9 mm, previously 12 mm, at the aortic hiatus.the celiac axis, sma, and left renal artery originate from the true lumen.the right renal artery originates from the false lumen with decreased perfusion compared to the left renal artery.calcified granulomas are seen in the left apex (4:20) and the left upper lobe (4:48).a 5-mm right upper lobe subpleural nodule (4:29) is unchanged from ___.a 6-mm left lower lobe subpleural nodule (4:78) is apparently new.the tracheobronchial tree is patent without endobronchial lesion.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.no pathologically enlarged mediastinal, axillary or hilar lymph nodes are present with the largest mediastinal node measuring 9-mm in the left paratracheal station (2:19).the pulmonary artery is of normal caliber.no bone finding suspicious for malignancy or infection is seen.sclerosis in the lamina and spinous process of t4 is unchanged from ___ and may be due to fibrous dysplasia or degenerative change.median sternotomy wires are intact with minimal dehiscence of the sternum.this study is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation.the right renal mass is unchanged from ___.no new abnormality is noted.

text: there are no pathologically enlarged lymph nodes in the mediastinum, hilum, or axilla according to ct size criteria.there are calcifications in the coronary arteries.heart size is normal.lungs are clear with stable appearance of bilateral sub-5-mm pulmonary nodules described on prior.there is a stable calcified granuloma at the left lung base.

text: there are no filling defects within the pulmonary artery, proximal, or distal branches to suggest the presence of pulmonary embolism.there is a bovine arch configuration to the great vessels.mild atherosclerotic calcifications line the intrathoracic aorta without evidence of aneurysmal dilatation or dissection flap.there are prominent calcifications along all coronary arteries, and calcifications in the mitral valve.there is a small pericardial effusion.a right paratracheal lymph node measures up to 11mm.no additional pathologically enlarged lymph nodes are seen.lung windows demonstrate small bilateral pleural effusions and interlobular septal thickening, consistent with volume overload.linear pleural plaques at the right lung base represent the sequela of prior asbestos exporure.

text: there is interval enlargement of the central cavitary lesion in the left upper lobe, measuring 2.9 x 3.7 cm compared to 3.1 x 2.5 cm previously.there is increased focal thickening in the posteromedial wall of the cavitary lesion compared to ___.other, smaller pulmonary nodules, which are not cavitary, appear stable.the largest nodule at the left apex measures 9 x 7 mm compared to 10 x 6 mm previously.the tracheobronchial tree is patent to segmental levels.a 7-mm lymph node in the left hilum (image 3:26) has not significantly changed.there are no pathologically enlarged mediastinal or axillary lymph nodes.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.the heart and great vessels appear unremarkable.post-radiation changes in the lingula and right upper lobe are unchanged.evidence of left mastectomy is again noted.
summary: interval enlargement of the dominant cavitary lesion in the left lower lobe, with increased focal thickening in the posteromedial wall of the cavity.stable smaller, noncavitary pulmonary nodules.stable three subcentimeter hypodensities in the liver, which are too small to characterize.1.5-cm cystic lesion in the left adnexum, which may represent decreased dilatation of the previously noted left hydrosalpinx, or a left adnexal cyst.

text: there is extensive emphysema in the lungs bilaterally, right more severe than left.large bullae are seen at the right lung apex.there are no focal consolidations.there are no nodules or masses.there is bibasilar atelectasis.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.the trachea and central airways are patent to the subsegmental level with no evidence for endobronchial lesion.there is no mediastinal or hilar adenopathy.following administration of intravenous contrast, there is normal opacification of the pulmonary vasculature.there is no evidence for pulmonary embolism.

text: there is an endotracheal tube, right subclavian central venous catheter and ng tube present in proper position.there is an apparent large filling defect along the superior aspect of the distal left main pulmonary artery in the region of the artery to the left upper lobe.this finding is concerning for a pulmonary embolism; however, note is made that evaluation fo the pulmonary artery is suboptimal as this was not performed with pulmonary angiography technique.the heart, pericardium, and great vessels are otherwise unremarkable.there are no pathologically enlarged areas of adenopathy.note is made of several scattered small prevascular, right paratracheal and subcarinal lymph nodes.there are small bilateral pleural effusions and dependent atelectatic changes.the airways appear patent to the segmental level bilaterally.

text: the thoracic aorta is normal in caliber with minimal atherosclerotic calcifications in the arch.contrast bolus timing is not optimized to evaluate for pulmonary embolism but there is no large central pulmonary embolus.the mid and distal subclavian posterior to the clavicle are difficult to evaluate but these regions are patent on ultrasound ___.the proximal subclavian vein, brachiocephalic vein and svc are well visualized and are patent.no pathologically enlarged axillary, mediastinal or hilar lymph nodes are present.coronary artery calcifications in the lad are noted.the heart, pericardium and great vessels otherwise are within normal limits.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.a tiny amount of fluid in the superior pericardial recess is physiologic.a tiny calcification is seen in the thyroid isthmus (4:6).lung window images demonstrate no worrisome nodule or mass.linear atelectasis is noted at the right lower lobe.tiny dependent and nodular lesions are seen in the bronchi bilaterally which may represent papillomatosis or secretions.this study is not optimized for a subdiaphragmatic evaluation.mild prominence of the left intrahepatic biliary ducts is unchanged from ___.patient is status post roux-en-y gastric bypass surgery and ventral hernia repair.a 2.0 x 2.1 simple cyst in the mid pole of the left kidney is unchanged since ___.a tiny hypodensity just superior to this is too small to characterize and is most likely a cyst.

text: the left lung is collapsed with ipsilateral mediastinal shift.in addition, there is a small pleural and subpulmonic effusion.the left main stem bronchus is patent, but subsegmental branches are not patent, though the etiology cannot be determined by ct.the heart is enlarged, but stable, and the aorta is unremarkable.there are coronary artery calcifications.ng tube is located in the stomach, and central venous catheter terminates in the lower svc.et tube is located 6 cm above the carina.there is a small right pleural effusion and basilar atelectasis.there are multiple filling defects within the subsegmental branches of the right lung, particularly right lower lobe, that is consistent with pulmonary embolus.the nonocclusive nature and lack of wall distention suggest perhaps a subacute etiology.a contour abnormality of the left main pulmonary artery could be secondary to volume averaging, but contour abnormalities as this can be a result of chronic pe and remodeling.there is however,no definite evidence for pulmonary embolus in the left pulmonary arteries.a small pericardial effusion has decreased in size from ___.however, there are areas of increased pericardial enhancement (such as series 3a, image 42) likely indicating an inflammatory process.again seen is herniation of fat and transverse colon via the anterior pericardial/diaphragmatic defect with a presence of colon as high as at the level of the aortic root.these bowel loops are of normal caliber, without evidence for obstruction.a small portion of the stomach is also present within this large anterior defect.
summary: multiple right subsegmental pulmonary emboli, likely subacute.left lung collapse, new compared to the chest radiographs of ___.complex pericardial and subpulmonic pleural effusions, decreased from ___, ___, but with areas of increased pericardial enhancement consistent with patient's history of infection.a large anterior pericardial/diaphragmatic defect with herniation of non- obstructed bowel, stomach and fat.abundant ascites, likely unchanged from ___, with increased peritoneal enhancement consistent with history of peritonitis.questionable filling defect within the transplant renal vein.a doppler ultrasound is advised to exclude this possibility.left common femoral vein thrombosis at site of central venous catheter, extending into superficial and deep branches.polycystic kidney and liver disease with multiple, stable, more dense lesions (presumed cysts) in addition to innumerable low-density cysts.two cystic structures adjacent to tail of pancreas of unclear etiology, unchanged from ___, perhaps are pancreatic cysts.these findings were discussed with dr.___ at 1 p.m.via telephone on ___, ___.

text: the patient is intubated.heart size is normal.there is no pericardial effusion.the aorta is normal in caliber and configuration, as is the main pulmonary artery.there is no large central pulmonary embolus identified, though this study was not tailored to evaluation of the smaller pulmonary arteries.there are small bilateral non-hemorrhagic pleural effusions, slightly greater on the left.pleural fluid tracks into the major fissures.there is diffuse septal thickening and ground-glass opacity, suggestive of pulmonary edema.additionally, there are dense consolidations bilaterally in the lower lobes, with complete right lower lobe collapse and near-complete left lower lobe collapse.the consolidated lung parenchyma appears to enhance homogeneously, and given dependent location with associated volume loss, the greatest component of this likely represents atelectasis, though concurrent pneumonia is impossible to entirely exclude.numerous enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes are again noted, increased in conspicuity from ___, likely reactive.
summary: small bilateral pleural effusions, with consolidation of the bilateral lower lobes.given dependency, volume loss, and relatively homogenous enhancement of the consolidated lung parenchyma this most likely represents substantial atelectasis rather than pnuemonia.however, a concurrent pneumonia is impossible to exclude by imaging.diffuse septal thickening and ground-glass opacity, compatible with pulmonary edema.mediastinal adenopathy, increased from prior study, likely reactive.small-moderate ascites, with diffuse peritoneal enhancement and multiple loculations, concerning for peritonitis.diffusely abnormal small bowel, with areas of wall thickening and multiple dilated loops extending to the patient's left lower quadrant ostomy.there is no distinct transition point identified, and given reportedly good ostomy output, these finding may reflect inflammation and ileus secondary to peritonitis.unremarkable colonic mucous fistula in the right lower quadrant.residual retained stool is seen within the transverse and left colon.findings discussed with dr.___ shortly following imaging on ___ by dr.___.

text: an endotracheal tube with the tip approximately 7 cm above the carina is noted.et tube is too high with the cuff close to the vocal cords.there is a small tracheal diverticulum at the thoracic inlet.there is an ng tube present.small amount of air in the brachiocephalic artery is likely secondary to iv injection and of doubtful clinical significance.small amount of soft tissue in the anterior mediastinum likely represents residual thymus.there is no mediastinal hematoma.aorta, pulmonary artery, heart and pericardium appear unremarkable.there is no mediastinal, hilar or axillary lymphadenopathy by size criteria.bibasilar atelectatic changes are noted.there is no pneumothorax, pleural effusion or pulmonary contusion.
summary: no evidence of chest, abdominal or pelvic trauma.et tube is too high with the cuff close to the vocal cords.recommend repositioning.discussed with dr.___ at 10:40 pm ___.

text: the thyroid images normally.there is no pneumomediastinum.no pathologic axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymphadenopathy is noted.the major thoracic airways are widely patent.the esophagus images normally.the heart is normal in size with no pericardial effusion.minimal dependent atelectasis is noted in both lung bases.no suspicious pulmonary nodules or masses are seen.the lungs are clear without consolidation or edema.paraseptal emphysematous blebs are noted at the lung apices.
summary: regarding the clinically observed cold right foot: the fem-fem graft is occluded.likewise, the right internal iliac artery to right popliteal artery graft is occluded.there is no runoff at the right knee with only minimal collateral flow opacifying short segments of some of the calf arteries.however, there is no contrast identified in either the dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial arteries at the right ankle.the left axillary artery to left popliteal artery graft is patent.two-vessel runoff is noted at the left knee with the dorsalis pedis opacified at the left ankle.a detailed wet read was provided at ___ hours on the day of study.

text: pre-contrast images of the thorax demonstrate no dense intramural hematoma within the aorta.surgical suture is present in the right hemithorax consistent with a prior wedge resection.post-contrast images demonstrate no pulmonary embolism to the level of subsegmental pulmonary arteries.there is no discrete thoracic lymphadenopathy, however, there is increased abnormal mediastinal and hilar soft tissue, for example on series 5, image 46.there is a moderate-sized right pleural effusion.there is no abnormal pleural enhancement.no gas is seen within the effusion to suggest infection.the heart size is normal.the aorta and great vessels are normal.there is mild atherosclerosis present involving the left subclavian artery and aorta.lung windows demonstrate complete atelectasis of the right middle lobe.there is slight mediastinal shift from the left to the right.the right upper lobe and left lung are clear.a soft tissue mass is again noted in the left breast.limited images of the upper abdomen demonstrate mild biliary dilatation.there is a right adrenal adenoma again noted.bone windows demonstrate no lytic or blastic lesions.a lucency is present in the thoracic spine, best seen on image 54 of series 5.this is likely related to degenerative change.
summary: no pulmonary embolism as clinically questioned.complete atelectasis of the right middle lobe.there is a moderate right pleural effusion with no evidence of infection on ct.abnormal mediastinal and hilar soft tissue.this may be related to postsurgical changes.left breast mass again noted.correlate with mammography.

text: the heart appears unremarkable.there is a large intraluminal filling defect at the left main pulmonary artery, consistent with pulmonary embolism.also noted are intraluminal filling defects in the pulmonary arteries supplying the right lower lobe.there is no evidence of pe in the pulmonary arteries supplying the right upper lobe.there is no significant pericardial or pleural effusion.there are several small mediastinal lymph nodes, none of which meet the ct criteria for pathologic enlargement.there is no significant axillary lymph adenopathy.the airways are patent to the level of the segmental bronchi bilaterally.on lung windows, there is a stable appearance of multiple pulmonary nodules, not significantly changed from the prior study.also noted is minimal pleural thickening posteriorly in the left lung.the visualized portions of the abdomen, including the liver, spleen and stomach appear unremarkable.bone windows demonstrate no suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions.
summary: there is interval development of bilateral pulmonary embolism which was not appreciated on the prior study.discussed with the medicine team immediately after the study.

text: the heart is normal in size.there is a left upper lobe lung mass which is contiguous with enlarged aorticopulmonary lymph node.in the interval since ___, the nodal mass with necrotic features has decreased slightly in size from 34 x 43 mm to 32 x 34 mm.the lung mass has decreased slightly in size from 37 x 76 mm to 25 x 74 mm.the nodal mass is noted to abut the pulmonary trunk with effacement of the fat plane and may be invading the main pulmonary artery.the lung mass is also noted to extend into the anterior chest wall in the subcostal area between the first and second ribs.there is no evidence of associated rib destruction.there is evidence of lymph node enlargement in the left supraclavicular region with a node previously measuring 12 x 15 mm currently measuring 12 x 19 mm and several other nodes in this region appear slightly increased in size.there is a new small left pleural effusion.the lung window images reveal new diffuse ground-glass opacities predominantly involving the upper and middle lobes with relative sparing of the lower lobes.this is new since the prior studies.there is a region of more dense ground- glass opacification in the medial left lung with a geographic boundary consistent with more focal post radiation change.the ground-glass opacities identified in the lower lobes on the recent chest cta have resolved.there is a new 6 mm round nodule in the right lower lobe with a slightly lobulated contour.there are also several smaller noncalcified nodules in the left lower lobe which were not seen in the prior study.the airways are notable for bronchiectasis in the right upper lobe which is unchanged and a focal calcification within this consistent with a broncholith.there is emphysema again noted.in the imaged portion of the upper abdomen, the visualized portions of the liver, spleen, pancreas, adrenal glands, and kidneys are normal.there are no suspicious lytic or sclerotic osseous lesions.
summary: new predominantly upper and middle lung zone ground-glass opacities, which are suggestive of a hypersensitivity pneumonitis which may be a diffuse response to the radiation therapy.the differential diagnosis includes an atypical infection vs.pulmonary edema.interval resolution of predominantly lower lobe ground-glass opacities seen in the recent chest ct likely represents resolution of an infectious vs.inflammatory process.a few new pulmonary nodules in the lower lobes are new since the prior study approximately 2 weeks ago.given the rapid onset of these findings, an infectious or inflammatory process is likely.however, metastatic foci cannot be definitively excluded and attention to these areas on future ct is needed.slight interval decrease in left upper lobe lung mass extending to the anterior chest wall and anterior mediastinum and also slight interval decrease in contiguous aorticopulmonary window lymphadenopathy.lymph nodes in the left supraclavicular region which are increasing in size.new small left pleural effusion.

text: comparison to a prior ct chest dated ___ performed to evaluate for pulmonary embolism.opacification of the pulmonary arteries is suboptimal.there is no evidence of a central pulmonary embolism nor is there evidence of right heart strain but a segmental embolism cannot be excluded on the basis of this study.the pulmonary artery is at the upper limits of normal in size (32 mm).the endotracheal tube and right internal jugular central venous catheters are in satisfactory position, the side hole of the nasogastric tube is at the level of the gastroesophageal junction and should be advanced by approximately 7 cm, if used for feeding, to avoid aspiration.there is no pathologic enlargement of the supraclavicular, axillary or mediastinal lymph nodes, the largest node in the mediastinum is in the right paratracheal station and measures 9 mm in short axis dimension (2:18).the cardiac size is normal.there is no pericardial or pleural effusion.the airways are patent to the subsegmental level, flattening of the posterior membrane of the trachea suggests image acquisition in expiration.left lower low airtrapping is extensive and similar in appearance to ___.bilateral lower lobe atelectasis is moderately severe, dense right upper lobe consolidation has completely resolved since ___.linear atelectasis in the right middle lobe has also improved.left upper lobe atelectasis has also completely resolved.centrilobular emphysema is mild.atelectasis of the superior segment of the left lower lobe has progressed since ___.the study is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation, only to mention surgical material along the greater curvature of the stomach and moderately severe hepatic steatosis.mid thoracic osteophytosis is mild.
summary: resolution of right upper lobe consolidation since ___ with residual bilateral lower lobe and right middle lobe atelectasis and new superior segment of left lower lobe consolidation.opacification of the pulmonary arteries is suboptimal.there is no evidence of a central pulmonary embolism nor is there evidence of right heart strain but a segmental embolism cannot be excluded on the basis of this study.the nasogastric tube should be advanced by approximately 7 cm if it is required for feeding, to avoid gastroesophageal reflux.dr ___, clinical team member, informed at 4.20 pm ___.

text: mediastinal great vessels are intact and there is no mediastinal hematoma.heart is normal in size without pericardial effusion.there is no lymphadenopathy.partially imaged thyroid gland is unremarkable.the tracheobronchial tree is patent to subsegmental levels.lungs are clear.bibasilar areas of atelectasis are noted.there is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax.ct of the abdomen:the liver demonstrates nodular contour and enlarged left lobe, suggestive of cirrhosis.no discrete hepatic lesion is identified.there is no evidence of intrahepatic or extrahepatic biliary ductal dilatation.the hepatic vasculature appears patent.the gallbladder is incompletely distended.there is no gallbladder wall edema or pericholecystic fluid collection to suggest acute inflammation.small amount of sludge and possibly tiny stones layering within the gallbladder lumen are noted (2:129).lower pole of the spleen is hypoattenuating, with several rounded areas of hyperattenuation which given findings on the outside hospital ct raise concern for contusion with pseudoaneurysm formation.there is no perisplenic or subcapsular hematoma.the pancreas and adrenal glands are unremarkable.the right kidney enhances homogeneously without hydronephrosis or renal masses.there is rupture of a left renal cyst with increase in internal layering blood (2:148).there is increased left retroperitoneal hematoma along the lower pole of the left kidney with areas of active extravasation noted (2:159, 153) a second cyst is noted in the left kidney appearing intact (2:144).there is no free air within the abdomen.the intra-abdominal aorta and its branches appear normal in caliber and are patent.small and large bowel loops are unremarkable without evidence of bowel wall thickening or obstruction.
summary: ruptured left renal cyst with intracystic and perinephric hematoma and active contrast extravasation.left retroperitoneal hematoma increased since osh ct obtained three hours prior.contusion involving the lower pole of the spleen with splenic pseudoaneurysms.these findings may predispose to delayed splenic rupture.acute fractures involving left iliac ___, left superior and inferior pubic rami and left l2 and l5 transverse processes.stable appearance of small intramuscular hematoma of the left obturator internus muscle.no acute traumatic injury in the chest.lobulated contour of the liver, compatible with underlying cirrhosis.sigmoid colon diverticula without associated inflammatory changes.

text: there is no pulmonary embolism.bilateral pleural effusions, small to moderate on the right, and small on the left, have developed since two days ago.there is resulting compressive subsegmental atelectasis.fluid is also seen along the right major fissure posteriorly (2:44).small parenchymal pulmonary opacities in the left lower lobe are again consistent with pulmonary contusion.right upper lobe nodular/ground glass opacities may be inflammatory or infectious.no residual pneumothorax is seen, although subcutaneous emphysema tracks around the site of the left chest tube, which apparently terminates just superior to the left lung apex.the heart, aorta, and great vessels appear normal.although not tailored for the purpose, limited axial images of the upper abdomen appear unremarkable.

text: the heart is normal in size.there is extensive coronary and aortic annular calcification, as well as calcification of the aortic arch, without aneurysm.the pulmonary arteries are text: there are no comparisons.there is evidence of massive acute pulmonary embolism with large thrombi impacted in both the central right and left main pulmonary arteries, extending into their lobar branches and reaching the segmental branch level.in the region of thrombus, there is relative paucity of more distal branch vessels.there is no focal airspace process to specifically suggest the development of pulmonary infarction.there is relatively minor underlying panacinar emphysema with scattered subpleural blebs.the heart appears somewhat enlarged; however, there is no specific evidence of right ventricular "strain"; specifically, no definite leftward bowing of the intraventricular septum is seen, and there is no dilatation of the superior or inferior vena cavae or abnormal reflux of contrast into the hepatic veins.no acute rib fracture or pleural effusion is seen.incidentally noted is a large, 3.8 x 3.3cm heterogeneous mass with peripheral calcifications,arising in the left lobe of the thyroid gland and extending caudally to a retrosternal location in the superior mediastinum.there is associated rightward deviation, without significant compression of the lower cervical trachea.there is no ascites, and the liver and spleen enhance normally without focal lesion.stomach, gallbladder, pancreas and both adrenal glands are unremarkable, and both kidneys enhance normally, as do the major retroperitoneal vessels, with mural calcification of the abdominal aorta and its branches.there is no free fluid or blood in the pelvis, with foley catheter and a small amount of air present in and otherwise unremarkable bladder.there are numerous fibroids with chunky calcifications in an otherwise atrophic uterus, with the ovaries not definitely identified.the unopacified bowel loops throughout the abdomen and pelvis are grossly unremarkable, without adjacent inflammatory change.there is no mesenteric, retroperitoneal or pelvic adenopathy.the regional skeleton demonstrates no evidence of acute traumatic injury.noted is multilevel degenerative change involving the lumbar spine with evident spinal canal narrowing at several levels.

text: fluid, the density of which is consistent with blood, surrounding the descending thoracic aorta has increased since the osh study performed one day prior measuring up to 7 mm in thickness.this is likely from a venous source as there is no evidence of active arterial extravasation or aortic injury.the retrosternal hematoma remains stable in size with no evidence of active extravasation.a focus of hyperdensity posterior to the left aspect of the manubrium (3:5) is most consistent with a tiny bony fragment.the pulmonary arteries remain patent.there is no evidence of vascular injury.the airways remain clear.a trace right-sided pleural effusion remains stable.the left pleural effusion, also consistent with blood, has slightly increased in size since the prior study but remains small.there is bibasilar atelectasis.a tiny right anterior pneumothorax remains but has greatly improved since the prior study.small ground-glass opacities noted anteriorly in the right upper lobe likely reflect small areas of pulmonary contusion, improved.there is a small hemopericardium, which is unchanged in size since the prior study and does not cause tamponade.multiple displaced right posterior rib fractures, likely contribute to a slight decrease in the ap diameter of the thorax and mild compression of the left atrium.the endotracheal tube ends 3.8 cm above the carina.a right central venous line ends in the lower svc.bilateral chest tubes end at the lung apices.extensive subcutaneous air is present, predominantly over the right hemithorax.this examination is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation.a large cyst in the right lobe of liver remains unchanged.ng tube is seen coursing to the stomach, though the tip is excluded from view.

text: a few tiny nodes are seen within the axilla bilaterally, unchanged since the previous exam.there has been significant decrease in size of the right hilar lymphadenopathy.there is an approximately 11 mm lymph node which remains in the ap window, unchanged.the heart size is mildly enlarged, with evidence of diffuse thickening of the left ventricular myocardium.there has been decrease in degree of pericardial effusion.there are no pleural effusions.evaluation of the lung windows demonstrates persistent collapse of the right middle lobe, without evidence for an obstructing endobronchial lesion or extrinsic compression of the middle lobe bronchus.again seen is severe bullous emphysema, most prominent in the upper lobes.several lung nodules are again seen.the previously seen, largest nodule in the right upper lobe is no longer identified.there is a small subcentimeter nodule adjacent to the major fissure on the left (image 27) which is unchanged.there is a second small nodule in the left lower lobe (image 41) which is also without change.another nodule is noted in the right lower lobe (image 45) which appears less prominent when compared to prior study.there is a fourth nodule seen within the left upper lobe (image 29) which is stable in size since the prior exam.in the imaged portions of the upper abdomen, the liver and spleen are unremarkable.the enhancement pattern of the kidneys is slightly irregular, but this is of uncertain significance and could be related to timing of bolus injection.the pancreas is unremarkable.there is slight prominence of the left adrenal gland.no suspicious osseous lesions are seen.

text: the heart is upper limits of normal in size, without evidence of pericardial effusion.atherosclerotic coronary artery calcifications and atherosclerotic calcifications of the aortic arch are present.there is no evidence for pulmonary embolism within the main, lobar, or segmental pulmonary arterial branches.the lower lobe subsegmental evaluation is slightly limited due to respiratory motion, though no discrete filling defect is identified to suggest pulmonary embolism.no pathologically enlarged mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymph nodes are identified by ct size criteria.there are metallic surgical clips along the right upper mediastinum, which creates extensive streak artifact limiting evaluation.post-surgical changes are evident following a right upper lobectomy.chronic atelectasis of the right lung apex appears grossly stable.however, there has been interval impaction of the right main stem bronchus, as well as extensive bronchial impaction throughout the right lower lobe, with consequent parenchymal opacification of the right perihilar region likely reflective of atelectasis.centrilobular ground glass opacities in the right lower lobe may reflect infectious or inflammatory changes related to the bronchial impaction.there are moderate-sized bilateral pleural effusions, slightly increased in size from prior study.this examination is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation.both adrenal glands are normal in appearance.mild wedging of multiple upper thoracic vertebral bodies are unchanged from prior study.

text: there are no filling defects seen within the pulmonary vasculature to suggest the presence of a pulmonary embolism.the aorta demonstrates normal caliber and contour.there is interval increase in the size of a large left-sided pleural effusion.also seen is an increase in the size of the opacity within the left upper lobe adjacent to the anterior chest wall.there is another left apical opacity with air bronchogram unchanged from the prior study.there is interval development of new patchy opacities in the right lower lobe.several scattered anterior mediastinal lymph nodes are again noted, which are unchanged in appearance.there is no significant axillary lymphadenopathy.a soft tissue mass is visualized in the left breast measuring 2.2 x 1.4 cm, unchanged in appearance.postsurgical changes are also seen in the left breast.there is interval development of pericardial thickening.in the imaged portion of the upper abdomen, the visualized portion of the liver demonstrates multiple areas of low attenuation likely representing metastatic disease.multiple sclerotic foci are again noted in the vertebral bodies consistent with known osseous metastases.

text: there is no evidence of central or proximal segmental pulmonary emboli involving the right upper, right lower, right middle, and left upper lobes.the majority of the lingular and left lower lobe branches are incompletely opacified and markedly affected by beam hardening artifact causing inability to evaluate for pulmonary emboli.there is no evidence of aortic dissection.the lungs display scattered areas of peripheral interstitial septal thickening and ground-glass opacities within the right upper and left upper/lingular lobes with no discrete pneumonia identified.there is a moderate size simple right pleural effusion with a fissural component and adjacent compression atelectasis of the right lower lobe.a few small pockets of anterior extrapleural air are noted (3:36, 31).the airways are grossly patent.there is extensive mediastinal lipomatosis, cardiomegaly, and atherosclerotic disease involving the intrathoracic aorta and coronary circulation.a moderate amount of mitral annulus calcification and aortic valvular calcification is noted.no pathologically enlarged axillary or central lymph nodes are identified.multiple prominent mediastinal nodes are likely reactive measuring up to 10 mm in the precarinal station.central venous catheter terminates within the mid svc.moderate amount of subcutaneous emphysema is noted along the anterior mid right clavicle (3:2).there is a irregular hypoattenuating lesion noted within the right thyroid likely consistent with a benign nodule.

text: there is a tunneled left subclavian dual lumen central venous catheter whose tips lie in the distal superior vena cava and upper right atrium, respectively.there are mitral calcifications, and some aortic calcifications, seen previously.there is very extensive collateral venous circulation, related to a known venous stenoses/occlusions, which are not characterized here further.the heart, great vessels, and pericardium are unremarkable.there is no evidence of pulmonary embolism.again noted is a small left pleural effusion, and there are bibasilar patchy parenchymal opacities and ground-glass opacities, which may represent atelectasis.in addition, there are more diffuse ground-glass opacities, more so than on the prior study with peripheral septal thickening, and this appearance is most suggestive of congestive heart failure or fluid overload.a small 3-mm calcified lung nodule in the right middle lobe, is unchanged.it most likely represents a granuloma.a prominent right paratracheal node is again noted which measures 13 x 23 mm in axial dimension, somewhat enlarged.prominent bilateral axillary lymph nodes are also unchanged.limited evaluation of the upper abdominal organs is unremarkable.

text: there is somewhat extensive segmental pulmonary embolus in the medial segment of the right middle lobe (3a:72), in the posterior segment of the right upper lobe (3a:51), and in the anterior segment of the right upper lobe (3a:54).no pulmonary embolus is seen on the left.there has been slight re-expansion of the left lung base, but with persistent moderate left pleural effusion and segmental atelectasis at the basal segments in the left lower lobe.the superior segment of the left lower lobe is aerated, as is the lingula and the left upper lobe.among the area of atelectasis, there is somewhat heterogeneous appearance, which may represent a component of aspiration or infectious airspace consolidation (3a:83).in the right lung base, the basal segments of the right lower lobe demonstrate bronchial secretion/plugging (3a:77).there is also subsegmental lung base atelectasis, and likely a component of aspiration and/or infection.elsewhere, the trachea and bronchi are patent to the subsegmental levels.an endotracheal tube terminates in satisfactory position.there is a nasogastric tube which terminates in the stomach.a right internal jugular line terminates in the superior vena cava in satisfactory position.there are few scattered mediastinal nodes which are not pathologically enlarged.there is a prominent left hilar node measuring 7 mm (3a:54).

text: in the right upper lobe, a pulmonary nodule previously measuring 1.7 x 1.6 cm now measures 1.9 x 1.8 cm.again seen is an approximately 6-mm in diameter nodule in the right lower lobe (2:30) and an approximately 7-mm nodule in the left upper lobe (2:26).a dominant mediastinal node in the right paratracheal area previously measuring 3.3 x 2.8 cm today measures 3.0 x 2.2 cm and its morphology is consistent with a necrotic node.a new 1.6-cm node is seen anterior to the svc (2:24) and a right hilar node has dramatically increased in size from 1.4 x 0.8 cm to 3.5 x 2.7 cm.a small pericardial effusion is again seen.otherwise the heart and great vessels are normal in appearance, excepting for some atherosclerotic changes.again seen are bilateral breast implants with calcification about the right-sided implant.

text: the left chest tube with lateral approach terminates in the apex, unchanged.there is a small left anteromedial pneumothorax.small-to-moderate left posterior pleural effusion layers in the dependent position and does not appear loculated.however, there are a 4.2 x 1.8 cm lateral collection (2:38), a 3.5 x 1.4 cm anterior collection (2:39) and a 4.2 x 2.8 cm medial collection (2:33), all concerning for loculated fluid collections.in particular, small amount of interspersed pockets of gas are noted within the medial and lateral collections, raising suspicion for superimposed infection such as empyema.the location of the medial collection is also unusual for trauma, but could represent a coup and contrecoup mechanism from a high-impact parenchymal contusion.there is interval decrease of subcutaneous soft tissue gas along the left lateral chest wall.the right lung is normally expanded without pleural effusion, pneumothorax or focal airspace consolidations.the heart is normal in size without pericardial effusion.the great mediastinal vessels are normal.the central tracheobronchial tree is patent.tiny triangular soft tissue in the mediastinum is compatible with a thymic remnant.small mediastinal lymph nodes are not pathologically enlarged, likely reactive from the underlying trauma/infection.there is no hilar or axillary lymphadenopathy.the study is not designed for subdiaphragmatic diagnosis.small amount of subcutaneous soft tissue gas tracks inferiorly to the left posterolateral abdominal wall.
