text: there is a large right hemopneumothorax, new since the prior examination.there is no evidence for active extravasation into this hemopneumothorax.there are several locules of air within the hemothorax (2:30, 2:22).this hemothorax is loculated along the right posterior apex (2:13).there is resulting atelectasis and collapse of the right lower lobe.the right upper lobe remains aerated, as does part of the right middle lobe.there is atelectasis at the left base; otherwise, the left lung appears unremarkable.patient is status post median sternotomy, and the cerclage wires remain intact without evidence for dehiscence.similar to the examination from two days prior, there remains air posterior to the superior sternal cerclage wires (2:18).this is most pronounced at the level of a left subclavian vein stent (2:17), which remains patent.patient is status post prosthetic aortic valve replacement, which appears intact and similar to the earlier examination, although evaluation is limited by this non-cardiac gated study.similar to the examination from two days prior, there is a possible aneurysmal dilation of the right atrium at the level of the tricuspid valve (2:42).evaluation for pericardial fluid is limited by the phase of contrast timing, and a small pericardial effusion cannot be excluded.the pulmonary artery appears unremarkable without evidence for pulmonary embolism.there is no evidence for aortic dissection.there is unchanged appearance to slight soft tissue prominence around ascending aorta, unchanged and likely postoperative in nature.limited evaluation of the upper abdomen reveals atrophic kidneys.otherwise, the upper abdomen appears normal.

text: within the lung parenchyma, no pulmonary contusion or pneumothorax is present.no pericardial effusion is seen.there are several pulmonary nodules including a 4-mm nodularity in the right upper lobe (2:16), along the right minor fissure (2:29) and along the left major fissure measuring 8 mm (2:34).a cluster of nodules are present within the superior segment of the right lower lobe (2:25).these appear ill-defined; however, individual nodules measure at least up to 1.2 cm.a nodule with a punctate calcification (2:26) is likely benign.no pathologically enlarged lymph nodes are seen.no pericardial effusion or mediastinal hematoma is seen.there are coronary artery and mitral annular calcifications.the airways are patent to the segmental level.within the abdomen, the spleen demonstrates a wedge-shaped hypodensity compatible with remote infarct.no evidence of splenic laceration is seen.the liver, gallbladder, pancreas and adrenal glands appear unremarkable.the kidneys contain hypodensities, including a 1.6-cm interpolar hypodensity in the right kidney and multiple additional hypodensities in the left, incompletely characterized.loops of small and large bowel are of normal size and caliber.no abdominal free air, free fluid or lymphadenopathy is seen.within the pelvis, distal loops of large bowel and rectum are of normal size and caliber.the bladder, distal ureters and prostate gland appear grossly unremarkable.incidental note is made of distention of the distal appendix; however, no periappendiceal inflammation is seen.no pelvic free air, free fluid or lymphadenopathy is seen.no fracture is identified.there are multilevel degenerative changes.

text: a nasogastric tube is in place.a left infusion port is present, subcutaneously, with the catheter tip distally within the superior vena cava.a jp drain is present within the superior mediastinum.a right pneumothorax is present.two thoracostomy tubes are in place, one with the tip at the right apex, and the second with the tip medially within the inferior pleural space.bilateral pleural effusions are seen, with locules of air within the right pleural effusion; the air locules could represent infection but are more likely related to the thoracostomy tubes and pneumothorax.a portion of the effusion is loculated on the right, and fluid extends into the major fissue.there is atelectasis of posterior lung bilaterally.haziness at the left lung upper lobe and lower lobe is noted, which respects the fissures.a few bullae are noted within the left upper lobe.subcutaneous emphysema is identified along the right chest wall, predominantly posteriorly and superiorly.surrounding the nasogastric tube is thickened soft tissue, consistent with the patient's recent esophagectomy.a tiny amount of fluid layers within the trachea.the anastomotic site of the esophagectomy is at the pulmonary apex (approximately image ___).no contrast was administered via the nasogastric tube.the right mainstem bronchus is narrowed by edema surrounding the gastric pull-through.a tiny pericardial effusion is noted.a few small hepaticoduodenal, retrocrural, and periaortic/pericaval lymph nodes are identified.variable attenuation is noted within the left lobe of the liver.some has the appearances of retractor injury, but a hypodense lesion in the left lateral segment requires further evaluation.a tiny amount of fluid is seen adjacent to the gallbladder, which otherwise appears unremarkable.the pancreas and spleen appear unremarkable.the right adrenal appears within normal limits.the left adrenal contains an approximately 1.8- cm nodule.the kidneys show symmetric contrast uptake without evidence of hydronephrosis or perinephric fluid collection.note is made of a left renal cyst.a jejunostomy tube is in place and exits through the anterior abdominal wall.note is made of atherosclerotic aortic calcifications.no osseous lesions are identified.
summary: right basilar and right apical thoracostomy tubes within the pleural space.bilateral pleural effusions and right pneumothorax.left pulmonary hazy opacities likely represent developing pneumonia.atypical pulmonary edema could, less likely, also have this appearance.the lack of contrast administered via the nasogastric tube prohibits evaluation for anastomotic leak.left adrenal nodule.the question of metastasis is raised.variable attenuation within the left hepatic lobe.this is of indeterminate significance, however, concern for metastasis is again raised.the hepatic and adrenal findings could be better evaluated by mri when the patient is suitably stable.

text: patient has undergone interval right posterior thoracotomy, with creation of ___ ___ window.heterogeneous material likely representing packing material is seen within the ___ window.esophageal stent is again identified with possible small amount of contrast outside of the lumen of the stent again identified.right-sided chest tube again seen in stable position, with the tip at the right hemithorax.pockets of subcutaneous emphysema are seen within the right chest wall, possibly secondary to chest tube versus creation of ___ window.there has been interval increase in size of bilateral pleural effusions with associated atelectasis.multiple enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes are again seen, with the right paratracheal lymph node measuring approximately 16 mm in short axis dimensions (2:20).heart and great vessels otherwise appear grossly stable.small pericardial effusion again seen.

text: there are no significant axillary lymph nodes.there is a pretracheal lymph node measuring 7 mm (image 7, 65), which is slightly bigger than in the prior study, but does not meet ct criteria for pathology.no significant hilar lymph nodes are seen.there are aortic calcifications.there are also coronary artery calcifications.there is no pericardial effusion.the pulmonary artery is within normal limits.no obvious filling defects are seen in this limited study of the pulmonary arteries.there are no pleural effusions.the airway is patent to the level of subsegmental bronchi.there is bronchial thickening and mild bronchiectasis in the lower lobes bilaterally, which are unchanged when compared to the prior study.examination of the lung fields demonstrate multiple small lung nodules.some of them are unchanged when compared to prior study.there are some new nodules around the area of inflammation seen in the right middle lobe.there is new ground glass and more dense opacities located peripherally in the right middle lobe, which are somewhat sharply demarcated.did the patient have a history of radiotherapy? considering the history of bronchiectasis, this could represent an acute infection.followup with a chest ct in three months is recommended to ensure resolution.new pleural- based nodular opacity is also seen on the right upper lobe (image 7, 41) measuring 5 mm.calcified granuloma is seen in the right lower lobe measuring 3 mm (series 7, image 122).a calcified nodule is seen in the right lower lobe open (series 7, image 136) measuring 6 x 4 mm.(this could also represent mucus impaction into the area).this is new when compared to the prior study.the scarring in the bilateral lower lobes is unchanged when compared to the prior study.limited images of the upper abdomen demonstrate findings consistent with cirrhosis and large amount of ascites.there is splenomegaly.there are two tiny areas of calcifications in the portahepatus around the portal vein that are unchanged when compared to the prior study.there is significant edema of the mesentery, which could be related to low albumin and/or portal hypertension.no suspicious lytic or blastic lesions are seen.
summary: new confluent ground glass and more dense opacities in the right middle lobe, located peripherally and well demarcated.this could represent an infectious process and clinical correlation is recommended.nevertheless, the appearance is somewhat atypical and followup with ct is recommended.stable bronchial thickening and mild bronchiectasis in bilateral lower lobes.multiple pulmonary nodules as described above.some could be inflammatory.attention on these nodules on followup is recommended.coronary artery calcifications.cirrhosis and portal hypertension with large amount of ascites and splenomegaly.

text: patient is status post metallic stent in the descending thoracic aorta.the posterior wall of the native aorta remains thickened, compatible with the excluded ulceration sac/wall components, and has not changed in size compared to the prior ct examination.there is no evidence of air to suggest abscess.the remainder of the thoracic aorta is unremarkable.there is bibasilar atelectasis.no pathologically enlarged mediastinal or hilar lymph nodes.

text: there is no intraluminal filling defect from the level of the main pulmonary artery through the subsegmental pulmonary arteries.the heart size is enlarged.there are calcifications of the aorta.there is a large superior mediastinal mass which appears contiguous with the left lobe of the thyroid and extends to the level of the carina with marked anterior and rightward displacement of the trachea and esophagus.this mass demonstrates heterogeneous enhancement and contains scattered calcifications measuring 9.5 x 5.9 cm in its largest dimension.there are moderate bilateral pleural effusions, right greater than the left.there is partial collapse of the bilateral lower lobes.there centrilobular emphysematous changes throughout both lungs.no pulmonary nodule is identified.very limited images of the upper abdomen demonstrate a subcentimeter, nonspecific low attenuation lesion with the dome of the liver.there is diffuse skeletal demineralization.

text: note that this is a technically limited examination secondary to respiratory motion and poor intravenous contrast timing.within these limitations, there is no central pulmonary embolism to the lobar levels and the segmental levels poorly assessed.the thoracic aorta and great vessels are unremarkable with no evidence of acute aortic syndromes.the heart is unremarkable with no evidence of pericardial effusion.note is made of a mildly prominent right paratracheal lymph node, measuring up to 8 mm, likely reactive in nature, increased since most recent prior exam.there is no other mediastinal, axillary or hilar adenopathy by ct size criteria.other than dependent atelectasis, the lungs are clear without focal consolidation, pulmonary nodules or masses noted.a small amount of airtrapping is noted, with secretions seen within the bronchi.there are no pleural effusions or pneumothorax.the endotracheal tube is seen with tip just terminating at the level of the carina and should be withdrawn by at least 3 cm for more optimal positioning.a nasogastric tube is seen coursing into standard position below the diaphragm.this examination is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation.the visualized portions of the upper abdomen are unremarkable.

text: patient is status post right upper lobectomy and resection of the right second and third ribs.abnormal soft tissue density in the right apex bulges into the upper axilla and lies inferior to the plane of the first rib.if the chest wall closure did not entail a large soft tissue flap, this is hematoma or recurrent tumor.circumferential tracheal, main stem bronchial, and right peribronchial wall thickening remain unchanged.11-mm subcarinal lymph node was previously 6 mm.no hilar or axillary lymphadenopathy is present.small, non-hemorrhagic layering, right pleural effusion is new.trace pericardial effusion is unchanged.dense diffuse coronary artery calcifications and calcified atherosclerotic plaque in the thoracic aorta are unchanged.dense consolidation in the superior segment of the right upper lobe is likely due to radiation.the remainder of the postoperative right lung is clear.in the anterior left upper lobe, a new cluster of less than 5 mm in size ground- glass nodules is probably infectious.the airways are patent to the subsegmental level.mild fullness of the left adrenal gland is unchanged.no other abnormalities are present in the visualized portion of the upper abdomen.rarefaction of the right clavicular head and right sternum are new in the interval, and may be due to radiation necrosis or, since the cortex is intact, tumor from hematogenous spread rather than direct invasion.degenerative changes with bridging osteophyte formation are present within the thoracic spine.
summary: abnormal soft tissue density in the right apex is either a large soft tissue flap, hematoma or tumor.increased 11mm subcarinal lymph node, could be postsurgical reaction.new small right pleural effusion and unchanged trace pericardial effusion.unchanged tracheal and peribronchial wall thickening previously questionned as tumor involvement, presumably evaluated by direct inspection new rarefaction of the right clavicular head and right sternum likely due to radiation necrosis, but malignant involvement is not excluded.right lower lobe radiation change.dfddp

text: the pulmonary arteries demonstrate no intraluminal filling defects to suggest pulmonary embolism.the heart, pericardium, and great vessels are within normal limits.there are no pathologically enlarged areas of adenopathy identified.the airways are patent to the segmental level bilaterally.note is made of an endotracheal tube, ng tube, and right internal jugular central venous catheter which are appropriately positioned.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.the lungs are remarkable for diffuse predominantly perihilar and upper lobe patchy airspace and ground glass opacities.this is most pronounced in the left upper lobe.the visualized portions of the upper abdomen are remarkable for diffuse hypoattenuation of the liver most consistent with fatty infiltration.there is also borderline enlargement of the partially visualized spleen.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism.diffuse predominantly perihilar and upper lobe asymmetric airspace disease which could represent pulmonary edema.fatty infiltration of the liver.borderline enlarged partially visualized spleen.

text: pleural tubes have been removed and what was previously a multiloculated left pleural effusion has resolved along the costal pleural surfaces leaving pleural thickening there.however there is a new loculated pleural collection or abscess along the diaphragmatic surface, inseparable superiorly from thickened pleura and/or consolidated lung.inferiorly it is continuous with the posterior aspect of a small gastric pouch and the tail of displaced pancreas.the diaphragm may be discontinuous at the gastroesophageal hiatus, but is otherwise generally intact.the study is not designed for subdiaphragmatic evaluation except to note continued dilatation of the biliary tree, predominantly extrahepatic.no other large subdiaphragmatic collection is seen in the region imaged.the chronic region of atelectasis in the left lower lobe is unchanged, contiguous with the now abnormal diaphragmatic pleural surface.other areas of mild scarring or atelectasis in the left lung, most marked in the region of left chest wall surgery, are not clinically significant.a y shaped region of ground-glass opacity in the posterior segment of the right upper lobe is probably inflammatory, particularly suggesting aspiration given the history of gastroesophageal surgery and mild gaseous distention of the upper esophagus.there is no pericardial or right pleural effusion.a 6-mm prevascular mediastinal lymph node is stable since ___.there are no pathologically enlarged mediastinal nodes.
summary: new left basal pleural fluid collection or abscess inseparable from consolidation at the base of the left lung and posterior aspect of small gastric pouch and tail of the pancreas.transdiaphragmatic infection arising from a postoperative gastroesophageal or gastric fistula, potentially involving the tail of the pancreas, to be excluded.findings were discussed by telephone with the referring physician, ___ ___, at the time of this dictation.

text: the heart and great vessels are unremarkable.the aorta is of normal caliber and there is no evidence of dissection.there is no pathologic mediastinal, hilar or axillary lymph nodes.there are prominent, posterior ill-defined patchy opacities present within the lung parenchyma, right greater than left, most consistent with probable aspiration.the anterior portion of the lungs is clear.no pulmonary nodules or pleural effusions are present.an endotracheal tube is located approximately 5 cm superior to the carina.
summary: patchy opacities present posteriorly within the lungs, right greater than left, most consistent in appearance with aspiration.clinical correlation is recommended.no intrathoracic, abdominal or pelvic acute pathology identified.no acute fractures or malalignment involving the thoracic or lumbar spines.recommend advancement of ng tube by 10 cm.findings reported to the ed dashboard and discussed with the trauma team including dr.___ by dr.___ at the time of the examination.

text: the aorta is normal in caliber and contour without evidence of acute injury.the heart is normal in size and there is no pericardial effusion.no pathologically enlarged mediastinal or axillary lymph nodes are present.the lungs are clear aside from minimal bibasilar atelectasis.
summary: no acute intrathoracic, abdominal or pelvic injury.fatty infiltration of the liver.diverticulosis.

text: ct of the chest with iv contrast: again seen is mediastinal lymphadenopathy with the largest conglomeration of lymph nodes in the right paratracheal station (2:16).when compared to the prior chest ct of ___, these stable to slightly larger in size.the largest lymph node is in the right paratracheal region and measures 2.1 x 2.6 cm, previously 1.6 x 2.4 cm.an additional enlarged lymph node is noted in the subcarinal area which measures 1.3 x 2.5 cm, unchanged.a smaller subcarinal lymph node (2:30) measures 1.5 x 2.0 cm, stable.again, there is no hilar lymphadenopathy.slight thickening of the right main stem bronchus is again demonstrated as seen on the initial study of ___.a spiculated nodule in the right upper lobe (2:15) measures 9 mm x 7 mm, unchanged.no new pulmonary nodules are identified.patchy areas of ground glass opacities in the right upper lobe are more prominent but nonspecific.there remains a small left-sided pleural effusion, stable.there is adjacent compressive atelectasis which is unchanged in appearance since the prior chest ct.the airways remain patent to the subsegmental levels.there is no axillary lymphadenopathy.the heart size is normal.
summary: stable to slight increase in size of mediastinal lymphadenopathy.stable size of spiculated right upper lobe lung nodule.no new pulmonary nodules identified.multiple bony lucencies as described above, new or more prominent, consistent with increased bony metastatic disease.

text: the visualized portions of the thyroid gland are unremarkable.no enlarged axillary or mediastinal lymph nodes.once again, the four-vessel branching pattern of the aortic arch is noted.otherwise, the heart and great vessels are unremarkable.the airways are patent to the subsegmental levels.no concerning pulmonary nodules seen.bilateral apical pleural scarring is unchanged compared to the prior studies.no pleural or pericardial effusion.
summary: no evidence of new or recurrent disease.stable s-shaped thoracolumbar scoliosis.

text: the patient is status post recent median sternotomy.sternal sutures are seen in place, intact.the sternal incision site is open at the skin at the inferior aspect, just over the xiphoid process.there is postoperative stranding in the anterior chest wall, as expected.there is very mild stranding of the fat of the superior mediastinum anterior to the great vessels.no sizable fluid collections are identified.the thoracic aorta is of normal caliber, with atherosclerotic calcifications.there are dense coronary artery calcifications.there is a small amount of fluid tracking up around the aortic root and main pulmonary artery.there is no significant amount of pericardial fluid.there is a very small left pleural effusion.no pathologically enlarged axillary lymph nodes are seen.one small node in the aorticopulmonary window measures 9 mm in short axis, which may be reactive.in the lung bases, there are scattered areas of linear atelectasis.there is no congestive failure or pneumonia.there is a 2-mm pulmonary nodule within the right lower lobe just posterior to the major fissure (series 2, image 37).within the imaged portion of the upper abdomen, the visualized portions of the liver, spleen, pancreatic tail and right adrenal gland are normal.a midline abdominal hernia containing bowel is partially imaged.
summary: postoperative changes, without a discrete fluid collection identified.very small left pleural effusion.atherosclerotic disease of the coronary arteries and aorta.2-mm nodule within the right lower lobe.in the absence of known malignancy, one-year ct followup is recommended to evaluate stability or change.partially imaged hernia of the anterior abdominal wall containing bowel.

text: there is an aortic dissection flap best appreciated on (___:78) with the flap originating just at the level of the expected origin of the left subclavian artery.there is extension of the aortic dissection flap throughout the entire descending thoracic aorta through to the abdominal aorta and involving the common iliac arteries which will be described in further detail below.there is opacification of both the true and false lumen.the false lumen measures approximately 4.4 cm in its greatest diameter while the true lumen measures approximately 1.5 cm in its greatest diameter.there is no evidence of extension of the dissection flap to include the origins of the great vessels including the left subclavian, the left common carotid, and the brachiocephalic trunk.note is made of extensive atherosclerotic calcifications involving the descending thoracic aorta and also involving the coronary arteries, most prominently involving the left anterior descending artery.no pericardial effusion is noted.there is a small right-sided pleural effusion and trace left pleural fluid.there are bilateral dependent atelectatic changes most predominantly distributed at the bases.no other pulmonary parenchymal opacities or pulmonary nodules identified.there is no axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.
summary: aortic dissection as described above originating just at the level of the origin of the left subclavian and extending through the entire descending thoracic aorta, the abdominal aorta, and both common iliac arteries.the sma, celiac axis, both renal arteries, and ___ all originate from the true lumen with no flap visualized.good opacification of both true and false lumens.aneurysmal dilation of the descending abdominal aorta most prominent just at the bifurcation with associated thrombus formation up to 5.8 x 5.5 cm.cirrhosis of the liver with sequelae of portal hypertension such as recanalization of the umbilical vein and gastroepiploic varices.

text: ct chest: there is no filling defect suggestive of pulmonary emboli down the subsegmental levels.atherosclerotic calcifications are seen throughout the transverse aorta.the great vessels are otherwise unremarkable.the heart is normal in size and no pericardial effusion.again seen is a 7 mm pretracheal node as well as several small non-pathologically enlarged nodes in the aortopulmonary window.there is some linear atelectasis seen in the right lung base.otherwise, there is no focal consolidation, pneumothorax or pleural effusion.again appreciated is a hiatal hernia.note is made of a multinodular thyroid seen with multiple hypodensities ranging in size from 1.2 cm to 1 cm.these are essentially unchanged compared to ct performed three years ago.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary emboli or other acute intrathoracic pathology.no acute aortic syndrome.decrease in size of previously seen mediastinal lymph nodes.no evidence of any pulmonary nodule or mass.unchanged multinodular thyroid.hiatal hernia again demonstrated.

text: the patient has had right upper chest wall resection.the region of anterior rib resection including a likely flap and possible graft material, including a small pleural fluid loculation is all unchanged since at least ___.there is no evidence of local tumor recurrence.both the resected and non-resected adjacent ribs show no evidence of tumor involvement.a tubular branching enhancing soft tissue structure extending superiorly from the right hilus has not changed in size since ___, but its axial diameter at the level of aortic arch calcifications, was 15.6 mm in ___:18, 12.3 mm today, 2:21 and 13 mm on ___, 2:19.the more distal smaller branching component of this abnormality has increased in size from ___ to ___ and has remained stable subsequently.i believe this is an impacted apical segmental bronchus.i would have presumed that it contains a slow growing endobronchial tumor; what appears to be a slight decrease in size over the past three months which could be due to chemotherapy.alternatively it is an inflamed mucoid impaction.central lymph nodes are not pathologically enlarged and there is no pericardial or pleural effusion, aside from loculated component along the chest wall graft described above.the study is not designed for subdiaphragmatic evaluation.bronchiectasis superior to the chest wall graft and lying along side it anteriorly is probably radiation related.there are no nodules in the periphery of the right lung, or in the left, aside from a calcified granuloma.several discrete pleural calcifications more numerous in the left hemithorax than the right are probably due to prior asbestos exposure.a small region of pulmonary fibrosis associated with bronchiectasis at the periphery of the right lower lobe posteriorly could be the residual of previous infection, could possibly be a very limited manifestation of pulmonary asbestosis.
summary: right suprahilar mass, increased slightly from ___ through ___ and stable or involuted subsequently is endobronchial abnormality, presumably tumor though conceivably mucoid impaction distal to small mass or benign narrowing in the apical segmental bronchus to the right upper lobe.bronchoscopy should be diagnostic.no evidence of tumor recurrence at the site of extensive right anterior chest wall resection.probable asbestos-related pleural plaque.minimal pulmonary fibrosis, not necessarily asbestos-related.

text: there are minor dependent atelectatic changes of both lungs.heart and great vessels are normal.the aorta is slightly tortuous.there are aortic vascular calcifications, but no evidence of dissection.multiple rib fractures are seen on the right, with an old healed rib fracture right #7.new rib fractures are seen at anterior aspect of right rib 2 causing a depressed chest wall deformity; there are rib fractures also seen in right rib 3, right rib 4, right rib 5, right rib 6, right rib 7, right rib 8, right rib 9.again no pneumothorax or hemothorax.there is a tiny amount of stranding in the substernal space, but without connection to the pericardium or to any vessels.there is no sternal fracture.
summary: multiple right-sided rib fractures causing mild chest wall deformity, but without pneumothorax or hemothorax.small amount of stranding in the retrosternal space, without connection to the pericardium or vessels.this is of uncertain significance, as there is no sternal fracture.non-occlusive filling defect in proximal portion of right common iliac artery.this is of uncertain age.contrast is seen beyond the filling defect.no fractures in thoracolumbar spine or bony pelvis.preliminary findings were relayed to the ed dashboard at time of image acquisition and discussed with the trauma surgery team.

text: there is no evidence for pulmonary embolus.the heart, great vessels, and pericardium are normal.the aorta is normal in caliber throughout.the airways are patent to the subsegmental level bilaterally.there is bilateral airspace consolidation of the lower lobes, left greater than right, consistent with pneumonia.there are scattered nodular opacities within the left upper lobe peripherally, ranging in size from 4-8 mm, also most likely infectious in etiology.there are no pleural or pericardial effusions.there is no pathologically enlarged axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymphadenopathy, however, multiple small, right paratracheal lymph nodes are identified, measuring up to 5 mm in short axis diameter.
summary: diffuse edema of the descending colon, sigmoid colon, and rectum with consistent with colitis.this finding is non-specific and may represent infectious etiology.a drug reaction if the patient is on chemotherapy could give this appearance.less likely is ischemia as the abdominal vasculature is widely patent.inflammatory bowel disease is also less likely.clinical correlation is recommended.no evidence for pulmonary embolus.bilateral airspace consolidation within the lower lobes, left greater than right, consistent with pneumonia.cholelithiasis without evidence for cholecystitis with mild central biliary ductal dilatation.multiple rounded low-attenuation foci within the kidneys bilaterally, which cannot be definitively characterized as simple renal cysts.a renal ultrasound is recommended for definitive characterization.at the time of interpretation at 1 p.m.on ___, these findings were discussed over the telephone with the ordering physician, ___.___ ___.

text: there are small bilateral pleural effusions, slightly increased from ___.the previously seen areas of ground-glass opacities in the upper lobes have progressed.this process is present diffusely throughout the lungs with upper lobe predominance.notes from careweb indicate that the patient was started on a new drug on ___, and these findings are all new since that period (not seen on prior ct study of ___).as such, drug-related toxicity or hypersensitivity should be seriously considered.additional diagnostic considerations include chronic eosinophilic pneumonia or less likely acute interstitial pneumonitis.the small mediastinal lymph nodes are unchanged.there are no pericardial effusions.coronary artery calcifications along the course of the left anterior descending coronary artery are unchanged.there is a small hiatal hernia.images of the upper abdomen demonstrate no abnormality.multiple sclerotic foci within the thoracic vertebral bodies are unchanged and could reflect metastatic disease.findings were discussed with dr.___ ___ on ___.
summary: progression of ground-glass opacities to consolidation predominantly in the upper lobes, likely toxicity or hypersensitivity to recently instituted medication.drug-related toxicity.if bronchoalveolar lavage or transbronchial biopsy is contemplated, the lung apices demonstrate the largest areas of involvement.

text: focal dissection of the descending aorta is again seen, distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery.overall appearance of focal dissection is unchanged.area involving the flap, again measures 17 mm in craniocaudal direction.there has been no propagation of the flap in any direction, and there is no evidence of new flap formation.small area of intramural hematoma adjacent to the aortic arch has resolved.there is no evidence of stranding within the mediastinum.there is no pericardial effusion.the great vessels are unremarkable.there has been interval resolution of pleural effusions.lung windows demonstrate no pulmonary nodules or focal consolidations.there is some subsegmental atelectasis in the right lower lobe.note is made of a separate origin of the left circumflex artery from the aorta, and mild coronary artery atherosclerotic calcification.
summary: unchanged appearance of short segment dissection involving the descending aortic arch, just distal to the left subclavian artery.interval resolution of small intramural aortic hematoma.interval resolution of pleural effusions.slight interval increase in intraabdominal free fluid, with high attenuation consistent with hemorrhagic ascites.unchanged appearance of findings consistent with portal hypertension, including prominent splenic and umbilical vein varices.

text: there are no filling defects in the pulmonary arteries to suggest presence of pulmonary embolism.there is a new small pericardial effusion.there is 2.6 x 1.4 cm anterior mediastinal soft tissue, slightly increased in size, compared to the prior study of ___.small left pleural effusion was present on the prior study.there is an opacity in the left lung base, which may represent atelectasis, aspiration or infection is not excluded.the evaluation of lung parenchyma is somewhat limited due to breathing motion artifact.the airways are patent to the subsegmental levels bilaterally.

text: comparison was made with ___ and ___.there is no pulmonary embolism to the subsegmental level, accounting for movement artifact in upper lobes.multifocal peribronchial opacities, bronchial wall thickening and tree-in-___ are in both lower lobes, right middle lobe and right upper lobe, much less marked in left upper lobe, worse than ___, some areas worse and some areas better than ___.there is no pleural effusion.airways are patent to the subsegmental level.subsegmental bronchi are slightly narrowed, likely due to peribronchial thickening and adjacent lymphatic tissue.small pericardial effusion increased.signs of anemia persist.mediastinal lymphadenopathy is unchanged, up to 17 mm in the subcarinal region and 13 mm in the lower paratracheal region.bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is also unchanged, up to 9 mm on the right.axillary lymph nodes are not enlarged using ct criteria.bilateral gynecomastia is asymmetrical to the left.a stent is in the lad and coronary artery calcifications are minimal.right picc ends in the cavoatrial junction.there is an ivc stent visible only on the scout view.this study was not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation except to note a fatty atrophy of the pancreas and splenomegaly.compression fracture of the upper abdomen is unchanged since ___.there is no suspicious bone lesion for malignancy.

text: there is asymmetric enlargement of the left lobe of the thyroid compared to the right with a focal hypodense area within the right lobe which is stable from the prior study.there is no supraclavicular, axillary or hilar lymphadenopathy.there are multiple small paraaortic lymph nodes in the mediastinum that are mostly unchanged from the prior study.there is a biventricular pacemaker and coronary artery calcifications.there are bilateral moderately sized pleural effusions with associated overlying atelectasis that appears unchanged from the prior exam.there is also fissural fluid in the left lung which is stable from the prior exam.there are no suspicious lung nodules seen.the airways are patent to the subsegmental levels.

text: previously seen left supraclavicular lymph node now measures approximately 2.0 x 1.2 cm (3:7), measuring slightly smaller compared to prior study.central low density again suggests necrosis.heart and great vessels appear stable.no pathologically enlarged mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy identified.1.7 x 1.1 cm pulmonary nodule located in the medial left lower lobe (3:47) does not appear significantly changed in appearance from prior study.two 5- mm pulmonary nodules in the right upper lobe are again seen, not significantly changed compared to prior study.no new nodules identified.there is no evidence of pleural effusion.again seen is evidence of emphysematous changes within the lungs.

text: patient is status post left pneumonectomy.no significant interval change seen in the appearance of apical pleural calcifications and fluid in the left hemithorax.stable left pleural thickening at the base again seen, with small enhancing component (3:36, 37) not significantly changed in appearance from prior study.heart and great vessels appear stable.there is no pericardial effusion.right lower lobe pleurally-based nodule again seen (3:36) measuring approximately 19 x 13 mm, little change compared to prior study.right apical, paramediastinal right middle lobe linear density is again seen, possibly representing scar versus radiation change.three-mm nodular density in the right upper lobe is also unchanged in appearance from prior study.no new nodules are identified.there is no pleural effusion.
summary: two dominant hepatic metastases, with additional smaller hypoattenuating lesions within the liver again seen, not significantly changed in appearance from prior study.multiple bilateral renal metastases unchanged.right medial lower lobe lung lesion, unchanged.narrowed left common iliac vein, not significantly changed in appearance from prior study.

text: the heart and pericardium appear unremarkable.the contours of the aorta and pulmonary arteries appear unremarkable.there are aortic mural calcifications, consistent with atheromatous disease.multiple mediastinal lymph nodes are seen which do not individually meet criteria for pathologic enlargement.the largest of these measures 9 mm in short axis diameter, located in the right hilum (series 2 image 29).additional subcentimeter nodes are seen in the pretracheal, precarinal, prevascular, and subcarinal locations.tiny probable retrosternal node (series 2 image 17).there is stranding within the subcutaneous soft tissues of the axillae bilaterally, more prominent on the right, as well as multiple vascular collaterals within the right chest.there is no evidence of thrombosis within the visualized portion of the right brachiocephalic vein.no pathologically enlarged axillary lymph nodes are seen.in the left scapular region, just adjacent to the scapular spine, a rounded 2.3 cm structure is seen with internal hypodensity suggestive of foci of gas or fat, too small to accurately characterize, and with a suggestion of a capsule.the airways are patent to the level of the subsegmental bronchi bilaterally, with minimal secretions seen within the right main stem bronchus.there is a moderate right pleural effusion layering dependently, with additional loculated pleural fluid along the right lateral chest wall (the fluid is of intermediate density, measuring approximately 22 hounsfield units).no left pleural effusion.there is extensive ill-defined opacity within the right middle and lower lobes, with patchy consolidation of the right lower lobe laterally and posteriorly.no definite nodules or masses are identified within the pulmonary parenchyma.a small amount of opacity is seen just adjacent to the major fissure on the left (series 2 image 36), felt likely to represent a small area of atelectasis versus scarring.within the right lung peripherally, there is a suggestion of thickening of the interlobular septa.limited images of the liver, adrenal glands, and spleen, appear unremarkable.the left kidney is atrophic and the right kidney is surgically absent, with surgical clips in the right renal fossa.
summary: consolidation within the right lower and middle lobes is suggestive of pneumonia.moderate right pleural effusion of intermediate density, with loculated component along the right lateral lung margin.multiple mediastinal lymph nodes, not quite meeting criteria for pathologic enlargement, are likely reactive.multiple right-sided rib fractures of varying ages.adjacent to the scapular spine on the left, an approximately 2 cm hypodense rounded structure containing internal fat and fluid.this is a nonspecific finding and clinical correlation with patient's symptoms in this region is recommended.this could possibly represent an infected fluid collection or inflamed bursa.atrophic left kidney and status post right nephrectomy.

text: the heart and great vessels are unremarkable.there is no evidence of pulmonary embolus.scattered prevascular lymph nodes do not meet ct criteria for enlargement.there is a small-to-moderate-sized left-sided pleural effusion with associated lower lobe compressive atelectasis.there is a small right-sided pleural effusion.patchy areas of consolidation are seen within the dependent right upper and lower lobes posteriorly consistent with aspiration.secretions are seen within left upper lobe bronchi.abdominal free fluid is partially visualized.osseous structures demonstrate a t11 vertebral body hemangioma.no suspicious lytic or sclerotic foci.multiplanar reformatted images were reviewed at the time of interpretation to evaluate vascular anatomy.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolus.patchy areas of consolidation in the right upper and lower lobes consistent with aspiration/infection.left lower lobe atelectasis.

text: the heart, pericardium and great vessels are within normal limits.there is no axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymphadenopathy.again seen is a wedge-shaped area with dystrophic calcification or inspissated barium, which appear slightly decreased in size.the lungs are otherwise clear.there are no pleural or pericardial effusions.

text: the heart, great vessels, and pericardium are normal.there is no evidence of aortic injury.the airways are patent to the segmental bronchi bilaterally.there are no pathologically enlarged axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymph nodes.there is no evidence of pneumothorax or pneumomediastinum.there are multifocal areas of consolidation, throghout both lungs, with the findings more predominant in the upper lobes.these are peripherally based with air-bronchograms.

text: no prior ct for comparison.study is somewhat limited secondary to motion.no filling defect is identified within the main or segmental pulmonary arteries.no evidence of central pulmonary embolism.the thoracic aorta is normal in caliber throughout, without aneurysmal dilatation.the heart is not enlarged.there is no pericardial effusion.there are no enlarged mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymph nodes.small lymph nodes are seen within the prevascular and paratracheal distribution.the central airway is patent, without filling defect.evaluation of the lungs reveals multiple ill-defined pulmonary nodules.within the right middle lobe, there are two nodules measuring 4 and 5 mm respectively (images 42 and 52), within the right lower lobe measuring 6 mm (image 32), and within the left lower lobe abutting the major fissure measuring 5 mm (image 67).no dominant mass is identified.there is dependent atelectasis bilaterally.there is mild central venous engorgement, and mild prominence of the interlobular septum, findings most compatible with mild underlying pulmonary edema.limited evaluation through the upper abdomen is grossly normal.there is degenerative change of the thoracic spine without lytic or sclerotic lesion.incidental note is made of hypodensities within the left lobe of the thyroid, better evaluated with ultrasound.
summary: no pulmonary embolism.multiple small pulmonary nodules as described.a followup ct examination is recommended in three months to further evaluate.incidental note of hypodense lesion within the left lobe of the thyroid, which would be better evaluated with ultrasound.mild pulmonary edema.

text: soft tissue windows reveal mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy, the largest one measuring approximately 1.8 cm in size in short axis in the pretracheal region.there is small bilateral pleural effusions.the patient is s/p cabg, pacemaker placements and et tube placement.the heart size is enlarged.there is no pericardial effusion.the et tube cuff is over-extended.retained secretion is demonstrated above the et tube cuff.lung windows reveal peripheral reticular pattern.there is patchy air space opacification in the right upper lobe and bilateral lower lobes.there is demonstrated in the right lower lobe consolidation posteriorly, raising the question of necrotizing pneumonia.note is also made of termination of right middle lobe bronchus, there is post-obstructive right middle lobe collapse/consolidation.in the proximal right middle lobe there is an area of homogeneous soft tissue density, which could represent a large obstructing lesion, measuring approximately 3.7 x 3.8 cm in size.within the right middle lobe, multiple hypoattenuation areas are present, which could represent post- obstructive necrosis.there is associated volume loss of the right lung.a large complex hernia is demonstrated at the thoraco-abdominal junction, probable periesphageal, containing both stomach and bowel loops.a small amount of ascites is demonstrated.a focal hypoattenuation area is demonstrated in the medial segment of the left hepatic lobe adjacent to the falciform ligament, most likely representing focal fat infiltration.bone windows reveal degenerative changes and a healed left lower rib fracture.
summary: findings concerning for centrally obstructing neoplastic mass, with post- obstructive right middle lobe collapse/pneumonitis with areas of necrosis.recommend correlation with bronchoscopy.bilateral lower lobe consolidations, raising the question of aspiration pneumonia associated with patient's large hernia.pockets of air demonstrated in the right lower lobe consolidative region raise the question of necrotizing pneumonia,.large complex probable periesophageal hernia containing both stomach and bowel.the et tube cuff is over-distended.bilateral small pleural effusions and mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy.

text: in comparison to ___, there has been interval resolution of small left and moderate loculated right pleural effusions.there is no residual pleural fluid identified, though minimal pleural thickening laterally on the right as well as associated scarring along the major and minor fissures is noted.there is no focal pulmonary consolidation.there is no pneumothorax.there are no pulmonary nodules or masses identified.the heart is notable for coronary calcification, as well as presence of both mitral and aortic valve prostheses.there is no pericardial effusion.the ascending aorta is mildly prominent, measuring 4.1 cm, stable since ___.there is mild atherosclerotic disease.the main pulmonary artery is normal in caliber.there is no large central embolus.prominent though not pathologically enlarged mediastinal nodes are noted, decreased in size compared to ___.for example, a pre-carinal node previously measuring 10 x 19 mm now measures 9 x 16 mm.the thyroid enhances normally.there is a right-sided picc, terminating in the superior vena cava.the trachea and central airways are patent to the subsegmental level.the esophagus appears normal.
summary: interval resolution of pleural effusions compared to ___.there is minimal scarring identified residually on the right.there is no evidence of pneumonia.note of aortic and mitral valve prostheses.prominent mediastinal lymph nodes are not pathologically enlarged by size criteria and are decreased from ___.no evidence of intra-abdominal infection.incidental note of infrarenal left-sided ivc.surgical clips in the region of the right common femoral artery, with underlying 1.9 x 2.0 x 5.5-cm thin-rimmed fluid collection, without significant associated inflammatory change.this may represent a simple post-operative seroma.clinical correlation to exclude superinfection is recommended.

text: multiple surgical clips and a dilated barium containing neoesophagus were noted consistent with known recent esophagectomy and gastric pull-through procedure.a single external drain is noted along the left lateral surface of the mid neoesophagus.no focal or paraneoesophageal fluid collections are identified and there is scattered prominent and likely reactive but not pathologically enlarged mediastinal lymphadenopathy.evaluation of the lung parenchyma displays bilateral moderate-sized pleural effusions right slightly greater than left with adjacent compressive atelectasis of portions of the right and left lower lobes.additional scattered ground-glass opacities and dense consolidations are noted within the aerated right and left upper lobes, right middle lobe and lingula lower lobes bilaterally.fat attenuation consolidation noted within the lingula and smaller additional fatty attenuation 6-mm lesion within the superior left lower lobe are stable.
summary: rim-enhancing multilobulated fluid collection adjacent to the splenic hilum is concerning for an abscess.it does not appear to be accessible by percutaneous drainage.remaining evaluation of the intra-abdominal intrapelvic organs is markedly limited due to a large amount of streak artifact from recently administered barium.interval development of moderate-sized bilateral pleural effusions with adjacent atelectasis of portions of the right and left lower lobes.unchanged appearance to lingular and left lower lobe lipoid pneumonia with interval worsening of multifocal ground-glass opacities and peribronchovascular infiltration worrisome for infectious etiology, likely aspiration related.no paraneoesophageal fluid collections identified.no clear presence of dense barium is noted within the tracheobronchial tree with unchanged appearance to airway chondrocalcification.findings were discussed with thoracic fellow dr ___ at 10 p.m.on date of exam.

text: the thyroid is unremarkable.there is no supraclavicular, axillary, or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.there is severe cardiomegaly.there are calcifications of the aortic valve and coronary arteries.there is no pericardial effusion.there is calcification of the aortic arch and descending aorta.there is no aneurysm.within the posterior mediastinum is a hematoma secondary to the t10 fracture.please see section on osseous structures for more details.there is interlobular septal thickening seen in the apices, the periphery, and in the subpleural distribution.this likely represents fluid overload.in the periphery of both lungs, there are several 3-5 mm nodules with the largest one measuring 5 mm (3a, 17).these are likely secondary to edema given their location and appearance.if clinically indicated, could consider followup when the patient is more euvolemic to assure resolution.there are bilateral ground-glass opacities at the bases also secondary to the pulmonary edema.there is a trace left-sided pleural effusion.there is no pleural effusion on the right.there is no pneumothorax.the pulmonary arteries are patent to the subsegmental level.there is no evidence of pulmonary embolism.

text: chest: many of the previously described 2-mm nodules are not well visualized on the present examination.this may be due to either resolution or slice selection.a right upper lobe nodule (series 3, image 15) is stable.an additional nodule within the right upper lobe (series 3, image 24) was not distinctly visualized on the previous exam.regions of scarring or atelectasis in the lung bases are again identified and are unchanged.there is no substantial change in the size or appearance of the numerous bilateral axillary, mediastinal, and hilar lymphadenopathy, in keeping with history of cll.the thoracic aorta is normal in appearance.the heart is not enlarged.there is no effusion.

text: there is no pulmonary embolism.thoracic aorta is normal in caliber and contour throughout.there is no dissection.mild global cardiomegaly is unchanged, but there is no sign of right ventricular enlargement.multiple borderline enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes have slightly increased in size, measuring up to 15 mm in the precarinal region (3:31), and 11 mm in the subcarinal region (3:39).endotracheal tube remains in place, tip terminating roughly 2 cm above the carina.right internal jugular central venous catheter is in place, tip at the superior cavoatrial junction.diffuse multifocal areas of ground-glass opacity in both lungs have markedly worsened since prior exam, and there are new areas of dense consolidation at the lung bases bilaterally, right greater than left, and in the right upper lobe.only the left upper lobe has been relatively spared from the progression since previous exam.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.this study is not specifically tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation, except to note unchanged fatty/atrophic appearance of the pancreas, and slight nodular enlargement of the left adrenal gland.limited views of the upper abdomen are otherwise unremarkable.nasogastric tube terminates in the stomach.there is no osseous lesion suspicious for malignancy.

text: between ___ and ___ sternal wires were removed and a presternal muscular flap graft was performed.edema of the graft has improved dramatically since ___.at the inferior margin of the graft, anterior to widely separated but normally mineralized xiphoid fragments is a bulbous soft tissue structure with attenuation characteristics identical to the graft (___ equals 35).i doubt that this is an infectious phlegmon because the fragments of the lower sternum and xiphoid have not demineralized and the cutaneous fistula tract at that level on ___ has been replaced by a thin strand which may all be scar.in addition the previous retrosternal soft tissue at this level which extended to the diaphragm has cleared entirely.there is no mediastinal or pleural fluid collection.lungs are clear aside from emphysema, following resolution of the atelectasis present on earlier scans.mediastinal lymph nodes are borderline enlarged ranging up to 12 mm in the lower paratracheal stations, unchanged since two most recent prior studies.the sternum is fused from the manubrium to the lower body just above the xiphoid fragments, and there is no new periosteal reaction or demineralization to suggest osteomyelitis.this study is not designed for subdiaphragmatic evaluation except to note stable chronic aortic dissection at the level of the diaphragm, large renal cysts, and severe scarring of the left kidney.
summary: no evidence of intrathoracic infection.previous edema of the presternal muscular flap has resolved.i doubt the bulbous presternal soft tissue structure at the inferior marin of the sternum is an infectious phlegmon.however, if clinical suspicion persists i would recommend ultrasound for evaluation and guidance of any indicated aspiration.no evidence of osteomyelitis.lungs clear.

text: there is a borderline enlarged lymph node in the left axilla measuring 9.8 mm in short axis.there are multiple subcentimeter mediastinal lymph nodes, none meeting strict criteria for pathologic enlargement.pulmonary arteries enhance normally throughout without evidence of filling defect to suggest pulmonary embolism.there is mild bibasilar dependent atelectasis.the thoracic aorta enhances normally throughout its visualized course.the heart, pericardium, and great vessels are unremarkable.the visualized airway is patent to the segmental level.there are several small densely calcified granulomas in the right lower lobe and scattered calcified plaques in the posterior left pleura.limited axial imaging through the upper abdomen demonstrates no abnormalities.non-contrast images demonstrate no evidence of intramural hematoma.coronal and sagittal reformatted images confirm the above findings.

text: the right brachiocephalic and left common carotid arteries have a common origin.no enlarged lymph nodes are seen in the chest.there is a very small right-sided pleural effusion, which has decreased.minor atelectasis is noted in the lingula.there are widespread areas of new abnormality in the lower lobes with many very small nodules, many of which are clustered, as well as vague ground glass opacities.the upper lobes are spared.new opacities are more widespread in the right lower lobe than the left.

text: the thoracic aorta demonstrates mild atherosclerotic calcification, without evidence of acute traumatic injury.the mediastinal vessels are unremarkable without acute traumatic injury.no mediastinal hematoma is detected.there is a large simple pericardial effusion.the attenuation values vary in the anterior portion of the pericardial effusion, likely artifactual.the dependent portion has low attenuation values consistent with simple fluid.no ct evidence for tamponade noted.the major airways are patent up to subsegmental levels bilaterally.no acute traumatic lung injury is detected.bibasilar scarring and atelectasis is seen in the right lung base.there is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax.

summary: progressive atelectasis of the left lung, now with complete lobar collapse of the left upper and lower lobes.increase in bilateral non-hemorrhagic pleural effusions, large on the left and small on the right.occlusion of the distal aspect of the left mainstem bronchus, which may be secondary to mucous plugging or invading tumor.overall slight increase in mediastinal adenopathy.progressive interlobular nodular septal thickening and ground-glass opacities in the right lung.findings are nonspecific and may reflect asymmetric edema or infection, though the appearance is concerning for lymphangitic spread of tumor.increased size of a segment ___/viii liver lesion and a newly identified segment vii lesion, findings concerning for worsening metastatic disease.healing fracture of the left posterior 9th rib, likely pathologic.dr.___ ___ communicated the preliminary results to dr.___ ___ at 7:38 pm on ___ by telephone.

text: there is no filling defect within the main, right, left, or segmental branches of the pulmonary artery to suggest the presence of pulmonary embolism.the thoracic aorta is normal in caliber throughout.there is no evidence of dissection.mild atherosclerotic calcifications of the aorta and coronary arteries are identified.heart size is grossly normal.there is an endotracheal tube in satisfactory position.left subclavian central catheter is present, with tip terminating in the cavoatrial junction.there are large bilateral pleural effusions with associated bilateral lower lobe collapse.there is scattered patchy airspace disease.a small cyst or bulla within the left lung is again identified.presently, it contains small amount of layering fluid.previously described right upper lobe nodule is again identified (series 3, image 42) and has not significantly changed in appearance.limited view of the upper abdomen demonstrates ascites.there is diffuse soft tissue edema, consistent with anasarca.osseous structures again demonstrate posterior fusion of the lower thoracic spine.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism.large bilateral pleural effusions, ascites, and anasarca.patchy airspace disease.

text: evaluation of the soft tissue reveals diffuse calcification of the aortic arch and coronary vessels.there is an avr.incidental note is made of an aberrant right subclavian artery, a normal variant.the heart is normal in size.no pleural or paracardial effusion is present.there is prominent soft tissue density within the right hilum which is poorly evaluated due to late time of the contrast bolus.adjacent is a 2.4 x 1.6 cm mass.several areas of patchy consolidation within the left lower lobe could represent aspiration or pneumonia.multiple closure wires are present within the sternum and the patient is post left mastectomy.no destructive lesions are seen on bone windows.
summary: nodule measuring 2.4 cm within the superior segment of the right lower lobe adjacent to soft tissue density in the right hilum.these findings are suggestive of a primary lung tumor, however, the evaluation is inadequate due to improper bolus timing.it is recommended that this study be repeated protocoled as a cta of the chest.

text: there are no filling defects within the pulmonary arteries to suggest pulmonary embolism.the pulmonary arteries are only well seen through the proximal subsegmental branches and a distal segmental and subsegmental pe cannot be excluded.pulmonary arteries are normal in size.there is atherosclerosis of the coronary arteries and the aorta.no aortic dilation.there is a large calcified plaque within the right subclavian artery proximal to the takeoff of the vertebral artery with apparent moderate stenosis of the right subclavian artery.there are large bilateral pleural effusions, left greater than right.there is dependent atelectasis within the lungs bilaterally.there is increased prominence of the fissures and bronchovascular bundles as well as some hazy ground-glass opacity, consistent with pulmonary edema.no pulmonary nodules or masses.no mediastinal, hilar, or axillary adenopathy.heart size is within normal limits.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism with certainty through the proximal segmental pulmonary arteries.distal segmental pulmonary arteries and subsegmental arteries are not optimally evaluated on this study.pulmonary edema and bilateral large pleural effusions without definite cardiomegaly.extensive coronary artery disease.large cystic lesion superior to the bladder and inseparable from the sigmoid colon likely represents an enteric duplication cyst; however, this is uncertain without intravenous contrast.a pelvic mri is recommended to characterize further if this has not been characterized on outside studies.moderate right proximal subclavian artery stenosis and calcified plaque.cholelithiasis, without evidence of cholecystitis.diffuse fatty infiltration of the liver.extensive renal calcification from diabetes and chronic renal insufficiency.extensive arteriosclerosis from diabetes and chronic insufficiency.

text: soft tissue window images demonstrate a left ij line with the tip in the right atrium.the aorta is normal in caliber, without any filling defects.the pulmonary arteries are normal, without any filling defects.there is a moderate to large simple-appearing left pleural effusion with associated compressive atelectasis.there is a small prevascular lymph node noted adjacent to the aorta.the previously noted right hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy is not as prominent on this study.lung window images demonstrate diffuse ground glass opacity within the upper lobes bilaterally, consistent with pulmonary edema.
summary: moderate to large simple-appearing left pleural effusion with associated ground glass opacity in the upper lungs, consistent with pulmonary edema.there is a large amount of ascites.there is colonic wall thickening and edema extending from the cecum to the transverse colon.the descending and sigmoid colon appear to be more normal in caliber.given this distribution, this more likely represents an infectious or inflammatory process.diffuse anasarca.findings consistent with right heart failure, including reflux of contrast into the hepatic veins.

text: the endotracheal tube terminates 2.5 cm above the carina and an ng tube is coiled in the dilated stomach.the heart and great vessels of the mediastinum are unremarkable.there is no pathologic axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.the lungs are clear aside from mild left dependent atelectasis.there is no pneumothorax or hemothorax.
summary: no evidence for traumatic injury in the chest, abdomen, or pelvis.

text: there has been interval development of bilateral diffuse patchy parenchymal opacities of both lungs.findings are consistent with pulmonary edema, though the differential includes extensive pneumonia.there has been interval regression of the left pleural effusion.a large right pleural effusion persists.there is associated atelectasis at the posterior base of the right lung.the heart and great vessels are normal.the airways are patent to the level of the segmental bronchi bilaterally.no pathologically enlarged hilar, mediastinal, or axillary lymph nodes.
summary: interval development of bilateral diffuse parenchymal opacities of the lungs, most consistent with pulmonary edema.extensive pneumonia would also be considered in the differential.large right pleural effusion.interval regression of left pleural effusion.changes of cirrhosis, anasarca, and varices as previously described.

text: no filling defects are seen within the main pulmonary artery and major branches.special attention was placed on the left atrium.two main right sided pulmonary veins are seen inserting into the left atrium.the superior most right pulmonary vein measures 26.4 x 19.5 mm in diameter.the inferior most right pulmonary vein measures 19.2 x 23.0 mm.the ridge between these two right pulmonary veins measures 8.3 mm in length.from the inferior most right pulmonary vein, a large branch draining the right middle lobe is seen, measuring 9.1 mm in diameter.small branches are seen to arise from both the superior and inferior right pulmonary veins.two main pulmonary veins are seen in the left side.the superior most left pulmonary vein measures 20.5 x 13.8 mm in diameter.the inferior most left pulmonary vein measures 18.4 x 14.0 mm in diameter.the ridge between these two left sided pulmonary veins measures 10.3 mm in length.a branch draining the lingula is seen inserting into the superior left pulmonary vein measuring 7 mm in diameter.

text: severe bullous emphysema, apical predominant is unchanged since ___.thickening of the walls of bullae generally is probably residual edema.right middle lobe nodule seen on ___ has resolved.three similar size opacities have appeared, ranging from 4 to 9 mm wide, 4:20 28 and 29.given their proximity and rapid development they are probably inflammatory.there are no focal lesions of concern in the left lung.a 10.5 mm wide prevascular mediastinal node was 6.4 mm in ___.a 13.2 mm right lower paratracheal node was 10.6 mm.a 10.8 mm juxtacardiac node, 3:33, was 9 mm.moderate cardiomegaly has increased.atrial septal fatty hypertrophy is noted.the intrapericardial right pulmonary is persistently enlarged, 33.8 mm across, indicating pulmonary arterial hypertension.heavy atherosclerotic plaque and mural thrombus throughout the arch and descending thoracic aorta is unchanged.

text: no intimal flap is detected within the aorta to suggest dissection.the heart is grossly unremarkable without pericardial effusion although there is pronounced epicardial fat.no filling defects are identified within the pulmonary arterial system to suggest pulmonary embolism although this study was not performed as a ctpa.bilateral breast prostheses are present.soft tissue stranding is noted in the left anterior chest wall superior to the left breast prosthesis likely post traumatic in nature.there is a small amount of right apical scarring.no suspicious nodule, opacity or effusion is present within the lungs.there is a mild amount of dependent atelectasis.no pneumothorax is detected.

text: there is no evidence of pulmonary embolism in the main pulmonary arteries or segmental pulmonary arteries.evaluation of the subsegmental branches is somewhat limited due to respiratory motion at the lung bases.no evidence of aortic dissection.heart size is normal.there are scattered calcifications within the coronary arteries.no pleural or pericardial effusion.there has been progression of the multiple right-sided pulmonary masses.within the right upper lobe, a rounded pleural based mass along the medial posterior border measures 3.6 x 2.8 cm (3:90), previously 2.4 x 1.8 cm.the large right lower lobe mass which extends from the pleura to the right hilum measures approximately 8.6 x 4.9 cm (3:61), previously 6.8 x 3.3 cm.the mass has an endobronchial component, nearly obliterating the main right lower lobe bronchus as well as the right middle lobe bronchus.the right middle lobe is nearly completely collapsed/infiltrated by tumor.the tumor also encases the right lower lobe artery.right hilar lymphadenopathy measures up to 2 cm.there is also a subcarinal node measuring 2.3 cm, precarinal node measuring 1.4 cm, and several additional prominent lymph nodes around the carina.there are also satellite nodules within the right lower lobe, measuring 1.3 cm at the right lung base (3:43), a 0.5 cm pleural based rll nodule (3:55), and a 1.1 cm right lower lobe nodule (3:58).other nodules have become more confluent and part of the right lower lobe mass.the left lung remains clear.the trachea is hyperexpanded and there are small foci of air adjacent to the trachea in the superior mediastinum, which likely represent small diverticula related to obstruction.the esophagus is patulous.this exam is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic assessment.again seen is a large heterogeneous lesion within the liver which remains concerning for metastasis and is increased in extent compared to ___.the lesion measures approximately 10 x 7.3 cm in the coronal plane.there is also a large nodule within the right adrenal gland measuring approximately 3.7 x 2.1 cm, new since the prior exam and also concerning for metastasis.lytic lesion within the inferior aspect of the t10 vertebral body with surrounding sclerosis has progressed since the prior exam.no loss of vertebral body height or pathologic fracture.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism.progression of metastatic disease with marked increase in the size of multiple right-sided pulmonary masses.the masses within the right lower and middle lobes have endobronchial extension, with near total collapse/infiltration of the right middle lobe, as well as encasement of the right lower lobe artery.these findings could relate to the patient's symptoms of hemoptysis.progression of metastatic disease with a new right adrenal metastasis, increased heterogeneous liver lesion which is likely a metastasis, as well as progression of the lytic t10 lesion without vertebral body collapse.

text: the thyroid gland is within normal limits.no pathologically enlarged supraclavicular, axillary, or mediastinal lymph nodes are identified.the tracheobronchial tree is patent to subsegmental levels.there is no pulmonary embolism or acute aortic syndrome.the heart is normal in size, and there is no pericardial effusion.a small right medial apical lucency is identified, most likely secondary to streak artifact from the adjacent contrast bolus.there is no focal consolidation, mass, or large pleural effusions.bibasilar atelectasis is identified.

text: since ___, there is marked radiologic deterioration.extensive subcutaneous and deep soft tissue edema in the left axilla, anterior thoracic cavity, and left posterolateral chest wall significantly progressed.marked diffuse anasarca.there is no subcutaneous air.large left simple pleural effusion significantly worse than ___ and tiny right pleural effusion.bibasilar secondary atelectasis is moderate on the right and marked on the left with complete collapse of left lower lobe.ng and et tubes are in good position.left-sided central line ends in the upper svc.bilateral pleural plaques are calcified.aortic valve calcifications are of unknown hemodynamic significance.coronary artery calcifications are scattered.ribs and bones are normal except to note multiple degenerative changes in the spine.12 x 5 mm left thyroid lobe hypodensity is unchanged.this exam was not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation except to note a calcified gallstone.

text: there is a midline tracheostomy tube.there is no new focal consolidation.moderate to large left pleural effusion with adjacent atelectasis is present.there is questionable residual chronic filling defect in right upper lobe pulmonary arterial branch (se 301b, image 38); however bolus was not optimal for evaluation.the previously described filling defect in the right brachiocephalic vein (2:19) is unchanged.there is no pneumothorax.there is no pericardial effusion.there is mitral annular calcification.there are no pathologically enlarged lymph nodes in the mediastinum, hila, or axilla.
summary: moderate to large left pleural effusion with overlying atelectasis.question residual chronic pe in the right segmental level; contrast bolus is not optimal for evaluation.stable small clot in the right brachiocephalic vein.new/increased left lower quadrant rim enhancing fluid collection, measuring up to 6.7 cm, anterior to the left iliacus muscle, where drain was placed previously.new right lower quadrant smaller collection about 2 cm, not well defined.post-surgical appearance of the abdomen and pelvis with stranding in the mesentery and free fluid, free fluid decreased prior.stable prominence of the left collecting system and left hydroureter, most likely secondary to the downstream inflammation.new mild prominence of the right renal collecting system and right ureter without definite obstructing lesion, although ureter not opacified at time of study.correlate with creatinine and attention at followup.subtle nodularity along the anterior contour of the left lobe of the liver is noted, with possible subtle underlying hypodensity.if this has not been previously evaluated, suggest further evaluation with ultrasound or mri.6 stable hypodense nodule at the surgical resection in pelvis.attention on followup.updated findings submitted to the radiology critical findings dashboard.

text: there are filling defects within the right subsegmental arteries (3, 14 and 3, 26) supplying the anterior and posterior segments.in addition, filling defects involving the right middle lobe subsegmental branches (3, 47) are also identified.there are possible left upper lobe subgmental pulmonary emboli (3,24).there are bilateral lower lobe consolidations with air bronchograms (3, 57).while this may represent atelectasis as it is enhancing, underlying infection cannot be excluded given the presence of air bronchograms.there are multiple mediastinal and left hilar lymph nodes.for example, at example, there is a left hilar lymph node measuring 1.3 x 1.5 cm (3, 43).a prevascular lymph node measures 0.7 x 2.3 cm (3, 27).there is no axillary lymphadenopathy identified.there is no pleural effusion.very trace pericardial fluid vs thickening is noted.there is no evidence of aortic dissection.no pneumothorax is seen.gynecomastia is noted.

text: et tube and ng tube are present.soft tissue windows shows no significant axillary, mediastinal or hilar lymph node enlargement.there is cardiomegaly.the pericardium is unremarkable.intrathoracic aorta has a normal caliber.incidentally seen is focal dilatation at the origin of the brachiocephalic artery with associated bovine arch.pulmonary arterial tree is well opacified by iv contrast.there is limited evaluation of the segmental and subsegmental branches of the pulmonary arterial tree due to their small size.the remainder of the pulmonary arterial tree shows no intraluminal filling defects to suggest the presence of pulmonary emboli.there are no pleural effusions.visualized upper abdomen shows extensive ascites consistent with peritoneal dialysis.lung windows show bibasilar atelectasis.no pulmonary nodules are seen.the airways appear patent to the level of the segmental bronchi bilaterally.the osseous structures are unremarkable.multiplanar reconstruction images confirm the above findings.
summary: limited evaluation of segmental and subsegmental branches of the pulmonary arterial tree.remainder of the pulmonary arterial tree shows no pulmonary emboli.cardiomegaly.ascites consistent with peritoneal dialysis.et tube and ng tube.

text: there are several small axillary lymph nodes which do not meet ct criteria for pathologic enlargement.the mass lesion previously identified extending from the svc into the right atrium demonstrates a more central area of hypoattenuation with soft tissue attenuation surrounding the lesion.there is no significant change in size in this obstructive lesion.there is no significant axillary adenopathy.there is no pericardial effusion.the left pleural effusion has resolved.there is a small right pleural effusion.post-xrt changes are seen in the paramediastinal distribution.the right apical pulmonary nodule is unchanged.no new nodular densities are identified.the airways are patent to the level of the segmental bronchi bilaterally.
