text: there is an interval increase of the number and the dimension of the pulmonary nodules.numerous pulmonary nodules are observed in both lungs.there are new nodules which are noticed in the subpleural area in the left lower lobe with peripheral enhancement.there is also pleural enhancement near these nodules.there is interval growth in most of the nodules inside the lungs.for example, the medial nodule in the left lower lobe which previously measured 0.8 cm now measures 1.3 cm.multiple lymph nodes are seen in the thoracic inlet in the left, paratracheal in the right side and the subcarinal.part of the lymph nodes are without change and the infracarinal nodes decrease from 2.7 x 2.2 to 2 x 2 cm.a stent is observed in the bronchus intermedius in the right side.
summary: there is interval marked progression of the disease especially in the thorax and abdomen.paraspinal mass with destruction of the right side of l3 and epidural components is observed - this finding is new.these findings were discussed in detail with the patient's doctor.

text: since ___, patient has had left upper posterior rib resections and externalization of the pleural space.the rind of pleural thickening in the left upper hemithorax is uniform, not as thick as it was preoperatively, and contains no gas or fluid loculations.soft tissue surrounding the thoracostomy site is normal.left hilus and the augmented bronchial stump have a normal postoperative appearance following upper lobectomy.dependent left pleural thickening and layering left pleural effusion are both very small.the extent of pleural thickening overlying the hilus and the upper mediastinum has substantially.10 mm left lower paratracheal lymph node is unchanged, and other nodes are not pathologically enlarged.this study is not designed for subdiaphragmatic diagnosis, but shows no adrenal mass.emphysema is severe.previous widespread bronchocentric infiltrative pulmonary abnormality has almost entirely cleared, leaving only a small residual in the right upper lobe at the level of the aortic apex.segmental atelectasis at the base of the left lung has improved.small pericardial effusion is stable.
summary: no evidence of new or recurrent intrathoracic malignancy.normal postoperative appearance for both left upper lobectomy and externalization of the left apical pleural space with chest wall resection and presumed muscle flap location.severe emphysema.'spill over' pneumonia cleared.

text: there is a very small filling defect in a right lower lobe subsegmental branch (series 3, images 25-23), consistent with a tiny subsegmental pulmonary embolus.additionally, there is an equivocal filling defect present in an additional subsegmental branch in the right lower lobe (series 3, image 27).no other filling defects are identified within the pulmonary arterial system.the aorta and major aortic branch vessels appear intact, with scattered areas of calcification consistent with atherosclerosis.there are multiple small mediastinal and axillary lymph nodes that do not meet ct criteria for pathologic enlargement.there is a possible trace pericardial effusion.there is opacity in the left lower lobe most consistent with atelectasis.lungs are otherwise grossly clear.the airways appear patent to the level of the segmental bronchi bilaterally.there is probable mimimal bronchiectasis in the lower lobes.limited images of the upper abdomen demonstrate a cyst in segment 8 of the liver, also seen on the previous study.bone windows reveal no suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions.there are multiple tiny focal densities in the posterior spinal canal in the lower thoracic spine, unchanged compared to the previous study, could represent residua from a previouis pantaque administration.
summary: tiny, subsegmental right lower lobe filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism.there is an additional equivocal tiny filling defect within a different right lower lobe subsegmental branch that could represent a second tiny focus.

text: the airways are patent to the subsegmental level.there has been interval decrease in a small-to-moderate partially loculated right pleural effusion.there is no pneumothorax.consolidation in the left base has almost completely resolved.from the previously described noncalcified lung nodules only one is clearly detected on this examination located in the right middle lobe (4, 133).small areas of atelectasis in the right middle lobe and adjacent to the pleural effusion have decreased.there are no new lung abnormalities.cardiac size is normal.there is no pericardial effusion.the aorta is normal in caliber.there are no axillary lymph nodes.mediastinal lymph nodes measure up to 10 mm in the subcarinal stations.right hilar lymphadenopathy measures up to 20 mm.phrenic lymph node measures 5 mm.the upper abdomen is unremarkable.there are no bone findings of malignancy.

text: there is no evidence of pulmonary embolism to the subsegmental levels.there is extensive atherosclerotic disease involving the thoracic aorta.there is no evidence of aortic dissection or intramural hematoma.there is extensive atherosclerotic disease involving the right coronary artery, left anterior descending artery and left circumflex arteries.the patient is status post dual-lead pacemaker placement with leads in standard positions.the main pulmonary trunk measures up to 3.3 cm, most compatible with pulmonary hypertension.no axillary adenopathy is identified.there is a pre-prominent pretracheal lymph node measuring approximately 1.4 cm in its transverse diameter, best seen on (3:25).there are multiple other smaller scattered mediastinal lymph nodes.no hilar adenopathy is identified.there is a moderate-to-large sized right pleural effusion and a small-in-size left pleural effusion that both dependently layer.there are scattered areas of linear airspace consolidation in a configuration that is most compatible with atelectasis.this can be seen involving the right lower ___, right middle ___, and the left lower ___.note is made of an enlarged heterogeneous appearance of the thyroid, most compatible with multinodular goiter.clinical correlation can be obtained.this examination is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation.the liver and spleen are incompletely imaged.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism.moderate-to-large in size right pleural effusion and small left pleural effusion.scattered areas of linear atelectasis involving the right and left lower lobes and the right middle ___.enlarged heterogeneous appearance of the thyroid, most compatible with multinodular goiter.enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes of uncertain etiology, could be reactive in nature.borderline enlarged main pulmonary trunk measuring 3.3 cm, compatible with pulmonary hypertension.

text: there has been interval improvement in the left pleural effusion with persistent right pleural effusion and adjacent atelectasis.the heart remains enlarged.there is no pericardial effusion.the great vessels are normal.the airways are patent to the subsegmental level.
summary: no evidence of intra-abdominal abscess or diverticulitis.no pneumonia.cirrhosis, status post tips with less ascites than on prior study.old compression fracture at t12.

text: the patient is status post right upper lobectomy.there is persistent consolidative lung parenchyma at the posterior medial right apex in association with bronchiectasis and distributed in a geographic pattern.this is consistent with post radiation change.there is mild concentric thickening within the paratracheal soft tissue that is also stable and is likely secondary to post radiation changes.there is a stable, approximately 2 mm nodule at the right apex seen best on image 16 of series 2.additionally, there is a stable linear opacity seen at the periphery of the right lower lobe seen on image 24 series 2 that is additionally stable and may represent a focal area of scarring.there is a triangular shaped peripheral opacity at the left lung base seen best on image 37 of series 2 which is unchanged from the prior study.there are no pleural or pericardial effusions.there are secretions present within the trachea and left main bronchus.there is underlying centrilobular emphysema.there is a moderate hiatal hernia not significantly changed from the prior study.there is no significant mediastinal hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy.the upper abdomen is visualized.there is a punctate hypodensity within the lateral segment of the left lobe of the liver which is unchanged from the prior study that likely represents a cyst.there is persistent fullness of the left adrenal gland which is not significantly changed from the prior study.there is a stable cyst within the upper pole and the lower pole of the left kidney.
summary: there has been no significant change in the post xrt changes in the right apex.there are stable left renal cysts.there is fullness of the left adrenal gland which is unchanged from the prior study.there is stable hypodensity within the lateral segment of the left lobe of the liver.this likely represents a hepatic cyst.there is moderate hiatal hernia.there are secretions present within the central airways.

text: chest: there is consolidation involving the entirety of the right upper lobe.centrally, there is no distinct structural or fat planes preserved between the consolidated lung, underlying known perihilar tumor, and mediastinum.due to subtle differences in attenuation, massively enlarged presumably malignant lymph nodes can be identified in the subcarinal, right paratracheal, and prevascular spaces.one such node measuring approximately 5.9 x 3.7 x 2.8 cm is adjacent to and causes significant mass effect upon the superior vena cava.mediastinal invasion is strongly suspected.there are abrupt cut-offs of both the right upper lobe bronchus and right upper lobe artery.arterial supply to the drowned right upper lobe is maintained presumably by collaterals and supply from bronchial arteries.however, there is nearly absent opacification of the right upper lobe lung parenchyma.there are clusters of lucencies peripherally in the right apex likely reflecting a necrotizing component to the post-obsructive pneumonia.there is complete collapse of the right lower lobe with fluid attenuation filling the supplying bronchials consistent with aspiration.a large simple right-sided pleural effusion is noted and contributes to the volume loss.this effusion tracks up to the upper right hemithorax.the trachea and main bronchi are patent.the left lung demonstrates nodular opacity in the left apex measuring up to 1.2 cm.peri-septal emphysematous changes are seen.there is a 1.9 cm left upper lobe nodule.there is also a 0.9 cm left upper lobe nodule adjacent to the major fissure is seen (5:45).a nodular opacity in the lingula is pleural-based and measures up to 0.7 cm (5:61).the thyroid gland is heterogeneous.the ascending thoracic aorta measures 3.3 cm in diameter.the descending thoracic aorta measures 2.2 cm in diameter.there is no evidence of aortic dissection.the heart is normal in size.coronary artery calcifications are seen.there is no pericardial effusion.partially visualized liver contains multiple hypodense lesions with the largest measuring up to 1.3 cm in the right lobe.there are scattered peripheral foci of hyperattenuation in both kidneys seen on the non-contrast exam, likely representing hemorrhagic-proteinaceous cysts (when compared to prior exams).left-sided renal hypodensities with the largest measuring up to 2.6 cm in the left renal upper pole likely represents cysts; however, incompletely evaluated due to streak artifact from adjacent spinal orthopedic hardware.the partially evaluated spleen and pancreas appear grossly unremarkable.the left adrenal is thickened.the right adrenal is not well seen due to adjacent streak artifact from spinal hardware.
summary: right upper lobe mass with postobstructive lung collapse-pneumonia with probable areas of cavitation-necrosis and obliteration of the right upper lobe pulmonary artery and bronchus.there is poor to near-absent lung parenchyma opacification as above.multiple mediastinal lymph nodes, presumed malignant, as described above.invasion of the mediastinum by right upper lobe mass is not excluded.anterior paratracheal lymph node places significant mass effect on the superior vena cava.left-sided pulmonary nodules with the largest measuring up to 1.7 cm.right lower lobe aspiration-pneumonia.massive likely malignant right-sided pleural effusion with lung collapse.bilateral renal cysts some of which are hyperdense and likely hemorrhagic-proteinaceous.multiple liver hypodense lesions, may represents cysts versus metastatic lesions.posterior fifth rib and sternal lucent lesions, likely metastatic.known pathologic compression fracture of t10 vertebral body.post-surgical changes of the spine.

text: there is adequate opacification of the pulmonary arterial tree, with no evidence for pulmonary embolus to the subsegmental level.the main pulmonary artery is normal in caliber.the aorta is atherosclerotic but normal in caliber.the origins of great vessels are unremarkable.there is no evidence of acute aortic syndrome.the heart is enlarged, with prominence of the atria.there is a small pericardial fluid.marked coronary calcifications are noted.a single-lead pacer is seen extending to the right ventricle.there are prominent mediastinal nodes, though none pathologically enlarged by size criteria.esophagus is unremarkable.an orogastric tube is seen passing into the stomach, though should be advanced for optimal positioning.the trachea and central airways are patent; however, there are extensive secretions identified, particularly within the left main stem bronchus, and also within the segmental and subsegmental airways at the right base.endotracheal tube is in standard position.in the lungs, there is mild emphysema.opacifications located dependently at the bilateral bases are noted, compatible with aspiration given the presence of secretions within the tracheobronchial tree.there is mild bronchiectasis and basilar fibrotic change, which may reflect chronic aspiration.no definite pulmonary nodule or mass identified, though evaluation is limited by basilar consolidations.there is no large effusion.there is no pneumothorax.
summary: bibasilar dependent opacities most consistent with aspiration given the presence of extensive secretions within the tracheobronchial tree.basilar fibrotic change and bronchiectasis may reflect chronic aspiration as well.no pulmonary embolus or acute aortic syndrome.orogastric tube enters the stomach, but should be advanced for optimal positioning.mild emphysema.extensive coronary calcifications.small pericardial fluid.no acute intra-abdominal process.no evidence for abscess, free fluid, or free air.suprapubic catheter in standard position.there is large bladder stone and bladder wall thickening, but there is no associated fluid collection or abscess in this region.aortic and coronary atherosclerosis, without frank aneurysm.narrowing of the sma origin noted.

text: the patient is status post cabg and there is has been resection of the sternum for osteomyelitis.at the level of the superior sternal notch, there is a 4.0 x 3.5 x 5 cm (transverse, ap, and craniocaudal dimensions, respectively), fluid collection which has enlarged from the reference scan from an outside hospital.there is a slightly hyper- attenuating rim.there is mild stranding in the surrounding subcutaneous fat.staple material is seen in the region.the fluid collection associated stranding are extending posteriorly into the anterior mediastinum.several lymph nodes are seen in the mediastinum, which do not meet size criteria for pathologic enlargement and appear stable when compared to ___.the airways are patent to the subsegmental bronchi level.there is a homogeneously enhancing left lower lobe opacity consistent with atelectasis.minimal dependent atelectasis is also seen at the right lung base.the lungs are otherwise clear.there is mild cardiomegaly.there is no pericardial effusion.no acute pathology is detected in the partially visualized upper abdominal organs.there is mild fat stranding in the subcutaneous tissues inferiorly to the described sternal fluid collections extending down to the level of the upper abdomen.

text: there remains a moderately sized right pleural effusion with a small anterior loculated component, best seen on series 4, image 172.stable scarring/atelectasis in the right lower lobe.involving the region of interest, there remains a focal rounded area of consolidation in the inferior right middle lobe with a surrounding area of loculated pleural fluid.the morphology of this region suggests it most likely represents a focus of rounded atelectasis, however, it is unchanged in appearance and is not resolved since ___.minimal atelectasis in the left lower lung.no suspicious nodules or masses are seen within the lungs.cardiomegaly with coronary artery calcification, aortic valve replacement, and evidence of prior cabg.atherosclerotic calcification throughout the thorax and upper abdomen.no pathologically enlarged lymph nodes are seen throughout the axillary, mediastinal, and hilar distributions.small subcentimeter mediastinal nodes are noted, not pathologically enlarged by ct criteria.the airways are patent to the segmental level.images of the upper abdomen demonstrate dense splenic artery calcification and hepatic venous reflux, which is occasionally seen in the setting of congestive heart failure.bone windows demonstrate scoliosis, degenerative changes and demineralization without suspicious lytic or blastic lesions.

text: centrilobular emphysema is seen.a moderate right pleural effusion is present.middle lobe and medial basilar right lower lobe atelectasis is present.no pneumothorax is seen.pulmonary arteries are patent to the segmental level.no embolism or filling defect is noted.a 2.4 x 4.6 cm precarinal mass impinges on the right middle lobe pulmonary artery (5:42, 5:48).no additional mediastinal, axillary or hilar adenopathy is present.a multilobulated dense liver lesion is seen in the right lobe expanding out from segment viii.perihepatic ascites is present.several rim-enhancing peritoneal implants are present in the right upper quadrant and midepigastrium (5:108, 5:99).the dense ascites measures complex density of 30 hounsfield units.the adrenal glands are normal.

text: there are bilateral pleural effusions, right greater than left with additional small focus of ground-glass opacification in the right lower lobe, likely due to fluid overload.there is a small amount of atelectasis in the medial segment of the right middle lobe.underlying mild emphysematous changes are noted.there are three small, sub 5-mm nodules (images 59, 83 and 84).these may represent small locules of fluid.there is a moderate-to-severe supravalvular aortic stenosis, with the ascending aorta measuring 5.6 ap x 5.4 tv cm at the level of the main pulmonary artery.at this same level, the descending thoracic aorta measures 2.3 cm, and the main pulmonary artery measures 3.1 cm.there are dense calcifications at the aortic root, in keeping with the reported history of bicuspid valve.lack of ekg gating precludes assessment thereof.solitary focus of coronary artery calcifications are seen in the distal rca.mild left atrial enlargement.there is classic arterial arch anatomy.no pericardial effusion.scattered slightly enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes, the largest in a pretracheal location measuring 2.1 x 1.5 cm (3, 30) small bihilar nodes.no axillary nodes.there is no pulmonary embolus.limited continuation of imaging below the diaphragm demonstrates no abnormalities.the bony structures are unremarkable with mild degenerative changes of the thoracic spine.

text: soft tissue window images demonstrate bilateral axillary lymphadenopathy.additionally, there are prominent soft tissues in the right paratracheal region, and in the right hilar region and along the right main stem bronchus.there is a small right pleural effusion.there is no left pleural effusion.no pericardial effusion is seen.lung window images demonstrate nodular consolidative wedge-shaped opacity involving the posterior aspect of the right lower lobe.this demonstrates areas of nodularity.adjacent to this anterosuperiorly, there are two 7 and 5-mm nodules (series 2, image 42).additionally, there is a small subpleural nodular density in the left lower lobe (series 2, image 33).

text: since the prior exam, there has been resection of the right medial clavicle, right first rib and right sternoclavicular joint, with a partial sternectomy.the chest wall is open and there is a 3 x 2.3 cm focus of fluid in the operative bed abutting the first right rib, which is newly eroded raising concern for osteomyelitis.previously seen retrosternal fluid collection and mass-like induration of the right pectoralis muscle edema have resolved.there is however increasing soft tissue density at the left sternoclavicular joint (2:7), possible infective arthritis, although without a discrete fluid collection.anterior and superior mediastinal fat is clean with no fluid collection or abscess.borderline enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes are unchanged, up to 1 cm in the right lower paratracheal and 0.9 cm in the right hilum.heart size is normal and there is no pericardial or pleural effusion.a 6-mm right middle lobe nodule is new from ___ (4:128).no additional nodules identified.the bronchi are patent to the subsegmental level.this exam is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic assessment.the liver is nodular, with hypertrophy of the caudate and right lobes consistent with cirrhosis.a replaced left hepatic artery arising from the left gastric artery is noted.a gallstone is seen within a non-distended gallbladder.the spleen is enlarged measuring 15 cm in long axis.there are no bone findings of malignancy.
summary: interval decrease in right pectoralis major edema and retrosternal fluid collection following resection of the right sternoclavicular joint.small fluid collection at the surgical site could be due to soft tissue infection.irregularity of the distal right first rib which may be due to chronic osteomyelitis.soft tissue proliferation at the left sternoclavicular joint may be due to infectious arthritis.new 6-mm right middle lobe nodule, presumably inflammatory.cirrhosis, splenomegaly and cholelithiasis.

text: the widespread pulmonary nodules are again noted, slightly decreased in size and number, comparing to ___.in contrary the right pleural effusion again appeared, still small.the airways remain patent.there is no evidence of endobronchial lesions.no new consolidation or masses are demonstrated.there is no mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy.a note is made again of dilated azygos and hemiazygos vein.the heart size is normal.a dilated right pulmonary artery is noted measuring up to 2.8 cm and may represent pulmonary hypertension.the images of the upper abdomen again demonstrate slightly enlarged spleen with multiple areas of low density, unchanged comparing to the previous study.generally enlarged thyroid gland with several hypodense nodules is unchanged.

text: there is evidence of prior cabg with median sternotomy wires and vascular clips.there is a right internal jugular central line noted.there are coronary artery calcifications.there are prominent mediastinal and anterior diaphragmatic nodes.the largest prevascular node measures approximately 1 cm in short axis.a lower paratracheal node is also noted to measure 1.1 cm in short axis.the largest anterior diaphragmatic node measures approximately 9 mm in short axis.there is a large left sided pleural effusion with more loculated components noted superiorly and medially.there is associated compressive atelectasis and partial collapse of the left lower lobe.there is a trace right sided pleural effusion with minor associated dependent atelectasis.there are scattered bilateral calcified pleural based plaques.there are ground glass opacities appreciated in both lung which would be most consistent with mild pulmonary edema.note is also made of pleural thickening along the right superior mediastinum.the bronchi are obtained to the segmental level bilaterally.note is made of secretions seen in the trachea.the tracheostomy tube cuff is also noted to be hyperinflated measuring approximately 3.1 cm across.the visualized portions of the upper abdomen are again remarkable for ascites, as seen on ct of the abdomen dated ___.
summary: left sided pleural effusion with loculated components noted on the superior and medial aspects of the left lung.while this complex pleural effusion could be may be associated with clinical diagnosis of pancreatitis, given evidence of prior asbestos exposure with calcified plaques, further follow-up is recommended to exclude alternative concern for mesothelioma.a follow-up ct is recommended in three months.correlation with thoracentesis may also be considered.left lower lobe passive atelectasis/collapse associated with pleural effusion.findings consistent with mild pulmonary edema.prominent mediastinal and anterior diaphragmatic lymph nodes, which could be hyperplastic.attention to these nodes at the time of follow-up ct is recommended.overdistended tracheostomy tube cuff.findings were discussed with the clinical team on ___ at 10:00 a.m.

text: in the lung windows, there are moderate bilateral pleural effusions with concomitant atelectasis versus opacities.in addition to the effusions in adjacent collapsed portions of the lung, there are multiple focal opacities in the right upper lobe and right middle lobe consistent with an infectious process.in soft tissue windows, no axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymphadenopathy.the heart and great vessels of the mediastinum are unremarkable.an ng tube is identified in the esophagus.the tip of the endotracheal tube is approximately 4 cm above the carina.
summary: no evidence for pulmonary embolus.bilateral pleural effusions and atelectasis/partial collapse of adjacent lower lobes.multifocal opacities in the right lung concerning for pneumonia.severe pancreatitis with decreased enhancement of the neck and tail concerning for necrosis.multiple peripancreatic fluid collections.these findings were discussed with the resident from the surgical team, dr.___, who is caring for the patient.

text: the heart, pericardium and great vessels are unremarkable.there is a small lymph node noted in the ap window, measuring 12 x 9 mm.no evidence of pneumothorax or pleural effusion.there is no focal consolidation noted.no evidence of pulmonary masses or nodules.
summary: there is evidence of two hemangiomas noted in the liver.evidence of diverticula, but no diverticulitis.no radiographic evidence for metastatic disease.

text: there is atherosclerotic disease of the thoracic aorta with diffuse intramural thrmobus formation and plaque formation involving the arch and rest of the thoracic aorta.no dissection or mediastinal hematoma is seen.there is no extravasation of iv contrast.evaluation of aneurysmal dilatation is difficult in the face of marked tortuosity.however, the lower thoracic aorta is aneurysmal measuring approximately 4.5 cm in diameter.focal scarring is seen in the posterior aspect of the right upper lobe and atelectasis and/or scarring is appreciated anteriorly involving the left upper lobe.also, there are three sub-5 mm nonspecific nodules seen in the right lower lobe, a small subpleural nodule in the lingula, and a few nodules in the left upper lobe.no pleural effusions or areas of consolidation are seen.there is no enlarged mediastinal or hilar lymph nodes.coronary artery calcifications are seen.there is no pericardial effusion.
summary: aneurysms of the descending and infrarenal aorta with extensive atheromatous plaque and mural thrombus.note is made of accessory renal arteries, one on each side, which originate from the abdominal aortic aneurysm.ulcerated artheromatous plaque is also noted.no evidence of aortoenteric fistula, dissection or rupture.colonic wall thickening of the upper ascending and transverse portions with mild adjacent stranding at the hepatic flexure consistent with colitis.small non-calcified pulmonary nodules.these may represent granulomas, but follow up ct in six months or comparison to prior studies, if available, is recommended.

text: the airways are patent to the segmental level bilaterally.the previously seen tree-in-___ opacities within the right middle lobe and bilateral lower lung lobes have improved in the interim but are still present.again seen in the left lower lung lobe is a 7.4-cm rounded mass which has decreased in attenuation.this mass previously measured 7.8 cm and is therefore essentially stable in size.coronary artery calcifications are seen within the heart.the heart is otherwise unremarkable.the pericardium is normal.the aorta demonstrates diffuse atherosclerotic calcifications throughout but is normal in caliber.the pulmonary arteries are normal.again seen are multiple small pulmonary nodules.along the right major fissure is again seen an 8-mm nodule which previously measured 9 mm.a 5-mm calcified nodule is seen at the left lung base, stable.again seen in the subcarinal region of the mediastinum is an enlarged lymph node measuring 1.5 cm, which previously measured 2.2 cm, and is therefore decreased in size in the interim.there is no new pathologically enlarged axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.
summary: unchanged size of left lower lung lobe mass measuring approximately 7.4 cm in greatest axial dimension.this mass has decreased attenuation when compared with the prior exam which may be secondary to chemotherapy treatment and necrosis.small pulmonary nodules in the lower lobes bilaterally are unchanged.interval improvement of multifocal tree-in-___ opacities within the right middle and bilateral lower lung lobes, likely infectious in origin.interval decreased size of subcarinal lymphadenopathy which measures 1.5 cm, which previously measured 2.2 cm.no evidence for recurrent disease in the abdomen or pelvis.

text: there is no pulmonary embolism.thoracic aorta is normal in caliber and contour throughout.there is heavy atherosclerotic calcified and noncalcified plaque throughout the visualized aorta, most prominent in the arch, and descending aorta, where there is mild-to-moderate luminal narrowing.heart is moderately enlarged.there is three-vessel coronary artery calcification.there is a stent in the right coronary artery.central airways are patent to the subsegmental level.there are multiple mildly enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes at multiple stations, with a conglomerate of multiple small lymph nodes in the subcarinal region measuring approximately 3.5 x 1.5 cm.there is a large right pleural effusion, with associated near complete collapse of the right lower lobe probably due to passive compression.there is a smaller, moderate sized left pleural effusion, and mild associated left basilar atelectasis.there is moderately severe apical predominant emphysema, with findings consistent with superimposed pulmonary edema including septal thickening, and areas of increased ground-glass attenuation.there is no focal consolidation.there is no pulmonary nodule or mass.this study is not specifically tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation.limited views of the upper abdomen demonstrate a low-attenuation 1.8-cm nodule in the left adrenal gland, most consistent with adenoma.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism.mild hydrostatic pulmonary edema.bilateral pleural effusions, large on the right, and small to moderate on the left.right lower lobe atelectasis related to the effusion.atherosclerosis.emphysema.probable left adrenal adenoma.findings discussed via telephone with dr.___ at 15:30 on ___.

text: there is no evidence of pulmonary embolus.there is extensive ground-glass opacification of the lungs bilaterally involving all lobes of both lungs, but asymmetrically worse on the left.in addition to ground-glass opacification, there is thickening of the interlobular septae.there are small-to-moderate pleural effusions bilaterally.there is mediastinal adenopathy with mild enlargement of pretracheal, paratracheal, subcarinal, and right hilar lymph nodes.the largest of these lymph nodes is in the subcarinal region and measures 2 cm in short axis diameter.no evidence of axillary lymphadenopathy.the upper abdomen is included in the field of view.this demonstrates no new liver lesions.there is hypoattenuation adjacent to falciform ligament, compatible with fatty infiltration.the adrenal glands are normal.the spleen is normal.the visualized portion of the kidneys is normal.there is evidence of recent whipple's procedure.there is some pancreatic calcification compatible with chronic pancreatitis.there is a right upper quadrant surgical drain in situ.postoperative changes are seen in the anterior abdomen.there is a small lesion in the right humeral head measuring 1 cm in diameter and compatible with an enchondroma.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolus.bilateral extensive reticular and ground-glass infiltration in all lobes of both lungs, but asymmetrically worse the left.the acute onset of this appearance compared to prior ct and comparing recent chest radiographs with prior radiographs are compatible with an acute process such as ards, drug reaction, viral infection, aspiration or fluid overload.mediastinal lymphadenopathy, which is likely reactive.right proximal humerus enchondroma.report phoned to dr.___ ___ at 6:20 p.m.on ___.

text: an endotracheal tube terminating 5 cm above the carina and bilateral internal jugular catheter terminating in the mid svc are noted.scattered mediastinal nodes do not meet ct size criteria for enlargement.there is no axillary lymphadenopathy.there are small bilateral pleural effusions with associated atelectasis.the lungs are otherwise clear, without evidence of pulmonary nodule or mass.the pulmonary arteries and airways are patent to the segmental level.there is no evidence of pulmonary embolus.
summary: minimal residual enhancing pancreatic tissue compared to ct of ___ when a pancreas of normal bulk appeared to be enhancing.this suggests diffuse pancreatic necrosis.extensive peripancreatic stranding without defined fluid collection.no free air or abscess.long segment of splenic vein narrowing without evidence of thrombosis.no varices.moderate splenomegaly.diffuse anasarca and trace ascites.hypodense band-like short lesions in segment v liver are of indeterminate etiology or significance, but mat relate to prior trauma.findings were discussed in person with dr.___ at the time of dictation.

text: central lymph nodes are not pathologically enlarged, ranging up to 11 mm in the subcarinal station, 13 mm wide in ___.moderate non-hemorrhagic pericardial effusion largely anterior, is new.there is no pleural effusion.the study is not designed for subdiaphragmatic evaluation, which warrants dedicated abdominal imaging when indicated.emphysema is moderate-to-severe in the upper lungs, milder elsewhere.5-mm nodule deep in the left upper lobe, 3:18, is unchanged since ___, but was 9 x 10 mm two years earlier on ___, therefore presumably an active inflammatory lesion at that time and subsequently a scar.a 20 x 25 mm severely spiculated somewhat heterogeneous soft tissue lesion in the left lower lobe, 4:127-141, is traversed by mildly dilated bronchi.it measured 19x24 mm on ___, but may be less radiodense today.the lesion was not present on ___.if it is malignant and developed over the course of the previous 15-month interval, i would have expected continued progression over the last two months.lesion should be accessible via transthoracic needle aspiration for histologic analysis rather than to presume it is malignant just by virtue of its shape and radiodensity.if it is malignant it is far more likely to be a primary bronchogenic carcinoma than a metastasis.
summary: left lower lobe lesion may be less radiodense compared to ___, and not present 15 months before that could be an inflammatory lesion such as cryptogenic organizing pneumonia.transthoracic needle aspiration should be feasible to exclude malignancy.moderate-to-severe emphysema.small pericardial effusion.no pleural effusion.severe atherosclerotic calcification, involving coronaries.

text: the airways are patent to the segmental levels, bilaterally.there is a moderately sized right-sided pleural effusion with hounsfield units around 14 consistent with simple fluid and a small on the left.associated compressive atelectases are seen on the right.the right lung demonstrate multiple patchy opacities in the periphery of the base.the right and left atrium are severely dilated.the ventricles appear normal in size.patient is status post tricuspid valve replacement.sternotomy wires are noted.surgical clips are seen in the superior mediastinum.there is tiny amount of free air within the anterior mediastinum probably related to recent surgery.the aorta and pulmonary artery are unremarkable.no evidence of mediastinal, hilar or axillary lymphadenopathy.prominent lymph nodes are noted within the left axilla, not pathologically enlarged by ct criteria.no evidence of pneumothorax.small amount of pericardial effusion is seen.images of the superior abdomen demonstrate dilated ivc, small hiatal hernia.
summary: status post tricuspid valve replacement.moderately sized right-sided pleural effusion with compressive atelectasis and a small pleural effusion on the left.patchy opacities within the periphery of the right lung base may represent atelectasis and ground-glass opacities may represent asymmetric pulmonary edema.infectious process cannot be excluded.no evidence of pneumothorax or hemothorax.

text: the previously reported right upper lobe mass has increased cavitation but has not significantly changed in size.patchy infiltrates have developed in the right upper lobe primarily inferior to the lesion and also in the superior segment of the right lower lobe.air bronchograms and some consolidation are present.in the appropriate clinical setting, these findings may represent pneumonia.a minimal right pleural effusion has developed.right hilar adenopathy is again noted.the left lung is free of infiltrate.post-operative changes compatible with old median sternotomy are noted.a pacemaker lead descends into the right ventricle.coronary artery calcifications are again noted.
summary: no pulmonary embolus identified.right lung infiltrates may represent pneumonia in the appropriate clinical setting.clinical correlation is recommended.small right pleural effusion.cavitary right upper lobe mass not significantly changed in size.

text: atelectasis at the right lung base is noted, likely secondary to marked elevation of the right hemidiaphragm.minimal atelectasis is also noted at the left lung base.the lungs are otherwise clear.the heart and great vessels are notable for a bovine arch as well as atherosclerotic vascular calcification at the aortic annulus, coronary arteries as well as aorta.there is no mediastinal or axillary lymphadenopathy by ct size criteria, though note is made of a borderline 9-mm left axillary node (2:28).
summary: elevated right hemidiaphragm as detailed on radiograph with associated right lung atelectasis.this finding may represent paralysis of the right hemidiaphragm in the appropriate setting.air/fluid collection in the expected location of the uterus.can not exclude this being intra-uterine.if concern exists clinically for infectious uterine process, would recommend further evaluation with pelvic u/s.extensive atherosclerotic vascular calcification.innumerable bilateral renal cysts.marked spinal degenerative change as detailed above.findings and recommendations posted to the ed dashboard and discussed over the telephone by dr.___ with dr.___ ___ at ~2:25pm on ___.

text: non-contrast evaluation displays no evidence of intramural hematoma and a mild amount of calcified atherosclerotic disease within the aorta and left coronary circulation.there is no evidence of aortic dissection or pulmonary embolism to the segmental level.some of the segmental branches were difficult to evaluate due to breathing artifact.there are bilateral simple pleural effusions, moderate on the right and small on the left without evidence of empyema resulting in adjacent compression atelectasis within the lower lobes bilaterally.the lungs display biapical pleural scarring and scattered regions of ground-glass opacity likely representing microatelectasis, but no suspicious nodules or regions of consolidation.the interstitial septa are not thickened and the airways are patent to the subsegmental level.limited evaluation of the upper abdomen, note this patient to be status post cholecystectomy with extrahepatic biliary dilatation.a small 6-mm hypoattenuating lesion is noted within the right lobe (3:90) with an additional few foci of ill- defined hyperenhancing nodule lesions, 4 mm in the left lobe and right lobe (3:97).incidentally detected is a calcified/thrombosed splenic artery aneurysm.
summary: no evidence of aortic dissection or pulmonary embolism.moderate simple right effusion and small simple left effusion with adjacent compression atelectasis.small arterial enhancing and hypoattenuating hepatic lesions as described above are of uncertain clinical significance, but likely benign.in absence of any known malignancy, this can be further evaluated with a dedicated mri on a non-emergent basis if clinically warranted.slightly prominent extrahepatic common duct measuring approximately 15 mm.this is of uncertain clinical significance in this elderly patient status post cholecystectomy.please correlate with lfts.if concern for biliary pathology, a dedicated ercp or mrcp can be performed.

text: once again, there is consolidation within the right lower lobe which does not appear to be significantly changed in the interval.there is no pleural effusion.the heart and great vessels appear grossly normal.note is made of the large hiatal hernia.
summary: persistent right lower lobe consolidation.chronic inflammatory changes involving the distal sigmoid and upper rectum of uncertain etiology.associated with this is a soft tissue structure within the lumen of the rectum which may represent chronic retained stool versus a villous adenoma.a sigmoidoscopy is recommended for further evaluation of both of these findings.there is no evidence of a perirectal or perianal abscess.

text: paraseptal and centrilobular emphysema present predominantly in the upper lobes bilaterally.there is biapical pleural parenchymal scarring.minimal peribronchiolar opacities are present involving the lateral aspect of the left upper lobe and right middle lobe.findings are consistent with nonspecific mild bronchiolitis.there is no focal infiltrate or mass.central airways are patent.subcentimeter mediastinal and right hilar lymph nodes are present.there is no pleural effusion.
summary: paraseptal and centrilobular emphysema.no focal lung mass.nodular liver consistent with cirrhosis without evidence of liver mass.no enlarged retroperitoneal or pelvic lymph nodes or other evidence of metastases.

text: the pulmonary arterial tree is entirely normal.the previous small upper mediastinal hematoma has shrunk from 15 x 27 mm at the level of its greatest girth to about half its previous area, 2:26.although mediastinal lymph nodes are not grossly enlarged, virtually all visible nodes have grown, for example in the right lower paratracheal station, two nodes, 6 x 17 mm in aggregate on ___ are 10 x 21 mm today.the bronchocentric pulmonary abnormality which by conventional radiographs accelerated dramatically between ___ and today consists of both peribronchial infiltration and small nodular areas of consolidation, for example in the anterior segment of the left upper lobe, 2:37, 41, 42.there is also a generalized background abnormality of ground-glass opacification with septal thickening, more pronounced inferiorly, which is probably concurrent pulmonary edema.large areas of both lower lobes are densely atelectatic, but the bronchial tree is patent except for a small amount of secretions pooling in the mid and lower trachea.maximum cardiac diameter has increased from 124 to 133 mm.there is no pericardial effusion.a moderate volume of new bilaterial nonhemorrhagic pleural effusion layers posteriorly.the study is not designed for subdiaphragmatic evaluation except to note the resolution of previous perihepatic blood.at comparable levels, the enlarged right adrenal gland, previously 25 x 20 mm is 20 x 30 mm.although this could be a hematoma, as previously diagnosed, i following this abnormality with ultrasound to exclude an incidentally discovered mass.
summary: no pulmonary embolism.widespread severe bronchocentric pulmonary abnormality could be pneumonia or atypical fat embolism syndrome, alternatively drug reaction, but unlikely pulmonary hemorrhage.mild pulmonary edema could be related to volume overload given interval increase in heart size and new moderate nonhemorrhagic bilateral pleural effusion.decreasing, isolated small upper mediastinal hematoma.suggest followup to distinguish stable adrenal hematoma from incidentally discovered adrenal mass.

text: the soft tissue windows demonstrate no significant axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymphadenopathy.the heart and great vessels are normal in appearance.specifically, the thoracic aorta is normal in appearance.the mediastinal fat does not demonstrate evidence for hemorrhage.noted is residual thymus.there is no pericardial effusion.the lung windows demonstrate bilateral dependent atelectasis.no alveolar consolidation is appreciated worrisome for pulmonary contusion.tiny collections of air are noted bilaterally in the pleural space, with no associated soft tissue injury.these are presumably related to the mechanism of injury and are of uncertain significance.
summary: small splenic laceration without intra-abdominal free fluid.bibasilar dependent atelectasis.tiny air collections in pleural spaces bilaterally, not associated with adjacent soft tissue injury.their significance is uncertain and they most likely relate to the mechanism of injury.

text: there is no evidence of pulmonary embolism or aortic dissection.multiple areas of airspace disease with peribronchial hazy nodules are seen in all lobes of the right lung, the lingula and left lower lobe.there is more confluent opacity with volume loss in the dependent portions of the lung primarily the lower lobes.this is consistent with multifocal pneumonia.no lymphadenopathy by size criteria.although this exam was not optimized for cardiac diagnosis, the heart is unremarkable with trace pericardial effusion.there is no central or axillary lymphadenopathy.an endotracheal tube is noted with its tip 1.5 cm above the carina.although this exam was not optimized for subdiaphragmatic diagnosis, the imaged abdominal organs are unremarkable.
summary: no pe.multifocal pneumonia, worse in the right lung, with a peribronchial distribution.dependent atelectasis.

text: a left port-a-cath is present with the tip terminating in the right atrium.coronary artery and aortic valve calcifications are again noted.calcified mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes are stable.there are no pathologically enlarged lymph nodes within the axilla, mediastinum, and hilum.overall, the lungs appear stable with the exception of a focal area of improved/decreased opacity within the left lingula now with residual interstitial opacities, which are not well characterized given respiratory motion.the previously seen multiple sub 5 mm non-calcified pulmonary nodules are all stable in size and appearance.a calcified granuloma within the right lower lobe periphery is also unchanged.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism.stable tiny pulmonary nodules.improving left lingular opacity representing either improved infectious or inflammatory etiology.non-visualized liver lesions, likely due to differences in phase of contrast.stable extensive metastatic bone disease.

text: no evidence of acute traumatic thoracic injury.there is moderate-sized pleural effusion noted on the right with attenuation value of 13.there is associated atelectasis of the right lung base.dependent atelectatic changes are noted in the left lung base.no evidence of pneumothorax.the airways are patent upto the subsegmental levels.the heart is moderately enlarged with associated calcification of the coronary arteries and mitral valve annulus.there is atheromatous calcification involving the ascending,arch and descending thoracic aorta.no significant mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy detected.
summary: no acute intrathoracic or intraabdominal traumatic injury.moderate right pleural effusion with associated atelectasis.two small hyperenhancing liver lesions, could represent flash-filling hemangiomas/fnh.multiple left renal cortical cysts.cholelithiasis without evidence of cholecystitis.

text: there is no evidence of definite pulmonary embolism.there are bilateral large pleural effusions associated with compressive atelectasis of the bilateral lower lobes.there is a large hiatal hernia.the heart and great vessels are unremarkable.there is no significant axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymph node enlargement.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism.large bilateral pleural effusions associated with compressive atelectasis of the lower lobes.large hiatal hernia.

text: the patient is intubated with the endotracheal tube terminating ~ 4.7 cm cranial to the carina.airways are patent to subsegmental levels bilaterally.the lungs are hyperexpanded bilaterally with emphysematous change, most notably at the lower lungs.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.opacity at the left lung base bears a honeycombing appearance.the lingula is notable for a peripheral, pleural abutting, 2.2 x 1.3 cm nodule (2:31).immediately caudal to this is a poorly delineated area of tree-in-___ and ground-glass opacity, which may represent an infection in the appropriate clinical context.otherwise, the lungs are clear.the heart and great vessels are notable for atherosclerotic calcification at the coronaries as well as at the aortic annulus and in the aorta.there is no mediastinal or axillary lymphadenopathy.post-contrast images show normal opacification of the pulmonary arterial system without evidence of pulmonary embolism.there is no evidence of aortic dissection.ng tube courses into the stomach and beyond the field of view.limited assessment of the intra- abdominal contents is unremarkable.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism or dissection.nodule at the lingula as detailed above.recommend comparison with prior imaging of the chest if available, and in its absence, this finding needs clinical correlation for possible malignancy and close 3month followup.small collection of tree-in-___ and ground-glass opacity on the left may represent an infectious process in the appropriate clinical context.

text: no filling defect is noted within the main pulmonary artery and its branches to suggest pulmonary embolism.however evaluation of the subsegmental braches is limited due to atelectasis.the heart has normal appearance.no pericardial effusion is noted.no pathologically enlarged central lymphadenopathy including mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymph nodes are visualized.moderate to severe left malignant pleural effusion is noted.thyroid contains a nodule in the right lobe.the lung windows demonstrate complete collapse of the left lower lobe and the inferior part of the lingula.the right lung is clear with no focal consolidation, pulmonary nodule or parenchymal opacification.minor atelectatic changes are noted at the right lung base.the visualized portion of the upper abdomen demonstrates normal appearance of the liver, spleen, and the left adrenal gland appears normal.moderate amount of ascites is noted within the abdomen.incidental note is also made of omental caking within the anterior abdomen.
summary: no pulmonary embolism.evaluation of the subsegmental branches of the left lower lung is limited due to lung collapse.large malignant left pleural effusion and complete collapse of the left lower lobe and the inferior portion of the lingula.moderate ascites and omental caking .

text: consistent with the given history, there is an apically directed right chest tube which gains intrathoracic access laterally between the fifth and sixth ribs.the sidehole is at the apex and the distal tip is deviated anteriorly and is directed toward the anterior right second rib.there is residual pneumothorax both in the basilar aspect and anteriorly to the apex.large preexisting emphysematous blebs are noted throughout both lungs, particularly at the apices.there is marked thickening of the visceral pleura, particularly involving the right middle lobe.extensive consolidation is seen of the right lower lobe with areas of hypoattenuation suggestive of necrosis.slightly less confluent opacification is noted in the posterior segment and apical segment of the right upper lobe.there is a small amount of layering fluid within the right hemithorax; however, no organized wall or other features to suggest underlying empyema is noted.given the extensive consolidation, it is difficult to assess for underlying nodules or masses.there is a relatively patchy peripheral and triangular-shaped consolidation in the left lower lobe, principally involving the lateral basal segment.smaller bronchovascularly redistributed opacities are noted in the superior segment of the left lower lobe and the posterior segment of the left upper lobe.a dense well-defined nodule is noted in the apical segment of the left upper lobe, reference series 2, image #12.a lobulated nodule approximately 6 mm in diameter is noted in the superior lingula, reference series 2, image #26.no right pneumothorax is seen.along with the centrilobular emphysema seen, there is extensive paraseptal emphysema at the extreme apices as well.there is an ill-defined hypoattenuated lesion centrally within the right thyroid lobe.the aorta is normal in contour, caliber and course.scattered calcified plaque is seen.the heart is normal in size with no pericardial effusion.the right hilum is difficult to assess.no gross mediastinal adenopathy is seen.the thoracic trachea is widely patent.no endoluminal lesion is noted.the esophagus images normally.limited imaging of the included upper abdomen reveals ill-defined hypoattenuated lesions in the liver which are incompletely evaluated given phase of contrast administration.included ribs are intact without fracture or suspicious osseous lesion.a bone island is evident in the left aspect of the t11 vertebral body.subcutaneous air is noted throughout the left chest wall consistent with recent chest tube placement.there is no extension of fluid or abscess noted.
summary: per clinical concern for empyema, there is minimal layering fluid within the right hemithorax without organization or enhancing walls to suggest underlying empyema.there are dense consolidations, worse in the right lower lobe with central areas of hypoattenuation and air which are most compatible with necrotizing pneumonia.multifocal pneumonia is suspected with extensive patchy opacities also noted in the right upper, left upper and left lower lobes.only the consolidation of the right lower lobe demonstrates areas of necrosis.given the distribution, aspiration is a consideration.persistent right pneumothorax with indwelling chest tube.chest tube course as described above.there is baseline pneumonia.no significant mediastinal shift is seen to suggest recurrence of tension physiology.marked visceral pleural thickening, particularly of the lower right hemithorax.this is of indeterminate etiology or chronicity.this could be related to underlying infection.given the lack of parietal pleural thickening or other abnormality, malignancy is felt less likely but is not excluded.

text: the soft tissue windows demonstrate no significant axillary or hilar lymphadenopathy.a 14 mm precarinal lymph node is identified of unclear etiology.the contrast bolus was optimally timed for evaluation of pulmonary arteries.no intraluminal filling defect is identified suggesting pulmonary embolus.there is a large left and moderate right-sided pleural effusion with associated passive atelectasis.there is no pericardial effusion.the lung windows demonstrate passive atelectasis and consolidation most prominent at the lower lobes associated with these pleural effusions.a tiny well marginated 2 mm pulmonary nodule is identified within the lateral segment of the right middle lobe.this likely represents a noncalcified granuloma, however if concern for neoplasm exists, this could be followed at three months to ensure size stability.there is diffuse paraseptal and centrilobular emphysema.there is also bullous disease prominent at the apices.an endotracheal tube is present approximately 3 cm above the carina.an enteric tube is seen proceeding down the esophagus.the airways are patent to the level of the segmental bronchi.
summary: no pulmonary embolus.cardiomegaly without failure.large left and moderate right-sided pleural effusion with associated passive atelectasis/consolidation most prominent at the lower lobes.tiny 2 mm sized pulmonary nodule located in the lateral segment of the right middle lobe that could represent a noncalcified granuloma but if concern for neoplasm exists, ct could be performed at three months to ensure size stability.paraseptal and centrilobular emphysema with bullous disease prominent at the apices.

text: ct chest with iv contrast: pulmonary arteries are patent with no intraluminal filling defects noted.no axillary or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.heart and aorta appear unremarkable.there is a small amount of air in the mediastinum and thoracic cavity which appears slightly reduced in volume in the interval since the last study.right-sided chest tube is seen and appears to be well placed.drain placed in the mediastinum exits the right chest and appears unchanged from previous study.bilateral pleural effusions are still observed with the volume of the effusion in the right hemithorax greatly reduced; the left hemithorax contains a greater amount of pleural effusion which is moderately reduced as compared to the last study.bilateral atelectasis associated with pleural effusion has resolved partially since last study.there appears to be no evidence of pneumonia in the lung fields visualized.partially fluid-filed stomach and remaining esophagus is visualized with no evidence of leakage.
summary: improving pleural effusion, pneumomediastinum and pneumothorax as compared to previous study.no evidence of pneumonic process/evidence of pneumonia.no evidence of lymphadenopathy in the visualized areas.all tubes and lines appear well placed and unchanged from previous study.no obvious foci of infection.area of reduced perfusion in left lobe of liver may reflect sequelae from retraction.

text: there is a central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein, terminating at the cavoatrial junction.there is a small 7 mm filling defect next to the tip of the catheter (2:23), could be a small thrombus, less likely artefact.the heart size is normal.there is a trace pericardial effusion.there is interval decrease in size of lymph nodes compared to prior ct, and no evidence of pathologically enlarged lymph nodes according to ct size criteria in the mediastinum, hilum, or axilla.the lungs are clear, with mild atelectasis at the left lung base.there is no pleural effusion, or pneumothorax.previously described 3-mm nodules not appreciated on today's study.there is a 2-mm lll subpleural nodular opacity, (2:19), not seen on prior, could be a focal atelectasis.
summary: wall edema and hyperemia of the mid transverse colon through the sigmoid suggestive of colitis, most likely inflammatory or infectious, less likely ischemic.interval decrease in mediastinal, hilar, and retroperitoneal lymph nodes.new small scattered mesenteric lymph nodes, non-specific, could be reactive.small non-occlusive filling defect in the svc near tip of the catheter could be a small thrombus, less likely artefact.d/w dr.___ ___.

text: the lungs are clear, with mild dependent atelectasis, but no consolidation, pneumothorax or pleural effusion.the tracheobronchial tree is patent to subsegmental levels.the heart size is normal, without pericardial effusion.great vessels are unremarkable.there is no hilar or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.
summary: non-displaced rib fractures in the left anterolateral ribs 4 through 2.no other acute abnormalities are present.moderate degenerative changes in the thoracolumbar spine.

text: there is no axillary lymphadenopathy.there is diffuse soft tissue density within the mediastinum.several more discrete soft tissue densities are present wihtin the mediastinum with the largest in the precarinal region, measuring 1.3 x 3.1 cm.this precarinal density demonstrates mass effect with indentation of the anterior wall of the trachea.secretions are present within the trachea.the patient is status post pneumonectomy with rightward shift of the mediastinum and fluid filled right thorax.there are several septations seen within the fluid.an irregular calcified density is present along the posterior right thorax extending into the mediastinum.this appears to connect to a posterior rib and likely represents heterotopic bone formation.there is a small pericardial effusion.the heart is not enlarged.there is a sub centimeter pericardial lymph node which was not present on the prior study.there is moderate emphysema in the left lung.hyperexpansion of the left lung is present consistent with prior right pneumonectomy.minimal left lower lobe centrilobular opacities are present.a more focal irregular density is present along the medial left lower lobe.the airways of the left lung are patent.intra and extrahepatic ductal dilatation is present.the common bile duct measures up to 1 cm.the common bile duct at the level of the head of the pancreas is incompletely evaluated.there is no pancreatic ductal dilatation.the other visualized upper abdominal organs are unremarkable.no suspicious lytic or sclerotic changes are present.there are post operative changes within the posterior right upper ribs.there is a fracture in the right posterior ninth rib and possibly in the eighth rib.no callus formation is present, suggesting acute or subacute fractures.there is a small amount of perihepatic fluid.

text: the heart size is enlarged with severe coronary artery disease and calcification of the aortic valve.atherosclerotic calcifications are also noted in the aorta.there is extensive pulmonary embolism involving all segments of the right lung.the appearance of the thrombi is most consistent with acute pulmonary embolism.there is no radiographic evidence of right heart strain.there are also no filling defects in the visualized ivc to suggest extension of renal cell carcinoma as a cause for pulmonary embolism.visualization of the lungs is limited by motion artifact; images were obtained during expiratory phase.there is suggestion of several centrilobular and other pulmonary nodules that cannot be further evaluated on the current study.there is also moderate-to-large right and small-to-moderate left simple, layering pleural effusion with associated atelectasis.there is also left greater than right subpulmonic effusion.no mediastinal or axillary lymphadenopathy is noted.very limited views of the upper abdomen are unremarkable.there is an old healed fracture of the left lateral fifth rib.there are no regions of bone destruction suspicious for metastasis.

text: there is no mediastinal, axillary, or hilar lymphadenopathy.there is no pneumomediastinum.minimal residual thymic tissue is evident.the aorta is normal in course and caliber.the heart is within normal limits for size.there is no pericardial effusion.the main pulmonary artery is within normal limits for size.there are no filling defects in the pulmonary arterial tree to suggest pulmonary embolism.there is minimal fibrosis versus scarring at the lateral aspect of the right lung base with an elevated right hemidiaphragm.this is relatively constant across multiple prior studies.no consolidation, edema, effusion, or pneumothorax is evident.the large bilateral pleural effusions previously noted have completely resolved.there is an indwelling central venous catheter from a right subclavian approach.the distal tip is obscured by contrast but is likely within the superior vena cava.the visualized osseous structures are unremarkable.

text: patient is status post ascending aorta repair, with surgical graft visualized in the aortic root and multiple surgical clips surrounding the surgically repaired ascending aorta.there remains an extensive type a dissection involving the aortic arch and into the brachiocephalic artery without involvement of the other great vessels.the dissection courses inferiorly to the most inferior aspect imaged at the iliac bifurcation.the airway is patent to the segmental level.the lungs are clear with the exception of mild bibasilar atelectasis and pleural thickening.diffuse nodular thyroid.no pathologically enlarge lymph nodes in the mediastinum.there is not optimal opacification of the coronary arteries, however, the main branches appear patent without demonstrable dissection or atherosclerotic disease.there is an artificial aortic valve.heart is moderately enlarged.
summary: status post thoracic aorta repair, with persisting extensive type a aortic dissection extending superiorly into the brachiocephalic artery and extending inferiorly to the level of the common iliac arteries, the most inferior aspect imaged on this study.all of the abdominal arterial branches with the exception of the right renal artery are fed by the true lumen and are patent without occlusion or dissection.no evidence of organ infarction.status post aortic valve replacement.cholelithiasis without evidence of cholecystitis.suboptimal opacification of the coronary arteries which appear patent on the source images.an addendum will be added after 3d volume and mip reconstructions are available.

text: when compared with the prior study, there has been increased geographic consolidation in association with traction bronchiectasis consistent with evolving radiation changes.this area of radiation fibrosis is distributed in a bandlike pattern in the region of the superior segments of the lower lobes.again seen at the bases bilaterally right-worse-than-left are smoothly- thickened septal lines.when compared with the prior study this thickening appears slightly more pronounced.there is a new right small pleural effusion with a small amount of fluid additionally within the fissures bilaterally.there are no discrete pulmonary nodules or masses.no endobronchial lesions are seen.when compared with the prior study there has been no significant interval change in a right paratracheal lymph node with a punctate area of calcification which measures approximately 12 mm x 12 mm.there has been some interval reduction in size of a subcarinal lymph node conglomerate.there is extensive atherosclerotic disease of the thoracic aorta which is non- aneurysmal.the trachea is "saber-sheathed".there is mild centrilobular emphysema within the apices.there has not been a significant interval change in the esophagus.the upper abdomen is visualized.within the medial segment of the left lobe of the liver, again seen is a lobulated hypodense lesion which is unchanged in size and shape and likely represents a cyst or hemangioma.there is a vague hypodense lesion within the right lobe of the liver which was not as clearly seen on prior study.this is seen best on image 54 of series 5.two smaller hypodense lesions within the right lobe of the liver are not as clearly identified on this current study.there is an ill-defined hypodense lesion with suggestions of some peripheral enhancement within the spleen measuring approximately 14 x 18 mm with some contour abnormality.this was not clearly seen on the prior study.additionally, there is an approximately 10-mm x 10- mm exophytic cyst off the upper pole of the left kidney that is slightly hyperdense which is unchanged from the prior study.there is stable fullness of the left adrenal gland.
summary: there has been interval evolution of radiation fibrosis in the central, perihilar regions of the lungs .there is slight worsening of thickening of septal lines at the bases, right worse than left.this is nonspecific and may represent interstitial edema or drug toxicity.involvement from lymphoma is considered less likely, as there has been general improvement in the mediastinal lymphadenopathy.there is new small right pleural effusion.there are multiple hypodense lesions within the liver.at least one of these lesions within the right lobe was not clearly identified on the prior study.two small lesions seen on the prior study are not currently identified.these apparent differences may be related to differences in phase of contrast additionally, there is a hypodense lesion within the spleen.it is uncertain whether this is indeed new or it was not previously visible secondary to differences in phase of contrast between the current and prior study.lymphomatous involvement cannot be excluded and an ultrasound could be performed to better evaluate the spleen.there is likely a hyperdense cyst involving the left kidney which is unchanged from the prior study.

text: there is a diffuse ground-glass opacity within the lungs with interstitial thickening consistent with pulmonary edema also noting the presence of right greater than left small pleural effusion.no pulmonary nodules are appreciated.there is some scarring in the right middle lobe.there is also some scarring in the left lower lobe in the superior aspect.evaluation of the thoracic vasculature demonstrates an anomalous pulmonary vein which drains into the svc from the right upper lobe.no other anomalous pulmonary veins are seen.in conjunction with this finding is noted massive enlargement of the right atrium which may be on the basis of volume effects.there are multiple small mediastinal lymph nodes which all appear to be less than 1 cm in short axis.limited evaluation of the upper abdomen demonstrate findings suggestive of sclerosis of the liver with ascites surrounding both the liver and the spleen.
summary: anomalous pulmonary vein draining the right upper lobe in conjunction with findings of pulmonary edema and massive enlargement of the right atrium.

text: the infiltrates seen on comparison chest x-ray correspond with moderately large bilateral nonhemorrhagic, layering pleural effusions, with bibasilar compressive atelectasis.no non-calcified nodules or masses are detected.isolated calcified granulomas (102a/12) suggest prior granulomatous infection.there is no mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy.heart, pericardium, and great vessels are normal in appearance.no pericardial effusion.imaging of the upper abdomen is not sufficient for diagnosis but demonstrates moderate intra-abdominal ascites, not significantly changed since ___.focal nodular thickening within the area of the stomach body is again noted.

text: the heart and great vessels are unremarkable.there are scattered mediastinal and axillary lymph nodes, which do not meet the ct criteria for pathologic enlargement.clips are seen in the mediastinum.chain sutures are seen in the right upper lobe and there is adjacent scarring.the patient is status post wedge resection of right upper lobe nodules.the previously seen right upper lobe nodule is no longer seen, and there are now faint ground glass opacities at that location.the left upper lobe nodule measures 2.5 x 1.4 cm and previously measured 2.5 x 1.6 cm.there is a moderate-sized right pleural effusion.

text: large, necrotic mass in the right upper lobe has increased in size from 9.2 x 6.5 cm to 9.6 x 7.1 cm (image 20, series 2).the mass extends laterally to the peripheral pleural surface and centrally to right hilum resulting in splaying of the right upper lobe anterior and posterior segmental bronchi.persistent bulky necrotic lymph nodes involving multiple mediastinal compartments as well as right hilar and right supraclavicular nodal stations.direct comparison of measurements of the lymph nodes between the pet-ct and current ct is somewhat limited due to absence of contrast on 2), up to 1.8 cm in the lower right paratracheal region, 1.6 cm in the right hilar region and 1.4 cm in the right supraclavicular region.a large pericardial effusion has increased in size from the prior pet-ct and is associated with slight flattening of the right atrial contour.diffuse coronary artery calcifications are again visualized.diffuse interstitial thickening in the right upper lobe is fissures.along its superolateral margin there is some adjacent nodular pleural thickening present.although no definite bone destruction is identified.there is effacement of the intercostal fat which could potentially indicate early chest wall invasion.dependent nodular opacities posteriorly at right lung base are new since the prior pet-ct and potentially due to nodular atelectasis.the large pericardial effusion is associated with adjacent atelectasis in the lingula and medial segment right middle lobe.the exam was not specifically tailored to evaluate the subdiaphragmatic region, but note is made of previous left nephrectomy procedure.nodular thickening of left adrenal gland is without change in appearance since the recent pet-ct.within the right kidney, small hyperdense cyst in text: there are aortic arch calcifications.there is no pericardial effusion.there is a single enlarged right paratracheal lymph node measuring 1.4 x 1.4 cm.small amount of fluid is noted in the pericardial recess.there is no significant mediastinal adenopathy.subcentimeter subcarinal nodes are noted and unchanged since the prior study.there is good contrast opacification of the central, lobar and segmental pulmonary vessels without evidence of pulmonary embolism.lung windows demonstrate marked interval worsening of interstitial and ground glass opacities bilaterally.given rapid interval progression, it favors acute etiology such as pulmonary edema over lymphangitic tumor spread.there are multiple pulmonary nodules, unchanged since the prior study, consistent with metastatic disease as described below.the large right upper lobe spiculated nodule measures 1 x 9 mm compared to prior similar measurement (3:14).the second more inferior right middle lobe nodules are also unchanged measuring 4 and 5 mm respectively (3:31).a more inferior right middle lobe lateral segment nodule measures 5 mm, unchanged.there are multiple other nodules, the accurate measurements of which is limited due to overlying airspace opacities.a large left lower lobe nodule measures 1.7 x 2.1 cm (3:43) compared to prior comparative measurements of 2.1 x 1.6 cm.there is a spiculated 9.9 mm right lower lobe nodule (3:55) unchanged since the prior study.there are new, bilateral pleural effusions.there is bibasilar compressive atelectasis.

text: 64-row mdct was performed from the thoracic inlet to the base of the lung following the administration of 130 ml of optiray intravenous contrast.the patient is intubated and the endotracheal tube is in adequate position.tip of a central line is at the junction of the innominate vein and svc.there are several preaortic and pretracheal nodes which are borderline in size and unchanged since the prior study.there is extensive coronary artery calcification as well as calcification of the aortic arch.there are bilateral pleural effusions, right greater than left, which have increased slightly since the prior study.there are diffuse emphysematous changes in the upper lobes.there are associated pulmonary opacities in the anterior aspect of the left upper lobe as well as in the dependent portions of both aerated lungs, most consistent with atelectasis, although superimposed infection cannot be excluded.there is no pericardial effusion.

text: a thyroid nodule is incompletely imaged but appears unchanged compared to prior examination (7:2).no supraclavicular or axillary lymphadenopathy is identified.a single enlarged mediastinal lymph node appears unchanged in size measuring 12 x 17 mm (7:39).no new pathologically enlarged mediastinal or hilar lymph nodes are identified.moderate cardiomegaly appears unchanged from prior, however, there is no pericardial effusion.moderate coronary atherosclerotic calcifications are also stable.the thoracic aorta is non-aneurysmal throughout its course.no central pulmonary embolism is identified on this portal venous phase study.the pleural surfaces are clear without effusion.the tracheobronchial tree is patent to subsegmental levels.mild paraseptal emphysema appears unchanged.no focal pulmonary nodule or mass is identified.previously visualized ground-glass pulmonary nodules are not clearly seen on the current examination.

text: there are extensive shoddy lymph nodes within the axilla, mediastinum, and hila, without individual significantly enlarged nodes meeting size criteria for pathologic enlargement.in addition, the right lower lobe basilar bronchi are somewhat narrowed, which may be due to aspiration or consolidation, associated with a patchy opacity at the right lung base.there is a more confluent opacity at the left lung base as well, representing pneumonia.there are other multifocal regions of patchy opacity within the superior segment of the right lower lobe, as well as within the right middle lobe, probably also representing other foci of pneumonia on the background of emphysema.there is also a somewhat spiculated 1-cm region at the left lung apex.limited evaluation of the upper abdominal structures demonstrates a tiny amount of ascites.coronally and sagittally reformatted images were also obtained, which demonstrate that the right ij catheter curves into the left brachiocephalic vein.these images also show the opacity of the right svc.

there is no peripancreatic fluid collection.the appearance of the pancreaticojejunal anastomosis is stable.the aorta and iliac vessels demonstrate no evidence of aneurysmal dilatation.there is no lymphadenopathy.the cecum and ascending colon are prominent.the ascending colon measures 6.8 cm in diameter.the cecum measures 9 cm in diameter.the transverse colon measures 5.6 cm in diameter.oral contrast extends to the cecum.there are no dilated loops of small bowel.urinary bladder is distended.uterus and rectum are unremarkable.

text: the lungs are symmetrically expanded without focal airspace consolidation, pneumothorax or pleural effusions.the tracheobronchial tree is patent to the subsegmental levels.a few tiny sub 5 mm pulmonary nodules are noted in the left lower lobe, right upper, and lower lobes, most likely incidental given that these are not widespread, although metastases cannot be excluded.the heart is normal in size without pericardial effusion.coronary artery calcification is noted.the great mediastinal vessels are normal.there is a large hiatal hernia.small mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes are seen.a few are mildly prominent, including a right upper paratracheal node which meaures 14 x 8 mm in axial dimensions, but none are pathologically enlarged by the ct criteria.small bilateral supraclavicular and axillary lymph nodes are also noted.a right pericardial node measures 6 mm.mild gynecomastia is noted.
