text: there is a large expansile left upper lobe consolidation, which may be combination of underlying mass and secondary concurrent post-obstructive left upper lobe and lingular collapse with possible post-obstructive pneumonia, difficult to separate.this process appears to extend into the mediastinum anteriorly and laterally (se2a,im 13 and 25), displacing the trachea to the right.there is massive left supraclavicular and mediastinal conglomerate lymphadenopathy, with splaying of the proximal left subclavian and left common carotid arteries, measuring 5.3 x 3.5 cm in this region for example.a subcarinal nodal mass measures approximately 5.2 x 3.5 cm.left paratracheal nodal conglomerate measures 4.2 x 3.3 cm (se2a, image 27).there is marked attenuation of the left main pulmonary artery and compressive attenuation/occlusion of left upper lobe segmental and subsegmental pulmonary arteries.although not tailored for evaluation of pulmonary embolism, no central pe is identified.there is also postobstructive collapse of the lingula.the left lower lobe remains clear, but with multiple, at least three, additional small pulmonary nodules, largest in subpleural location posteriorly measuring 5 mm (28, 45).the right lung remains aerated, demonstrating apical paraseptal emphysematous changes.multiple, at least three, pulmonary nodules are also present on the right, largest 8 mm in the right lower lobe (28, 56).there is no pleural effusion.the heart is normal in size without pericardial effusion.the aorta is normal in size without acute pathology.limited subdiaphragmatic evaluation demonstrates multiple right renal cysts and no other gross visceral abnormality.
summary: large left upper lobe consolidation which appears to extend into the mediastinum and concurrent post-obstructive left upper lobe and lingular collapse.above findings, in conjunction with massive left supraclavicular and mediastinal lymphadenopathy, raise the concern for underlying mass.complete obstruction of left upper lobe and lingular bronchi could be due to a combination of compression and endobronchial tumor.marked attenuation of the left upper lobe segmental pulmonary arteries.bilateral smaller pulmonary nodules.overall appearance is suspicious for neoplasm, primary lung cancer versus metastasis, also consider lymphoma.post-obstructive pneumonia can not be excluded.recommend correlation with bronchoscopy and tissue sampling.

text: there is no axillary or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.several enlarged left hilar lymph nodes are present and are not significantly changed in the interval, the largest of which measures 30 x 23 mm and previously measured 28 x 22 mm.the previously identified large pleural-based mass in the left lower lobe is unchanged in size or appearance.it currently measures 57 x 39 mm, previously measuring 56 x 39 mm.there are multiple bilateral small pulmonary nodules, which have not increased in size since the prior study, and appear to have actually slightly decreased in size.no pleural effusions or pericardial effusions are present.the major airways are patent.the heart and pericardium are unremarkable.
summary: no change in pleural-based soft tissue mass of the left lung.no change in lymphadenopathy of the left hilum.slight decrease in size of multiple bilateral pulmonary nodules.status post left nephrectomy with soft tissue at the surgical site consistent with postoperative change.right kidney angiomyolipoma, unchanged in appearance.stable appearance of multiple punctate sclerotic foci within the bones.an oncology table has been submitted in ccc.

text: a nasogastric tube terminates within the intrathoracic gastric pull-through distal to the anastomotic site with oral contrast pooling dependently within the intrathoracic stomach.no definite new oral contrast is noted within the tracheobronchial tree to confirm a gastrobronchial fistula.again identified adjacent and slightly superior to the gastroesophageal anastomosis centered within the posterior mediastinum is a 2.9 x 5.0 cm air containing collection with unchanged punctate hyperdensities within it, possibly old barium, which abuts the left main stem bronchus and portion of the left atrium.a large amount of secretions are noted within the proximal and distal bronchi, best appreciated within the left bronchial tree and there is bilateral bronchiectasis involving the right upper lobe and entire left lung.a small slightly hyperdense left pleural effusion is noted and there is bilateral pleural thickening and moderate left basilar atelectasis adjacent to the gastric pull- through.scattered nodular and ground-glass opacities throughout the lung parenchyma with dense right lower lobe consolidation is stable and is mediastinal lymphadenopathy, the largest nodal conglomerate within the subcarinal chain measuring 19 x 26 mm.atherosclerotic disease within the intrathoracic aorta and cranial circulation is stable as is prominent superior pericardial recess.there has been interval removal of a right-sided central venous catheter, and placement of a left- sided central venous catheter, which terminates within the mid svc.endotracheal tube remains in standard position.small pericardial effusion persists inferiorly.
summary: no definite gastrobronchial fistula identified.this cannot be excluded by ct examination and could be further evaluated with dedicated barium swallow once patient is able to tolerate.evaluation is also limited on todays exam due to oral contrast instillation through a nasogastric tube, which passes distal of the gastroesophageal anastomosis where the leak is suspected.air containing collection within the medial posterior mediastinum adjacent to the gastroesophageal anastomosis is unchanged in size and appearance and is most suggestive of a mediastinal abscess or phlegmon.leak at the anastomosis should be considered.large amount of secretions within the left main stem bronchus with diffuse pulmonary parenchymal opacities (predomintly within the rll), most suggestive of underlying aspiration pneumonia.bronchiectasis involving the right upper lobe and entire left lung, likely related to chronic infection/inflammation.rim-enhancing fluid collection within the region of the pancreatic tail is unchanged and most suggestive of a pancreatic pseudocyst.a duplication cyst or a cystic pancreatic tail neoplasm is also within the differential, but felt less likely.colonic diverticulosis without evidence of acute diverticulitis.mild circumferential wall thickening involving the proximal rectum is likely related to underdistension, but should be correlated with prior colonography results or if clinically indicated, repeat colonography.diffuse anasarca.clinical service was informed.

text: the patient is status post right mastectomy and axillary dissection.there are no suspicious axillary or mediastinal lymph nodes.a tiny prevascular lymph node measures 4 mm.there is a small pericardial effusion.the heart and great vessels are otherwise unremarkable.there is a left subclavian port-a-cath with the tip within the cavoatrial junction.there are no pleural effusions.there are several small sub 5-mm subpleural nodules posteriorly likely reflecting dependent changes.some of them are new when compared to prior study and some are unchanged.they are not particularly suspicious for metastasis but attention on followup is recommended.no focal lesions are noted in the liver.the liver, the spleen, kidneys, and pancreas are unremarkable.the right adrenal gland is again noted to be slightly nodular but unchanged when compared to the prior study.the largest nodule within the right limb of the right adrenal gland measures 6 mm.the left adrenal gland is within normal limits.no retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy is seen.there is no free fluid in the abdomen.
summary: stable appearance of nodular adrenal gland.stable appearance with multiple sclerotic areas throughout the bones and stable pathologic fracture of the left seventh rib posterolaterally.

examination.otherwise, no enlarged lymph nodes are noted in the axillary and remaining mediastinal regions.the right hilum is clear.there is a bovine arch.the aorta is otherwise unremarkable.the esophagus images normally.the heart is normal in size.there is no pericardial effusion.a port is noted in the superficial right anterior chest wall with a catheter from a right subclavian approach terminating within the right atrium.bronchioles to the anterior and lateral basal segment of the left lower lobe are splayed secondary to mass lesion (see below).otherwise, no obvious bronchial cavity has been filled with fluid.the pleural-based nodular density in the posterior basal segment of the left lower lobe is again noted and stable at approximately 6 mm in size.a new ovoid nodular stable at approximately 7 mm.at least three nodular opacities along chain sutures in the medial right upper lobe are present.the more cephalad component has enlarged with the more caudal extent consistent with prior left mastectomy.there are subtle fibrotic changes along the periphery of the lingula likely secondary to radiation changes.
summary: interval progression of metastatic burden in the lungs.the large cavitary lesion in the left lower lobe has filled in centrally with fluid but has enlarged in the interval.two nodules proximal to that lesion, likely metastatic lymph nodes in the left hilum, have also enlarged.there is a new nodule in the superior segment of the left lower lobe as well.of note (not mentioned above), there has been interval improvement in the more post- obstructive atelectasis noted in the anterior basal left lower lobe.left lower lobe, right middle lobe, and left apical nodules have remained stable in size.there has been interval development and enlargement of lesions along sutures in the medial left apex.

text: examination of the pulmonary arteries shows a pulmonary embolus within the left lower lobe medial basilar segment of the pulmonary artery.there is also filling defect within the apical posterior branch of the right upper lobe pulmonary artery.other smaller pulmonary emboli may be present as well.there are small bilateral pneumothoraces, and bilateral chest tubes are in place.there are dependent atelectatic changes bilaterally, and a ground glass appearance of the lingula as well as the right lower lobe.there are interstitial changes at the right lower lobe as well.the gastric pull up is seen within the chest.the central airways are patent to the segmental bronchi bilaterally.there is bilateral subcutaneous air associated with the chest tubes.there is a thoracotomy defect of the right fifth rib posteriorly.no other osseous abnormalities are noted.multiplanar reformatted images are used to confirm these findings.
summary: bilateral pulmonary emboli and pneumothoraces with postop changes as described above.the findings were discussed with the surgical house staff immediately after the examination.

text: the heart is normal in size.there is new hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy with the largest lymph node noted in the subcarinal region measuring 3.2 x 2.5 cm, demonstrating heterogeneous enhancement.also noted are bilateral hilar lymph nodes which are mildly enlarged by size criterion including a right hilar lymph node measuring 1.1 x 1.3 cm and a left hilar lymph node measuring 1.2 cm (3:32).comparison to the prior study is limited secondary to lack of intravenous contrast administration previously.multiple prominent paraesophageal\aortic lymph nodes are noted, some unchanged compared to the prior study including a left sided paratracheal node that was previously fdg avid.a right sided paratracheal node at the thoracic inlet (3:8) is newly enlarged.normal-appearing axillary lymph nodes are noted bilaterally.evaluation of the lung parenchyma demonstrates no pulmonary nodules or masses.there are no consolidations or pleural effusions.atelectasis is noted at the lung bases bilaterally.they patient is status post total thyroidectomy.

text: the pulmonary arteries are well opacified out to the subsegmental branches.there is no evidence for pe.the heart and great vessels are unremarkable.there are no pericardial or pleural effusions.no pathologically enlarged axillary, mediastinal or hilar lymph nodes are seen.lung windows demonstrate innumerable pulmonary nodules bilaterally, consistent with patient's known history of metastatic renal cell ca.there is also effacement of the posterolateral wall of the trachea on the right (series 2, image 154).this could represent metastatic involvement to the trachea.this finding was not seen on the prior ct, though there was considerable respiratory artifact at this level previously.the previously identified infiltrates have cleared in the interval.very limited evaluation of the upper abdomen reveals evidence for a replaced left hepatic artery.there is a small hiatal hernia.bone windows demonstrate mild degenerative changes of the spine.no definite metastatic lesions are appreciated.the above findings were confirmed with the multiplanar reformations.

text: there is no evidence of aortic dissection or pulmonary embolism although distal subsegmental pulmonary vessels are suboptimally opacified.an ng tube is noted in situ, terminating in the stomach.there is a right subclavian catheter extending up to the medial portion of the right subclavian vein, as reported earlier on the same day.biapical emphysema is noted.there is confluent consolidations in the both lower lobes as well as in the right middle lobe with small bilateral pleural effusions.the central airways are also thickened.there are two discrete lung nodules measuring 3-mm and 2-mm(2a:53, 55) in the right lower lobe, and a possible additional right lobe lobe nodule (3: 58).extensive peribronchovascular opacities are also seen in the upper lobes, especially on the left.a few thickened interlobular septa are noted, but these are not widespread.a nodule in the left lobe of the thyroid measures 22 mm in diameter.a smaller nodule in the right lobe measures 13 mm.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism.multifocal lung opacities, including extensive bibasilar consolidations, suggestive of pneumonia.radiographic follow-up to resolution is recommended.if opacities fail to resolve, a follow-up chest ct could be considered.small discrete nodules (less than 4 mm).if the patient has a risk factors for malignancy, then a chest ct could be considered in six months.otherwise, follow-up is probably unnecessary according to the ___ society guidelines, although short-term follow-up within three months is recommended if radiographic opacities do not resolve.colitis involving much of the colon, with findings most prominent in the ascending colon and with probable rectal involvement.major differential considerations include an antibiotic-associated colitis or ischemia associated with a low-flow state.hyperdense renal cyst in the right upper pole, for which ultrasound imaging is recommended.thyroid nodules, for which ultrasound evaluation is also recommended when clinically appropriate.hyperenhancing adrenals, may reflect shock adrenals in the current clinical setting.

text: note is made of bilateral pleural effusions as well as atelectasis.the patient is intubated.the tip of the et tube is identified 2.7 cm proximal to the carina.ng tube is in situ.there is no evidence of any pulmonary embolus.the aorta is normal in caliber with no evidence of any dissection.upper cuts of the abdomen reveals some fluid around the liver and some intraperitoneal fluid in the left upper quadrant, which may be secondary to postoperative change.note is made of prevascular, ap, and right hilar lymph nodes, which are prominent.the largest of these in the prevascular space measures 10 mm in short axis diameter.the bony windows reveal fractures in the left ribcage in relation to ribs number one, five, six, seven, and eight.the thoracic vertebrae are unremarkable.on the lung windows, note is made of some mild interstitial edema.multiplanar reconstructions were essential in depicting the anatomy and identifying any pathology.

text: the pulmonary arteries are patent without evidence of filling defects to suggest pulmonary embolism.coronary calcifications are identified.the heart size is normal.there is a right ij tunneled dialysis catheter.there is low attenuation material around the svc portion of the catheter consistent with fibrin sheath or a thrombus.it essentially includes a short segment of the svc.the inferior svc is reconstituted through the azygos vein.there is opacification of numerous collaterals in the right upper chest and neck.there is discontinuous flow across the right subclavian vein.this could be secondary to thrombus or positioning of the patient's arm above her head.axillary, mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes do not meet ct criteria for pathologic enlargement.there is linear atelectasis at the left lung base.the lungs are otherwise clear.there are no pleural effusions.visualized portions of the upper abdomen are unremarkable.
summary: short segment occlusion of the svc secondary to fibrin sheath or thrombus around the dialysis catheter.numerous large collateral veins in the upper chest and neck are observed and the svc reconstitutes inferiorly through the azygos vein.discontinuity of flow through the right subclavian vein could be secondary to thrombosis or could be related to arm positioning.no evidence of pe.

text: chest ct angiogram: there are no filling defects in the pulmonary vasculature to suggest pulmonary embolism.metallic stent is seen extending from the aortic valve to the proximal aspect of the descending thoracic aorta.again is visualized aortic dissection that has not interval change, appearing multiseptated along its entire thoracic course.there has been interval decrease in size in the fluid collection that was seen surrounding the root of the aortic graft and the proximal portion of the aortoinnominate bypass.the anterior mediastinum fluid collection is no longer seen.the maximum diameter of the descending thoracic aorta at the level of the carina measures 52 x 57 mm.subsegmental atelectasis is seen in the posterior left lower lobe.there is no pericardial effusion.small quantity of free fluid is seen in the right major fissure.there is a large hiatal hernia.the airways are patent.multiple lymph nodes are seen in the mediastinum, in the prevascular, pretracheal, perihilar, and precarinal regions.the largest one located in the precarinal region measures 11 mm.

text: there is no filling defect within the pulmonary arterial system to suggest pulmonary embolism.an area of band-like atelectasis is seen at the left base.there is a small right pleural effusions with adjacent atelectasis.the lungs are otherwise clear.the heart is mildly enlarged.great vessels appear normal.there is extensive soft tissue density at both hila, likely representing conglomerate lymph nodes.smaller lymph nodes are also noted in the mediastinum.the aorta is heavily calcified.osseous structures are unremarkable.
